caption: Jharia in Jharkhand, India is well known for its old and vast coal reserves in the country which have been explicitly exploited for over a century now. The coal field fires that have been widely spreading underground have had an unignorable impact on environment and inhabitants' way of life here. Above all, the burning lands have taken toll on the future of children of the families that work here, replacing their playful childhood by solid labourhood, and making them look way older than their age. The kids here are used to making countless treks up and down the hills scavenging coal and getting smudged with black coal and dust all over for ensuring survival at the end of the day. This sight of a mother readying her son for school in a place like Jharia where basic primary education is not given much importance gives a sigh of relief. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia
tags: life, nature, natgeoearthday, everydayindia, everydayclimatechange, pollution, tybitto, fire, india, climatechange, people, landscape, reportagespotlight, everydayeverywhere, asia, dailylifeindia

caption: Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: Tashi, a friend of mine in the Zanskar Himalaya rests after a whole summer's day of lugging heavy loads of fodder on to his flat-roofed home. This fodder, the scraps of the green pea harvest, is used to feed the community‚Äôs all-important livestock over the winter. However, Tashi‚Äôs community now faces an ongoing drought as the village's main source of water, the glacier that ran down the mountain behind the village has all but completely retreated due to warming temperatures. The village now relies on a small spring to water their crops, which isn‚Äôt enough and is leading to severely reduced harvests. Furthermore, the summer of 2016 also saw them and the rest of the Zanskar valley suffer a locust plague further exacerbating the impact of water shortages. Climate change in the Himalayas is, by a large margin, accelerating at a greater rate than the rest of the world (excluding the Arctic). The associated impacts such as fast retreating glaciers, larger and more glacial lakes forming, and lack of winter snowfall are all having impacts now and even more so in the short and long term future. -- #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #india #himalayas #zanskar #globalwarming #climatechangeisreal
tags: everydayclimatechange, himalayas, globalwarming, zanskar, climatechange, india, climatechangeisreal

caption: Every morning at 4 a.m. 5-year-old eyes open up to shrug off all thoughts about procrastinating at work which involves seemingly endless treks up and down the burning Jharia, known for its vast and valuable coal resources which are used to prepare coke in the country is nestled in the Damodar valley region in Eastern India. The ever-increasing underground fires and mining practices in a region full of resources have driven the place to the brink of subsidence, pointing towards an impending ecological and human disaster and dismissing hopes for a better future. From the oldest to the youngest, the place has swallowed up all possibilities of living a healthy life for everyone here giving rise to unsafe and dangerous conditions. But the imprints of tiny footsteps on the burning lands have continued to signal the undying spirit of bringing livelihood leaving behind all other aspirations. Dressed in her school dress Aabha (changed name) awaits help to lift a bag full of scavenged coal that weighs around 80 kg on her head while helping her parents on the coal fields of Jharia after returning from school. The children in the mines here are the real diamonds. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia
tags: life, everydayindia, dailylifeindia, pollution, tybitto, landscape, reportagespotlight, everydayeverywhere, natgeoearthday, everydayclimatechange, nature, climatechange, asia, fire, people, india

caption: It started in 1988 when the World Bank issued sanctions on India to deregulate its Seed Policy and establish joint ventures which paved way for the multinational agrochemical and agricultural biotechnology corporation- Monsanto, headquartered in St Louis, Missouri control more than 95% of the cotton production in India today. In the shadow of its world-famous technologies, Monsanto started its dirty work in the country by undemocratically imposing the idea of ‚Äúmanufacturing‚Äù a seed after misusing Indian laws and giving hopes of fighting global warming, saving environment from conventional farming and ensuring sufficient food production for all. Apparently, Monsanto has brought more evil than good. Genetic Engineering is a means to control organisms which has ended up in converting open pollinated seeds to hybrids, thereby turning renewable resources into non-renewable ones. From illegal open-field trials of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMO) as a deliberate act of releasing chemicals in the environment to genetic pollution due to cross pollination- Monsanto started a mysterious biological warfare against India. From a seed to an organism, the contamination spread across all the levels of the food chain posing grave risks to health. Monsanto‚Äôs monopoly in the production of GMOs in India has encouraged monoculture that has marginalised alternatives and restricted access to scientific research, shrinking biodiversity and sustainability. Erratic rains in the cotton belts of Maharashtra (Vidarbha region) have increased cultivation costs with signs of impending drought and diseases. For the last 15 years, Monsanto has been criminally negligent towards its ill-effects on environment and living beings. It has taken away the charm of agriculture- the largest livelihood provider in India by exclusively aiming to earn super profits in the form of royalties paid by local seed companies. Although the present government has imposed a cut of 70% in the royalties paid to the company for its cotton technology, but holding it accountable for its unfavourable implementation before it takes off is more needful. Text - Deepali Y. for #everydayindia Photo - @thevisualactivist
tags: everydayindia

caption: Submitted by @jerenius: This is not a picture of a house with a beautiful view by the sea. It's a picture showing the devastating effects of rising sea levels and soil erosion in Monkey River Town, #Belize, one of the places worst affected by #climatechange. The situation is exacerbated by irrigation and farming methods upstream the river that used to bring sediment to the coast. This house used to have a yard in front if it where they could grow crops. This area is loosing more than 5 meters of the shore each year. Many families have been displaced. The school is nowadays just by the beach, and will soon be flooded unless moved to another location. #everydayclimatechange #climate #environment #photography #everyday #climateimpacts
tags: everydayclimatechange, climatechange, climateimpacts, everyday, environment, belize, climate, photography

caption: Orang Rimba (forest people) or known as Suku Anak Dalam is one of the tribe groups living in the depth of forests in Jambi Province (Sumatra, Indonesia). They are nomadic life based and their lives depend on what is provided by forests. Since the 1970s, many of these peoples have been displaced from their traditional lands by logging companies and palm oil plantations, and for some time have been the target of government settlement projects. #forestproject #saveourforest #saverainforest #deforestation #orangrimba #sukuanakdalam #climatechange #everydayclimatechange
tags: saveourforest, forestproject, saverainforest, sukuanakdalam, everydayclimatechange, climatechange, orangrimba, deforestation

caption: The Tama and Sumida rivers empty into the bay at Tokyo. Photo by Paolo Patrizi @paolopatrizi for @everydayclimatechange Average temperatures in central Tokyo rose more than 5 degrees during the last century and are nearly 4 degrees higher than the national average. This increased temperatures in urban areas like Tokyo is called the heat island effect. Buildings, roads and other things found in abundance in the cities absorb heat during the day and release it at night, keeping the temperatures high. Part of this is caused because Tokyo doesn‚Äôt have many parks or trees. #climatechange #globalwarming #extremeweather #everydayclimatechange #climatechangeisreal #japan #tokyo #Asia
tags: asia, tokyo, globalwarming, extremeweather, climatechangeisreal, everydayclimatechange, climatechange, japan

caption: It's been great to see new audiences stop by for our outdoor #EverydayClimateChange Exhibition! We hope the exhibition encourages more discussions about climate change and how we can make a difference. . @everydayclimatechange shares images by photographers from all over the world regarding climate change. As these photographers are diverse and have different cultures, the assortment of images gathered reflects these varying perspectives. The photographs chosen illustrate the causes and effects of everyday climate change, and possible solutions that different communities are undertaking. . Part of #storiesthatmatter. Stories That Matter, is an annual @objectifscentre programme that looks at critical issues in our world through photography and film. Thanks to the @everydayclimatechange contributors who are sharing these important stories with us! The show continues till 30 Apr. . #climatechange #climatechangeisreal #everydayclimatechange #outdoorexhibition
tags: climatechangeisreal, everydayclimatechange, climatechange, outdoorexhibition, storiesthatmatter

caption: @Regrann from @everydayclimatechange - Photo by Paolo Patrizi @paolopatrizi for @everydayclimatechange As the availability of food, water and energy resources becomes scarcer in an age of detrimental climate change, it will become paramount for food resources to be produced locally and for individuals, families and communities to become self-sufficient in regards to food, waste and energy. A growing number of people in the famously crowded Tokyo metropolis are becoming city farmers, planting crops atop tall buildings or deep underground. City farming also offers a solution for another problem in Tokyo and other major cities ‚Äî the so-called urban heat-island effect. On this rice field, metal halide lamps and high-pressure sodium lamps are used. The lights can go up and down so that they can be adjusted accordingly to the rice growth. In this environment, rice can be harvested three times a year. A gentle breeze is imitated through a fan. This prompts pollination and also lowers the temperature in the room. The state ‚Äì of- the art farm, known as Pasona O2, was created by Tokyo- based temporary staffing agency Pasona Group Inc. and was set up as a means of providing agricultural training to young people who are having trouble finding employment and middle-aged people in search of a second career. In the absence of sunlight, the plants are sustained by artificial light from light-emitting diodes, metal halide lamps, and high-pressure sodium vapor lamps. Computer controls the temperature of the room, and the vegetables are grown by a pesticide-free method in which fertilizer and carbon dioxide are delivered by spraying. #cityfarming #rice #climatechange #globalwarming #extremeweather #everydayclimatechange #climatechangeisreal #japan #tokyo #Asia - #regrann
tags: asia, tokyo, globalwarming, extremeweather, regrann, climatechangeisreal, everydayclimatechange, climatechange, cityfarming, japan, rice

caption: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . From Somaliland during this current drought: 4 year old Hamse Ali holds hands with his grandmother Shukri Mohamud Abdi as they walk down one of the dry and dusty streets of Haro Sheikh town in central Somaliland where they live. The self-declared independent state in northwest Somalia is currently suffering a devastating drought after 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years. The last drought was 2011 but this one the community say is worse. Households have lost 95-100% of their livestock, the whole region suffering there is nowhere for people to migrate, and food, water and savings resources are completely depleted. The region is on the verge of famine and this area around Haro Sheikh is suffering the worst of it. Shukri is Chairlady of the Village Savings and Loans Association (VSLA) group Barwaqo whose 22 members have put what money they had saved for themselves towards the community to help cope with the drought. This drought has put pushed the people and their communities to the very edge, the physical and emotional impacts going painfully deep and beyond what is quantifiable, especially when it comes to children. Hamse Ali's parents left in October 2016 taking their livestock west, leaving him and his sister Nada Iud Saleban with their grandmother Shukri. He doesn't know when they will return. . Many people have been asking How Can We Help? >CARE International have been on the ground since before the drought became critical helping communities especially with water resilience projects. If you feel to help you can donate to CARE at www.careinternational.org.uk/donate-1. . . #climatechange #globalwarming #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #mycanon #visualsgang #canonphotos #Somalia #acolorstory #Somaliland #myfeatureshoot #handsinframe #holdinghands #lenscultureportraits #thatsdarling
tags: somalia, handsinframe, womenphotojournalism, holdinghands, documentary, thatsdarling, lenscultureportraits, everydayclimatechange, acolorstory, visualsgang, justbackfrom, myfeatureshoot, photojournalism, somaliland, mycanon, climatechange, canonphotos, reportagespotlight, globalwarming

caption: The retreat of glaciers in GNP. As you can see from this photo overlooking the same spot, the ice field has melted enough to let some trees grow into the side of the mountain. This summer I'll be rangering around this marvelous environment. Scientists predict that there will be no active glaciers by 2030 in GNP, so at least I've got a little bit of time left to experience the driving force of all of this beauty. #climatechange #nps #usgs #glaciernationalpark #rockymountains #rei1440project #findyourpark #everydayclimatechange

caption: Photo by Amnon Gutman @gutmanen for #everydayclimatechange. Mother and child at the village of Setio Patag, Mindanao Matidsalug Manobo tribe have a traditional concept of land ownership based on what their communities consider their ancestral territories. Ancestral lands include cultivated land as well as hunting grounds, rivers, forests, uncultivated land and the mineral resources below the land. As farmers suffer the brunt of global warming's relentless advance, agroforestry seems a viable technique for a better quality and higher yield of harvest despite worsening climate conditions. Agroforestry is essentially a diversification of crops in one farm, thereby diversifying a farmer's income stream as well, Around 400 farmers in Columbio and Esperanza, Sultan Kudarat, and 400 more farmers from Lanuza, Surigao del Sur are looking into Agroforestry to cope with diverse forms of economic shocks and climate vulnerabilities. 40% of the Philippines' domestic food needs and 30% of the country's food exports come from Mindanao, yet in 2011, Typhoon Sendong damaged an estimated $48.4 million worth of properties and livelihood in the area. The following year, Typhoon Pablo devastated Mindanao once again, affecting 6.3 million people, with more than 200,000 homes damaged or destroyed. Major sources of income, like large banana, coconut, corn, and rice farms were flattened to the ground. Mindanao suffered an estimated loss of $780 million. By planting more crops in one area, a farmer relies on several streams of income. If one kind of crop is damaged by a strong typhoon, a farmer practicing Agroforestry will still have other crops to fall back on and sell. Farmers, with the help of some scientists, breed drought-resistant seed varieties, a portion of which are kept in seed banks for the next planting seasons. #climatechange #globalwarming #climatechangephilippines
tags: globalwarming, climatechange, everydayclimatechange, climatechangephilippines

caption: From Somaliland during this current drought: Beautiful girls enjoying the chance to model in the town of Haro Sheikh in central Somaliland. What these girls are going through living in this area is the worst of the drought. Despite the smiles they are on the brink of famine with all the regions food, water, livestock and other resources now completely depleted. This has become a critical life-saving operation. It is impossible to reach everyone everywhere with the limitations of logistics - few roads in a vast country - and too little funding, however there are a few organizations on the ground such as @CAREorg who have been helping since the drought situation first became critical in October 2016. . . . #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #mycanon #dametraveler #girlfriends #girlpower #acolorstory #climatechange #globalwarming #Somaliland #myfeatureshoot #feedfeed #commontable #lenscultureportraits #portrait #portraitphotography #storyportrait #postmoreportraits #colorcrush #ig_world_colors

caption: Kosovo's western landscape, a few kilometers outside the capital. All the way to the right is one of Kosovo's two lignite-fired thermal power plants called Kosovo B. It is a major source of air pollution in Prishtina and surrounding small towns and villages because it releases toxic fumes and ashes. The air in Prishtina in the last few months has been labeled as "Unhealthy‚Äù and even ‚ÄúHazardous‚Äù to breathe - on some days, the quality is worse than Beijing and Delhi. Even so, the Kosovo government is proposing to build ‚Äãa new 600-megawatt lignite coal power plant ‚Äãto replace and refurbish the aging coal plants but local and international environmental ‚Äãand advocacy ‚Äãgroups want to transform Kosovo into a clean energy leader‚Äã and not rely on coal as its sole energy source. #pristina #prishtina #kosovo #air #pollution #landscape #clouds #sky #everydayclimatechange‚Äã‚Äã #photojournalism #kosovocoal‚Äã @everydayclimatechange

caption: A seaweed farmer pulls seaweed into his boat early in the morning on Dal (which means Lake in Kashmiri) in Srinagar, #Kashmir, India on June 13, 2016. Following the Mughal, Afghan, Sikh and Dogra rule, the place has earned the epithet, "Jewel in the crown of Kashmir‚Äù. However the rule of #ClimateChange is yet to be factored into its history books. Climate change is warming lakes around the world at an alarming rate, threatening freshwater supplies and ecosystems, says the largest study of its kind led by an Indian-origin researcher. The study which spanned six continents and a total of 236 lakes, representing more than half of the world‚Äôs freshwater supply, were monitored for at least 25 years. ‚ÄúWe found that lakes are warming at an average of 0.34 degrees Celsius each decade all around the world, threatening freshwater supplies and ecosystems,‚Äù said study lead author Sapna Sharma in an interview with The Hindu. ‚ÄúThis can have profound effects on drinking water and the habitat of fish and other animals‚Äù #everydayclimatechange

caption: #Rensta #Repost: @danielbeltraphoto via @renstapp ¬∑¬∑¬∑ ‚Äú After declining off from a peak in the 1990s and early 2000s, Amazon deforestation increased last year for the first time in the past decade. The forces behind deforestation are myriad: industry, agriculture, mining, but ‚Äúprogress" often comes at an untold cost. https://goo.gl/EEdDdW I just returned from a month long assignment for @greenpeaceuk to document this increase in deforestation. This is an aerial view of the western branch of the Rio Ua√ßa as it meanders through rainforest land west of Parque Nacional do Cabo Orange in Brazil. Beyond that the protection of these lands is vitally important in efforts to stem global warming and climate change, these lands offer a shrinking window into what a world without human impact once looked like. While the new American presidential administration is choosing to ignore, lie and cast doubt about man‚Äôs impact on the climate, these alternative facts don‚Äôt mean we can ignore it. We all have to make efforts locally - and globally - to ensure that future generations have a healthy Earth to call home. See more of my images of the Amazon at The Guardian. https://goo.gl/HK85RQ" Let's make a change so everyone can travel and discover this beauty full of life and diversity. #amazondeforestation #amazonrainforest #amazon #climatechange #globalwarming #environment #environmentalism #conservation #brazil #rainforest #trees #amapa #colombia #everydayclimatechange #greenpeace #travel #discover #tourist #fact #wanderlust #viaggio

caption: La perdita delle api minaccia l‚Äôapprovvigionamento alimentare globale. Le api (fondamentali per la produzione di miele, frutta, noci, verdure) sono molto preziose per il nostro ecosistema e sono sempre pi√π in difficolt√† a causa del cambiamento climatico, la monocoltura intensiva (e quindi il mutamento del loro habitat) e soprattutto l‚Äôutilizzo di pesticidi. Le api sono dei bioindicatori capaci di intercettare immediatamente le sostanze inquinanti e devono essere salvaguardate, perch√© grazie all‚Äôimpollinazione contribuiscono in maniera decisiva al mantenimento della biodiversit√† agricola. In Italia, il 2016 √® stato un anno nero per le api e la produzione di miele ha subito un crollo di quasi il 70 per cento rispetto al 2011. In paesi come gli Stati Uniti nel 2015 gli agricoltori hanno perso il 40% delle colonie di questi insetti. . The loss of bees threatens the global food supply. Bees (essential for the production of honey, fruits, nuts, vegetables) are very valuable to our ecosystem and are increasingly hard pressed because of climate change, intensive monocultures (and thus the change of their Habitat) and especially the use of pesticides. Bees are bio-indicators that can immediately detect pollutants and must be safeguarded because thanks to pollination they do a significant contribution to the maintenance of agricultural biodiversity. In Italy, in 2016 it was a bad year for bees and honey production has been plummeting by nearly 70 percent compared to 2011. In the United States in 2015, farmers have lost 40% of the colonies of these insects. . #spring #quincetree #bees #peonies #wisteria #magnoliatree #figtree #flowers #pollination #pollution #climatechange #honeybee #springisintheair #flyaway #capturedmoment #colorshots #parasites #pesticides #honey #profumodiprimavera #primavera #api #everydayclimatechange #animals #natgeo #inquinamento #capturethemoment #yourshotphotographer #streetphotographer #streetphotos

caption: @everydayindia @thevisualactivist for #everydayindia Every morning at 4 a.m. 5-year-old eyes open up to shrug off all thoughts about procrastinating at work which involves seemingly endless treks up and down the burning lands in the open pit coal mines of Jharia till late afternoon. Keeping aside all kinds of harrowing experiences of body ache from previous day's work and sometimes continuing with an ailing stomach, the child wakes up to start his day along with his friends and other people (mostly women) from the vicinity to scavenge coal and balance baskets as heavy as 30 to 50 kg atop his still-developing head on every single trip across the dangerously unsafe and fiery terrains. This is the situation of almost every child who works in these coal fields to earn a living for the family leaving behind all sorts of playful desires of childhood that were fulfilled for most of us, fortunately. Even after being completely aware of the conditions, officials are more concerned about the profits they earn, and the helpless parents choose survival of family over everything else and hence, end up utilizing their most efficient and trusted resources- their children for earning a living at the cost of basic education and carefree childhood. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia
tags: everydayeverywhere, asia, everydayclimatechange, pollution, landscape, nature, reportagespotlight, climatechange, life, fire, india, dailylifeindia, natgeoearthday, everydayindia, people, tybitto

caption: A Mandeaein(Minority religion in Iran) girl,19, wears gloves cause she is throughout her menstrual cycle.she is getting ready to practice for a praying ceremony. Khouzestan Province,#iran,2016. The Mandaeans are often stigmatized as najis, the Muslim concept of ritual uncleanliness, by the larger regional community in which they live. In reality, the Mandaeans take pains to stay clean: they wash themselves extensively before prayer; women wear gloves throughout their menstrual cycle; and water figures prominently in their rites. Still, the stigma inhibits their lives in Iran in a very visceral way. #magnumfoundation #religion #everydayclimatechange #iran #reportagespotlight #middleeast #instagram

caption: A woman holds up a sonogram of the baby she‚Äôs carrying. The mom, who lives in Puerto Rico, thinks she might have contracted Zika during her pregnancy -- but she doesn't really know, because she can't get her hands on her test results. Many doctors in the area are against abortion and therefore don't share results. Yet as the Americas become friendlier for disease-carrying mosquitoes, experts are worried about the spread of Zika and other infectious diseases... #climatechange #zika #zikavirus #pregnancy #infectiousdisease #everydayclimatechange #pr #Journalism #film

caption: #Repost @uletifan Orang rimba tribes take a rest while they going for hunting in the forest. Orang Rimba (forest people) or known as Suku Anak Dalam is one of the tribe groups living in the depth of forests in Jambi Province (Sumatra, Indonesia). They are nomadic life based and their lives depend on what is provided by forests. Since the 1970s, many of these peoples have been displaced from their traditional lands by logging companies and palm oil plantations, and for some time have been the target of government settlement projects. #forestproject #saveourforest #saverainforest #deforestation #orangrimba #sukuanakdalam #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #jambi #tribe #primitive #forest #jungle #people #seadjambi

caption: Mesmerized by beautiful bird beak illustrations digitized by @biodivlibrary When you look at different bird beaks, you‚Äôre seeing a great example of something called adaptation. Adaptations are traits that developed to perform a certain function and allow organisms to thrive in their environment. Although one adaptation might be very useful for a certain species in a specific environment, that same trait might not be useful for another species in a different environment. To understand how adaptations arise, it helps to understand the process of evolution. Populations of plants, animals and other living organisms change over many, many generations. Scientists call this process natural selection. Natural selection happens in a species when individuals that have traits better adapted for their environment survive longer and have more babies. They pass on the beneficial adaptations to their offspring. So, over the generations these adaptive traits become more common in the population until nearly all individuals in a species have the adaptation. In birds, beaks pay a vital role in food gathering and regulating body temperature, and there is evidence that beak size changes with climatic gradients. In 2015, researchers at Deakin University published a paper stating that they had observed certain species in hotter climates that have measurably bigger beaks now than they had in the 19th century. #climatechange #birdsofinstagram #birder #adaptation #naturalhistory

caption: This is definitely one of my favourite and one of the most thought provoking murals in the duikweg/subway on the @nwupuk campus. üòç‚ô• But that aside, @broni_bree and I usually have the nicest late afternoon chats over a cup of javaüòäüíì. No doubt that the issue of the environment arises every now and then, I mean hello, future environmentalists hereüòÇüòí. So ofcourse we get to talking about the tremors/light earthquakes we experienced yesterdayüò∞. This really sparked a conversation about the current state of our environment, and with good reason. And kids, if you haven't noticed yet, it's actually quite bad. That's probably putting it lightlyüòï Like are we not going to acknowledge that climate change is a reality and that the impacts thereof are becoming more and more widespread and prevalent daily?This is basically all of the things we did our projects on in Natural Science back in school ay, think back to Global Warming üòâ. Like the fact that sea levels are rising, that weather patterns are extreme and have become increasingly inconsistent and that we are experiencing more droughts, wildfires, floods, destruction of biodiversity and disruption of food supplies than ever beforeüò¢üò®. And that's not even the last of it.üëà Despite the many alarming signs of the phenomenon that is climate change, our leaders still refuse to acknowledge and address this reality. So I say maybe WE should raise awareness regarding this issue. This starts by educating one person at a time, engaging in these conversations and keeping our leaders accountable. We are destroying our most valuable resource, our home, the only one earth we have. No doubt that there will be consequences, so let's fight for the environment, for earth, her people, and all her inhabitants. üåç ‚ô• üåº #tuesdaythoughts #oneearth #climatechange #thinkgreen #everydayclimatechange #changeispossible #actonclimate #latenightthoughts
tags: climatechange, everydayclimatechange, tuesdaythoughts, actonclimate, thinkgreen, oneearth, changeispossible, latenightthoughts

caption: Every morning at 4 a.m. 5-year-old eyes open up to shrug off all thoughts about procrastinating at work which involves seemingly endless treks up and down the burning Jharia, known for its vast and valuable coal resources which are used to prepare coke in the country is nestled in the Damodar valley region in Eastern India. The ever-increasing underground fires and mining practices in a region full of resources have driven the place to the brink of subsidence, pointing towards an impending ecological and human disaster and dismissing hopes for a better future. From the oldest to the youngest, the place has swallowed up all possibilities of living a healthy life for everyone here giving rise to unsafe and dangerous conditions. But the imprints of tiny footsteps on the burning lands have continued to signal the undying spirit of bringing livelihood leaving behind all other aspirations. Dressed in her school dress Aabha (changed name) awaits help to lift a bag full of scavenged coal that weighs around 80 kg on her head while helping her parents on the coal fields of Jharia after returning from school. The children in the mines here are the real diamonds. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia

caption: Every morning at 4 a.m. 5-year-old eyes open up to shrug off all thoughts about procrastinating at work which involves seemingly endless treks up and down the burning lands in the open pit coal mines of Jharia till late afternoon. Keeping aside all kinds of harrowing experiences of body ache from previous day's work and sometimes continuing with an ailing stomach, the child wakes up to start his day along with his friends and other people (mostly women) from the vicinity to scavenge coal and balance baskets as heavy as 30 to 50 kg atop his still-developing head on every single trip across the dangerously unsafe and fiery terrains. This is the situation of almost every child who works in these coal fields to earn a living for the family leaving behind all sorts of playful desires of childhood that were fulfilled for most of us, fortunately. Even after being completely aware of the conditions, officials are more concerned about the profits they earn, and the helpless parents choose survival of family over everything else and hence, end up utilizing their most efficient and trusted resources- their children for earning a living at the cost of basic education and carefree childhood. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia

caption: Small-scale miners taking a break on a hill overlooking a swamp where they also dive for gold. Compressor mining, as they call it, involves diving into thick mud and staying there for hours to look for gold. They can't see anything and breathes only through a small tube with air provided by a small compressor. For decades, local residents at Paracale town work in hazardous conditions scavenging under the earth and diving into tunnels filled with mud using only makeshift tools to mine for gold, often placing their health and lives at risk. Ban Toxics, a local NGO working at these sites claims that artisanal mining is a poverty driven industry and that small-scale miners typically work in harsh conditions with no proper training, protection, and pollution control methods. Local reports indicated the country produced about 18 tons of gold at a market value of over $700 million in 2014 while 80% of the gold comes from artisanal and small-scale mines which operate without a government license. The Philippines holds the largest copper-gold deposit in the world and is the fifth most mineral-rich country for gold, nickel, copper, and chromite, but massive environmental destruction prompted the new Department of Environment and Natural Resources secretary, Gina Lopez, to threaten many large-scale mining operations of closure. #philippines #reportage #mining #reportagespotlight #onassignment #artisanal #camarinesnorte #everydayphilippines #everydayclimatechange

caption: Documenting the current drought in Somaliland has not been without its challenges. Driving 5 days covering huge distances allowed for only 5hours on the ground to collect images and stories. A pretty tough task, not to mention of course a tough situation to cover physically and emotionally. But as with all my work (which is why I am so passionate about what I do) there are rewards. For those of you familiar with my work you won't be surprised that these are just 2 of the special elements of why I have been able to connect so deeply: WOMEN and COLOUR. #thecolorshift . Image caption: Women wait in line to collect their food aid vouchers at a food distribution by CARE International at a centre in Anaibo Town, central Somaliland. Four consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years in Somaliland, the self-declared independent state in northwest Somalia, has left the region depleted of all its resources and experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 1974. It is on the verge of famine. Women are the basic needs providers for every family as such it is their role to find and collect water and food not only for their family but for their livestock. The food aid package provided by CARE International is not enough to feed livestock, as such each family has seen 95-100% of their animals die, but it has helped over 300,000 people since the drought situation became critical in October 2016. . . . . #documentary #photojournalism #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #women #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #vsco #climatechange #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange @natgeocreative @gettyimagescreative #nothingisordinary #welltravelled #mytinyatlas #calledtobecreative #livecolorfully #dametraveller @space.ram

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . Amina Suleiman Gas, 45 prepares rice while her neighbours daughter Asma Awale Ibrahim, 11 goes to chase a goat out from the kitchen of her homestead where she has lived for 10 years in Barwako village 20kms into the desert from Anaibo Town, central Somaliland. Amina has received food from CARE food aid distributions - wheat, flour, rice, beans, dates, sugar and oil ‚Äì which she says is enough for her, her husband and the children, but not the livestock. Last week she lost 18 of her animals, now she is left with 12. Barwako was a village of 100 families but 245 more have come in from the surrounding area because of the drought. Amina is a member of the Villlage Savings and Loans Association (VSLA) who have shared all their savings with the displaced families, now they have nothing left. "We shared everything with them," Amina says. At least 6.2 million people, more than half the population, need assistance after 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years have left the region depleted of all its resources and experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 1974 and is on the verge of famine. CARE International has helped over 300,000 people with food distributions since the drought situation became critical in October 2016, 200,000 of which receiving water assistance. . . . #climatechange #globalwarming #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #pastoralism #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #vsco

caption: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . Amina Suleiman Gas, 45 prepares rice while her neighbours daughter Asma Awale Ibrahim, 11 goes to chase a goat out from the kitchen of her homestead where she has lived for 10 years in Barwako village 20kms into the desert from Anaibo Town, central Somaliland. Amina has received food from CARE food aid distributions - wheat, flour, rice, beans, dates, sugar and oil ‚Äì which she says is enough for her, her husband and the children, but not the livestock. Last week she lost 18 of her animals, now she is left with 12. Barwako was a village of 100 families but 245 more have come in from the surrounding area because of the drought. Amina is a member of the Villlage Savings and Loans Association (VSLA) who have shared all their savings with the displaced families, now they have nothing left. "We shared everything with them," Amina says. At least 6.2 million people, more than half the population, need assistance after 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years have left the region depleted of all its resources and experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 1974 and is on the verge of famine. CARE International has helped over 300,000 people with food distributions since the drought situation became critical in October 2016, 200,000 of which receiving water assistance. . . . #climatechange #globalwarming #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #pastoralism #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #vsco

caption: Every morning at 4 a.m. 5-year-old eyes open up to shrug off all thoughts about procrastinating at work which involves seemingly endless treks up and down the burning lands in the open pit coal mines of Jharia till late afternoon. Keeping aside all kinds of harrowing experiences of body ache from previous day's work and sometimes continuing with an ailing stomach, the child wakes up to start his day along with his friends and other people (mostly women) from the vicinity to scavenge coal and balance baskets as heavy as 30 to 50 kg atop his still-developing head on every single trip across the dangerously unsafe and fiery terrains. This is the situation of almost every child who works in these coal fields to earn a living for the family leaving behind all sorts of playful desires of childhood that were fulfilled for most of us, fortunately. Even after being completely aware of the conditions, officials are more concerned about the profits they earn, and the helpless parents choose survival of family over everything else and hence, end up utilizing their most efficient and trusted resources- their children for earning a living at the cost of basic education and carefree childhood. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia

caption: Anaibo Internally Displaced People (IDP) camp on the outskirts of Anaibo town in central Somaliland, where CARE internally are carrying out food aid distributions. 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years Somaliland, the self-declared independent state in northwest Somalia has left the region experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 1974. Over 1000 families coming to Anaibo for food aid from the surrounding area but some families fear coming into town not knowing town life and they remain stranded in the desert. At least 6.2 million people, more than half the population, need assistance, the region is depleted of all its resources and is on the verge of famine. This region is now in a critical life-saving situation, visual documentation is key for CARE International's advocacy in order to get immediate fund-raising and support, and to continue their longer term programs on prevention and resilience. . . #lenscultureportraits #portrait #portraitphotography #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #pastoralism #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii #climatechange #globalwarming #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #vsco

caption: Motherfucking #sunflowers can typically grow as high as 2 meters and have flowers as large as 20 centimeters. In the very barren soil in my backyard I planted many of them, and the ones that have managed to survive won't even get to be 10% of the size of industrially produced sunflowers. That's ok with me, pioneering organisms always pay a significant price in getting an stable ecosystem going. caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Amnon Gutman @gutmanen for #everydayclimatechange. Matidsalug Manobo man cross a river on his way back home. Mindanao. Matidsalug Manobo tribe have a traditional concept of land ownership based on what their communities consider their ancestral territories. Ancestral lands include cultivated land as well as hunting grounds, rivers, forests, uncultivated land and the mineral resources below the land. As farmers suffer the brunt of global warming's relentless advance, agroforestry seems a viable technique for a better quality and higher yield of harvest despite worsening climate conditions. Agroforestry is essentially a diversification of crops in one farm, thereby diversifying a farmer's income stream as well, Around 400 farmers in Columbio and Esperanza, Sultan Kudarat, and 400 more farmers from Lanuza, Surigao del Sur are looking into Agroforestry to cope with diverse forms of economic shocks and climate vulnerabilities. 40% of the Philippines' domestic food needs and 30% of the country's food exports come from Mindanao, yet in 2011, Typhoon Sendong damaged an estimated $48.4 million worth of properties and livelihood in the area. The following year, Typhoon Pablo devastated Mindanao once again, affecting 6.3 million people, with more than 200,000 homes damaged or destroyed. Major sources of income, like large banana, coconut, corn, and rice farms were flattened to the ground. Mindanao suffered an estimated loss of $780 million. By planting more crops in one area, a farmer relies on several streams of income. If one kind of crop is damaged by a strong typhoon, a farmer practicing Agroforestry will still have other crops to fall back on and sell. Farmers, with the help of some scientists, breed drought-resistant seed varieties, a portion of which are kept in seed banks for the next planting seasons. #climatechange #globalwarming #climatechangephilippines
tags: repost, everydayclimatechange, globalwarming, climatechangephilippines, climatechange

caption: Jharia in Jharkhand, India is well known for its old and vast coal reserves in the country which have been explicitly exploited for over a century now. The coal field fires that have been widely spreading underground have had an unignorable impact on environment and inhabitants' way of life here. Above all, the burning lands have taken toll on the future of children of the families that work here, replacing their playful childhood by solid labourhood, and making them look way older than their age.The kids here are used to making countless treks up and down the hills scavenging coal and getting smudged with black coal and dust all over for ensuring survival at the end of the day. In a place which has little to do with basic education, watching her daughter excited to go to school brings heartfelt happiness and a deep sense of satisfaction on a mother's face. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. @thevisualactivist for #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia
tags: india, life, climatechange, tybitto, everydayclimatechange, natgeoearthday, everydayeverywhere, dailylifeindia, nature, reportagespotlight, everydayindia, asia, landscape, pollution, fire, people

caption: Jharia in Jharkhand, India is well known for its old and vast coal reserves in the country which have been explicitly exploited for over a century now. The coal field fires that have been widely spreading underground have had an unignorable impact on environment and inhabitants' way of life here. Above all, the burning lands have taken toll on the future of children of the families that work here, replacing their playful childhood by solid labourhood, and making them look way older than their age. The kids here are used to making countless treks up and down the hills scavenging coal and getting smudged with black coal and dust all over for ensuring survival at the end of the day. This sight of a mother readying her son for school in a place like Jharia where basic primary education is not given much importance gives a sigh of relief. Agroforestry is essentially a diversification of crops in one farm, thereby diversifying a farmer's income stream as well, Around 400 farmers in Columbio and Esperanza, Sultan Kudarat, and 400 more farmers from Lanuza, Surigao del Sur are looking into Agroforestry to cope with diverse forms of economic shocks and climate vulnerabilities. 40% of the Philippines' domestic food needs and 30% of the country's food exports come from Mindanao, yet in 2011, Typhoon Sendong damaged an estimated $48.4 million worth of properties and livelihood in the area. The following year, Typhoon Pablo devastated Mindanao once again, affecting 6.3 million people, with more than 200,000 homes damaged or destroyed. Major sources of income, like large banana, coconut, corn, and rice farms were flattened to the ground. Mindanao suffered an estimated loss of $780 million. By planting more crops in one area, a farmer relies on several streams of income. If one kind of crop is damaged by a strong typhoon, a farmer practicing Agroforestry will still have other crops to fall back on and sell. Farmers, with the help of some scientists, breed drought-resistant seed varieties, a portion of which are kept in seed banks for the next planting seasons. #climatechange #globalwarming #climatechangephilippines
tags: globalwarming, climatechangephilippines, everydayclimatechange, climatechange

caption: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . . 80 year old Habibo keeps out of the midday sun inside one of the make-shift tents of the IDP camp outside Haro Sheikh town in central Somaliland. Climate change not only affects our environment but our society and its structure too. It especially impacts those who live in poverty, in drought-prone regions, women (as basic needs suppliers) and children, and the elderly. Older people are more vulnerable to the effects of temperature extremes and have significantly higher mortality risk in extreme weather events. 500 families are now living as internally displaced people (IDPs) in camp outside Haro Sheikh, an area experiencing the worst of the drought. 200-300 households first arrived four months ago, more continue to come every day. After 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years the region is now experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 1974 and is on the verge of famine, the elderly, women and children suffering the most. They are desperately in need of food and water, all their livestock have died. . . . #lenscultureportraits #portrait #portraitphotography #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #pastoralism #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii #climatechange #globalwarming #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #vsco

caption: RG @everydayclimatechange: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. What does 'climate change' mean? In Olkiramatian area at the base of the Ngurumen Hills on the Kenya-Tanzania border, today's dry season demonstrates clearly the terms 'extreme' and 'arid'. Annual rains are now no longer guaranteed and rainfall if it does come is less. As well as the well-known agents of global climate change like carbon emissions there are the many smaller-scale elements contributing massively to local climate change. The Olkiramatian area in Kenya's south Rift Valley is an already arid environment, add to this an increase in population, livestock numbers, tree cutting for charcoal, and the results are significant: a 12 foot drop in the Ewaso Nyiro river level during the dry season, livestock having to move farther distances in search of what minimal if any grazing vegetation is left, and dust storms tearing off the already delicate almost non-existent top soil. The area has become a self-perpetuating system that propels climate change issues still further. How long before it's all gone? #climatechange #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #dust #masai #environment #desert #desertification #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #water #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #reframeclimate #dust #natgeohub #ic_landscapes #photooftheday #sustainableliving #sustainability #apocalypse #livestock
tags: desert, climatechangeisreal, toldwithexposure, natgeohub, climatechange, masai, everydayclimatechange, livestock, globalwarming, sustainableliving, sustainability, environment, ic_landscapes, apocalypse, reframeclimate, photojournalism, documentary, visualsoflife, climate, water, dust, followmetoo, photooftheday, desertification

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . ‚ÄúWe mix paper with water and they think it is food‚Äù. After the worst drought in living memory, Amina Suleiman has nothing but cardboard to feed her cows. ‚ÄúIt is better they have something in their stomach‚Äù, she explains. At least 6.2 million people, more than half the population, need assistance after 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years have left the region depleted of all its resources and experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 1974. Amina has received food from CARE food aid distributions - wheat, flour, rice, beans, dates, sugar and oil ‚Äì which she says is enough for her, her husband and the children, but not the livestock. She realizes they will soon have to carry more animals some hundred meters from the family‚Äôs huts to the place where they are burned. ‚ÄúNow we need food and water. Next we will need new livestock ‚Äì and training for new vocations‚Äù says Amina. This region is now in a critical life-saving situation, visual documentation is key for CARE International's advocacy in order to get immediate fund-raising and support, and to continue their longer term programs on prevention and resilience. . . . #lenscultureportraits #portrait #portraitphotography #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #pastoralism #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii #climatechange #globalwarming #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #vsco

caption: This is Satya Narayana, a farmer in Shamirpet. This region has been experiencing extreme drought in recent years, in part due to climate change. The severe droughts make it especially difficult for farmers to make a reliable income. But protected cultivation in special greenhouses like this one from Kheyti, a social enterprise with the mission of empowering small farmers, allow farmers to reliably grow crops in a protected setting. The greenhouses are fitted with drip irrigation and keep pests out, so farmers are able to more consistently rely on their harvest surviving the tough conditions.

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: We tend to take water for granted, especially the when it comes out of our taps. It is our most precious resource and one that is becoming ever more scarce in a warming world due to climate change. India faces one of its toughest challenges as a developing nation this century as water resources become more scarce amongst a growing and thirty population. Here a woman in a slum settlement in Delhi goes to collect water that only runs for two-hours per day every two days. - #everydayclimatechange #climatechangeisreal #globalwarming #everydayindia #india #water #globalwarming #reportagespotlight
tags: everydayclimatechange, everydayindia, india, reportagespotlight, water, globalwarming, climatechangeisreal, repost

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . Amina Suleiman Gas, 45 stands amidst the carcasses of her dead animals, piled for burning outside the compound where she has lived for 10 years in Barwako village 20kms into the desert from Anaibo Town, central Somaliland. Last week she lost 18 of her animals, now she is left with 12. She sent most of her livestock west with her neighbor in November 2016 when the drought began to get worse and fears they have not survived. Barwako was a village of 100 families but 245 more have come in from the surrounding area because of the drought. Amina is a member of the Villlage Savings and Loans Association (VSLA) who have shared all their savings with the displaced families, now they have nothing left. "We shared everything with them," Amina says. At least 6.2 million people, more than half the population, need assistance after 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years have left the region depleted of all its resources and experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 1974. It is on the verge of famine. CARE International has helped over 300,000 people since the drought situation became critical in October 2016, 200,000 of which have received water assistance. . . . . #lenscultureportraits #portrait #portraitphotography #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #pastoralism #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii #climatechange #globalwarming #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #climatechangeimpact
tags: canon5dmarkiii, mycanon, waterislife, portraitphotography, acolorstory, reportagespotlight, everydayclimatechange, climatechange, portrait, canonphotos, globalwarming, somaliland, lenscultureportraits, repost, climatechangeimpact, documentary, water, pastoralism, womenphotojournalism, safewater, visualsoflife, drought, photojournalism, justbackfrom

caption: @Regrann from @everydayclimatechange - Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: Rainfall patterns across the Indian subcontinent are continuing to change for the worse. Many parts of the country are receiving too little or too much. However, the overall trends point to a much drier landscape in the middle and long-term future due to the increasing effects of climate change. Both rural and urban communities are facing the consequences of these water shortages, especially those peoples found at the bottom of the socio-economic ladder. Pictured are women in a slum settlement on the outskirts of New Delhi washing their bowls and collecting as much water as they can for storage. . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #india #asia #climatechangeisreal #newdelhi #delhi #water #rainfall
tags: climatechange, delhi, asia, india, rainfall, globalwarming, newdelhi, water, climatechangeisreal, everydayclimatechange

caption: We were walking along the stretch of Koh Pao when I saw this villager approaching us from the opposite direction. From a distance, I could see that he has a cigarette neatly tucked away in between his lips, while puffing out little clouds of smoke as he got closer and closer. But it wasn't until he was next to me that I noticed his cigarette, which turned out to be a leaf roll, matches well with his full camo outfit. So in my newly learned Khmer language, I asked him for a portrait and thankfully, behind the fierce demeanour lies a kind and gentle man who was more than willing to pose for a shot. #reportagespotlight #portrait #EverydayEverywhere #wearethestreet #sonyimages #instamagazine_ #sonyA7RII #vsco #summicron35 #leica #myfeatureshoot #singapore #documentary #cambodia #sandmining #sanddredging #environment #children #everydayclimatechange #everydayasia

caption: @Regrann from @leonardodicaprio - #Regram #RG @everydayclimatechange: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. This image of an Amhara boy and his horse in barren fields that should be full of wheat and teff was taken in Wollo 600kms north of Ethiopia's capital Addis in 2008 when the entire region suffered major drought as both the years' rains failed. Ethiopia continues to face the same issues of failed rains and are currently suffering the worst drought in 30 years exacerbated by the El Ni√±o phenomenon. A recent climate change study in the Horn of Africa finds that the land is drying out at an unusually fast pace as a result of soaring greenhouse gas emissions. Associate professor at the University of Arizona and lead author of the study Jessica Tierney said in a statement in the IBTimes, "Given the scale of threats in Africa and across the world, studying the hyper-local impacts of climate change will be critical to helping communities adapt and prepare". In a country where more than eight in ten people depend on rain-fed agriculture, the drought is having a significant impact and the Ethiopian government estimates that more than 9 million people will need humanitarian assistance in 2016. #climatechange #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #ethiopia #documentary #photojournalism #climate #visualsoflife #ethiopia #GlobalClimateChange2015 #News #environment #famine - #regrann
tags: climatechange, climate, globalclimatechange2015, environment, globalwarming, regram, ethiopia, documentary, regrann, rg, famine, everydayclimatechange, visualsoflife, photojournalism, news

caption: Today marks the launch of the new ¬£1 coin. A 12 sided coin that is being billed as the 'most secure coin in the world'. But is it helping to secure a world free of climate change that we want to see? The banks a lot of us save and spend our money with are still investing in fossil fuels which are causing climate change. To mark the occasion, use your new pound coin for good. Post a picture of your new coin and share messages with the banks - @royalbank @barclaysuk @hsbc and Lloyds Bank - asking them to keep the future of this coin and all other investments clean by making the Big Shift to renewable energy. #newpoundcoin #poundcoin #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #currency #changeiscoming #money #moneymoneymoney #brighterdays #brighterfuture #divestment #keepitclean #campaigners #solarpower

caption: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . Amina Suleiman Gas, 45 stands amidst the carcasses of her dead animals, piled for burning outside the compound where she has lived for 10 years in Barwako village 20kms into the desert from Anaibo Town, central Somaliland. Last week she lost 18 of her animals, now she is left with 12. She sent most of her livestock west with her neighbor in November 2016 when the drought began to get worse and fears they have not survived. Barwako was a village of 100 families but 245 more have come in from the surrounding area because of the drought. Amina is a member of the Villlage Savings and Loans Association (VSLA) who have shared all their savings with the displaced families, now they have nothing left. "We shared everything with them," Amina says. At least 6.2 million people, more than half the population, need assistance after 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years have left the region depleted of all its resources and experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 1974. It is on the verge of famine. CARE International has helped over 300,000 people since the drought situation became critical in October 2016, 200,000 of which have received water assistance. . . . . #lenscultureportraits #portrait #portraitphotography #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #pastoralism #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii #climatechange #globalwarming #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #vsco
tags: acolorstory, drought, mycanon, vsco, everydayclimatechange, documentary, somaliland, justbackfrom, water, canonphotos, portrait, womenphotojournalism, climatechange, visualsoflife, waterislife, pastoralism, photojournalism, lenscultureportraits, canon5dmarkiii, reportagespotlight, portraitphotography, globalwarming, safewater

caption: #Repost @ravimishraindia „Éª„Éª„Éª Watching Karu, a small child sitting alone on top of a pile of rocks surrounded by coal, soiled by black dust, turning his back to the rest of the world makes me reflect on the state of existence of children in the coalfields of Jharia. The kid seems to have become more familiar with coal than anything else around. This makes me recall the days when I was a child and how cluelessly, at the age of 13, I embarked on an unknown journey of life, with no one else around me, it reminded me of the time when I had to take tough decisions in situations that offered hardly any choices and how I had to work for 20-21 hours to ensure survival. The plight of kids here in Jharia is disheartening. Almost every child lives a life that many of us can't even think of. The word 'childhood‚Äô holds no meaning in their lives. Working conditions in the coalfields are such that a mere slip of foot would result in death from coal fire. Children who have hardly completed a decade of their lives, have dry scaly skin, already. The limbs that are supposed to be nurtured with oil and sports are found smeared in coal and black dust. The air that they respire does no good, either. Their faces are smudged with ashes and soot. Their growth stunted. It is difficult to digest the fact that children as young as 5 get up at 4 in the morning and walk for hours- only to earn a living! It feels terrible to watch such small kids scavenging coal, picking up numerous baskets, making countless treks up and down the hills, getting stained with black coal in a dangerously polluted and unsafe region, leaving behind their childhood- only to find means of survival. But, there's a gleam of hope that comes out of their sparkling eyes as they speak. The smile that shoves off every dust particle on their face overpowers all odds.‚Ä® @thevisualactivist for #everydayindia #PVCHR #u4humanrights #India #Asia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #tybitto #reportagespotlight #Jharia #everydaychildhood
tags: u4humanrights, repost, everydayeverywhere, pvchr, everydayclimatechange, reportagespotlight, india, everydayindia, everydaychildhood, tybitto, jharia, asia

caption: #Repost @ravimishraindia „Éª„Éª„Éª "I had discontinued school after my father's demise", says Sadaam Khan, 14. He recalls having left school after his third grade. Sadaam has been earning his bread since 5-6 years by scavenging coal in Jharia. When asked if he would like to resume school, he promptly replies with a 'yes'. From "I'll become whatever destiny holds for me" to "I want to become an Engineer" Sadaam's future aspirations reflect his high hopes from life. I asked him if there was anything that he would like to ask from the rest of the world. He replied, "I would ask for the fulfillment of my dream of becoming an Engineer after studying well." This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia #everydaychildhood
tags: dailylifeindia, repost, people, everydayclimatechange, pollution, india, nature, fire, tybitto, life, climatechange, asia, everydayeverywhere, reportagespotlight, landscape, natgeoearthday, everydayindia, everydaychildhood

caption: After declining off from a peak in the 1990s and early 2000s, Amazon deforestation increased last year for the first time in the past decade. The forces behind deforestation are myriad: industry, agriculture, mining, but ‚Äúprogress" often comes at an untold cost. https://goo.gl/EEdDdW I just returned from a month long assignment for @greenpeaceuk to document this increase in deforestation. This is an aerial view of the western branch of the Rio Ua√ßa as it meanders through rainforest land west of Parque Nacional do Cabo Orange in Brazil. Beyond that the protection of these lands is vitally important in efforts to stem global warming and climate change, these lands offer a shrinking window into what a world without human impact once looked like. While the new American presidential administration is choosing to ignore, lie and cast doubt about man‚Äôs impact on the climate, these alternative facts don‚Äôt mean we can ignore it. We all have to make efforts locally - and globally - to ensure that future generations have a healthy Earth to call home. See more of my images of the Amazon at The Guardian. https://goo.gl/HK85RQ #amazondeforestation #amazonrainforest #amazon #climatechange #globalwarming #environment #environmentalism #conservation #brazil #rainforest #trees #amapa #ghostforest #everydayclimatechange #greenpeace #greenpeaceuk
tags: environmentalism, greenpeaceuk, everydayclimatechange, amazonrainforest, brazil, ghostforest, greenpeace, trees, climatechange, environment, conservation, amazondeforestation, rainforest, amapa, globalwarming, amazon

caption: The screenings for our #storiesthatmatter programme may be over, but come by still for the #EverydayClimateChange Exhibition, running till 30 Apr. . @everydayclimatechange shares images by photographers from all over the world regarding climate change. As these photographers are diverse and have different cultures, the assortment of images gathered reflects these varying perspectives. The photographs chosen illustrate the causes and effects of everyday climate change, and possible solutions that different communities are undertaking. . Part of #storiesthatmatter. Stories That Matter, is an annual @objectifscentre programme that looks at critical issues in our world through photography and film. Thanks to the @everydayclimatechange contributors who are sharing these important stories with us! . #climatechange #climatechangeisreal #everydayclimatechange #outdoorexhibition

caption: #Repost @ravimishraindia „Éª„Éª„Éª "Every time I pick up the basket, my head aches, but it recovers after some time", recollects Sandeep, a 13-year-old boy who shares his experience of working in the coalfields of Jharia while scavenging coal since last one year. Sandeep , who used to help his father in the fields earlier, has never been to a school. On being asked about his desire/dream, he says that he dreams of riding a tempo rickshaw after growing up in order to earn a living. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia #everydaychildhood

caption: #Repost @ravimishraindia „Éª„Éª„Éª "I can lift almost 30- 50 kg of coal at a time", recounts Gautam Kumar Yadav, 13, who has been working in the coalfields of Jharia since the age of 5 i.e. for eight long years! With Hindi as his favourite subject, Gautam goes to school and studies in fourth grade, presently. Although unable to recall much of his learnings from the subject, he tells that he is strong in the field and can cope with peculiarities like headaches. While appreciating him for his dedication, I asked him about his dream. Aiming high, he said that he would love to join the Police services or become a Doctor or work with BCCL -a subsidiary of Coal India Limited. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #PVCHR #tybittoo #everydaychildhood

caption: #Repost @ravimishraindia „Éª„Éª„Éª Babu (Changed name),6, poses for a portrait in Jharia, Jharkhand. I first met Babu in 2014, a 3-year-old toddler then, whose face was covered with black dust blowing out of the coal burning just a few metres away from him. It was very scary to see him sitting and playing so close to the fire all alone, so I moved him away from it. Seeing toddlers and young children around the burning coal is a very common scene, but, mostly there is an adult around, so I was a little surprised to see Babu sitting alone. Hence, I asked the people around about the whereabouts of his parents. I was informed that Babu had lost his parents in an accident, and is being raised by his grand parents. I have been meeting Babu every time I go back to Jharia. My eyes fill with tears of joy every time I see him, but it also breaks my heart to see a toddler turning into a man, seeing him missing out on being a child. It's heartbreaking to watch him carry chunks of scavenged coal, and not being given a chance to study, play and have a childhood. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #January2017 #everydaychildhood
tags: repost, people, everydayclimatechange, pollution, india, nature, fire, life, climatechange, january2017, asia, everydayeverywhere, reportagespotlight, landscape, natgeoearthday, everydayindia, everydaychildhood

caption: #Repost @ravimishraindia „Éª„Éª„Éª Salman (10) poses for a portrait in Jharia, Jharkhand. I dream of becoming an engineer and help my family by getting a Job where I can earn more then 100 - 120 RS (approx 2 USD), I get very tired because we start walking (working) at around 4 A.M everyday, and walk (work) till late in the afternoon. The scavengers around this region start their day long before the sun rises in the sky, a big group of scavengers, especially women and young children between the age group of 8 to 15, begin the first of countless treks down a steep and narrow switchback into the open pit mine to scavenge chunks of coal, which they carry back to the surface in baskets balanced atop their heads. This year I will be sharing some of my favourite stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #January2017 #everydaychildhood

caption: Pastoralists bring their livestock home after grazing them on the ever depleting rangeland in the Afar Region of Ethiopia. In the foreground, camels try to graze on the invasive species, Prosopis. This thorny tree is fast encroaching on the already shrinking grazing land, depleting the water table and hindering pastoralists access to the rangeland. Erratic rainfall and more frequent droughts are further undermining the viability of pastoral livelihoods in the area, placing more pressure on scarce resources and exacerbating conflict between the Afari and Somali tribes. #ethiopia #africa #climatechange #drought #internationaldevelopment #pastoralism #livelihoods #everydayclimatechange #resilience #travel

caption: Fishermen returning home at sunset in Lavanono ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ The severe 3 yr drought in Southern Madagascar has pushed coastal communities to rely more heavily on fishing for their livelihoods. The changes in ocean climate combined with the heavy fishing from deep sea trawlers make for smaller catches in Lavanono. Fisherfolk across Madagascar and the globe are threatened by climate change and the globalization of the seafood supply chain. #everydayclimatechange #climatechange

caption: Fishermen children playing in the rain, Koh Sralao village, Koh Kong. This village used to be a thriving fishing community in the past but after the sand dredging companies came and destroyed most of their fishing spots, many families struggled to make ends meet with the income they earned from just fishing. This eventually forced them to migrate elsewhere for other employment opportunities; some went to Thailand to work in farms while others headed to the town centres or special economic zones. But life there isn't any easier either with long overtime hours and sometimes, back breaking labour too. Currently, villagers estimate that there are only 300 to 400 families left behind in Koh Sralao. A drop from the 700 families that used to live in the village just 10 years ago. #reportagespotlight #portrait #EverydayEverywhere #wearethestreet #sonyimages #instamagazine_ #sonyA7RII #vsco #summicron35 #leica #myfeatureshoot #singapore #documentary #cambodia #sandmining #sanddredging #environment #children #everydayclimatechange #everydayasia

caption: A woman shades herself from the midday sun in one of hundreds of make-shift tents providing shelter for 500 families now living as internally displaced people (IDPs) around the town of Haro Sheikh 60km east of Hargeisa the capital of Somaliland. 200-300 households first arrived four months ago, more continue to come every day. They are desperately in need of food and water, all their livestock have died. "We have a little water in our wells but the water has become salty, people are starting to suffer diarrhea", says Jamal Hussein, Deputy Mayor of Haro Sheikh. After 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years the region is now experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 1974 and is on the verge of famine. This area around Haro Sheikh is experiencing the worst of the drought. All food, water, livestock and other resources are completely depleted, it has now become a critical life-saving operation. @CAREorg has helped over 300,000 people since the drought situation first became critical in October 2016, 200,000 of which have received water assistance but it is impossible to reach everyone everywhere with the limitations of logistics and funding #myfeatureshoot . . #lenscultureportraits #portrait #portraitphotography #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #pastoralism #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii @CareIntUk #climatechange #globalwarming #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #refugees

caption: The pelicans are showing up on the wildlife cameras that were set up on Gunnison! For more pelican spotting you can log on to GSPELIproject.org Gunnison Island in the Great Salt Lake is a harsh remote place to nest for the American White Pelicans. But the migratory birds choose to breed here in one of the largest colonies of North America because of those same reasons, because of how untouched and inaccessible it is to human or animal invasion. The nesting survival rate for the pelicans on the island is low (close to 0.25) as the birds have to fly far to forage for food and freshwater bays. The eggs either get destroyed in harsh weather conditions and if they do hatch, then the fledglings have to learn to fly miles to learn how to feed themselves. Now, with the lake levels going down due to water diversions and climate change, a land bridge has formed to Gunnison, giving access to predators such as coyotes who can destroy colonies at a time. Furthermore, freshwater bays like Bear River Bay are drying up, due to which the birds may have to fly farther in many trips to feed their juveniles, causing starvation and dehydration for the chicks who are waiting to be fed. A baby pelican needs to be fed almost 150 pounds of fish before it turns into a fledgling and learns to fend for itself. The cameras have been setup to monitor the land bridge and gather more data on the birds #climatechange #research #birds #everydayclimatechange #remotecameras
