caption: We the great rulers of the planet earth. We the smartest and the most successful specie of them all. We have impeccable minds. But wait this is not how it goes these days let's see..... We the dictators of the planet earth. We the dominants every specie lives according to us. We have the most disastrous minds. In conclusion "WE THE DESTROYERS". For the past 2 centuries research is being done, warnings have been given, scientists have been saying that we are degrading this planet and we have to stop before something major happenes. Guess what there is going to be no sea ice by the year 2040, more than 50 species are going to be extinct, sea levels are going to rise which will result in submersion of major cities and countries and I am telling you one day we will be among the endagered species. It was once said that don't push someone loyal to you to the point where they do not care. We have pushed our mother earth again and again and again and now I am sure she doesn't cares. Antarctica recently hit it's record breaking high temperature(17.5 Celsius), almost every Caribbean country is going underwater..... I can end this right away by telling you to do something that will have help us but I think the only thing I can tell you right now is "If we continue hurting this planet one day this planet will also hurt us and when it does we will never be able to make up to it and say our sorry". Do what needs to be done or one day we will be looking for some alternative but mind it there is no Planet B. #changeclimatechange #earthhour #earth #pollution #climatechange #environment #globalwarming #change #last #chance #inhuman #to #human #earth #climatechange #environment #sustainable #energy #pollution #airpollution #farming #renewablesources #world #article #cropburning #renewableenergy #ecosystem #nature #greenpeace #greenery #awareness #deforestation #everydayclimatechange #earthhour #hope

caption: Dead animals piled for burning outside the boundary of Xaaxi as a dust devil passes through the town in central Somaliland, the self-declared independent state in northwest Somalia. I've been documenting the situation on the ground in Somaliland for @careorg and scenes like this are everywhere. Each household has lost between 95 and 100 percent of their livestock. In a country where pastoral communities make up around 60 per cent of the population who rely on livestock as a source of income and sustenance, this is a very critical situation. More and more we are seeing this way of life coming under threat because of recurring drought, environmental degradation and livestock depletion. This region has seen 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains and is now experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 2011. All resources are depleted, it is on the verge of famine. There is a window of 2 weeks, from mid until the end of March, in which efforts must be made to reach the population with emergency measures before a full scale famine will occur and people will begin to die in large numbers. This area around Xaaxi is experiencing the worst of the drought. CARE International has helped over 300,000 people since the drought situation became critical in October 2016, 200,000 of which have received some kind of water assistance. WASH (Water, Sanitation and Hygiene), access to clean safe water, the rehabilitation of wells and water transport are key elements in CARE's emergency response on the ground. . . . #vsco #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange @everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #pastoralism #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii @careintuk #climatechange #globalwarming #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #sanitation #dametraveler
tags: acolorstory, everydayclimatechange, reportagespotlight, canon5dmarkiii, water, pastoralism, mycanon, photojournalism, canonphotos, climatechange, drought, justbackfrom, sanitation, somaliland, womenphotojournalism, documentary, visualsoflife, vsco, dametraveler, waterislife, globalwarming, safewater

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Ed Kashi @edkashi/@VIIPhoto for @everydaylimatechange. Agricultural laborers harvest rice in Balliputtuga, India on Jan. 27, 2016. India‚Äôs rice production is under threat from climate change, according to a report from the World Bank. Average temperatures have increased while rainfall at the end of the growing season has decreased, resulting in lower yields over the short and long term. This is bad news for farmers as well as for India as a whole: the former because it means less product and the latter because if the trend persists, India will be forced to increase imports of grain for consumption. #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #climatechangeisreal #climate #globalwarming #EarthHour
tags: everydayclimatechange, climatechangeisreal, earthhour, repost, climate, climatechange, globalwarming

caption: Photo by Ed Kashi @edkashi/@VIIPhoto for @everydaylimatechange. Agricultural laborers harvest rice in Balliputtuga, India on Jan. 27, 2016. India‚Äôs rice production is under threat from climate change, according to a report from the World Bank. Average temperatures have increased while rainfall at the end of the growing season has decreased, resulting in lower yields over the short and long term. This is bad news for farmers as well as for India as a whole: the former because it means less product and the latter because if the trend persists, India will be forced to increase imports of grain for consumption. #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #climatechangeisreal #climate #globalwarming #EarthHour
tags: everydayclimatechange, climatechangeisreal, earthhour, climate, climatechange, globalwarming

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . Dead animals piled for burning outside the boundary of Xaaxi as a dust devil passes through the town in central Somaliland. Scenes like this are currently everywhere in Somaliland with each household losing between 95 and 100 percent of their livestock. Pastoral communities make up around 60 per cent of the Somali population and livestock trade is arguably the most important source of household income with pastoralists relying on their animals as a source of income and sustenance. Now we are seeing this way of life coming under threat because of recurring drought, environmental degradation and livestock depletion. After 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years Somaliland, the self-declared independent state in northwest Somalia is now experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 2011 and is on the verge of famine. There is a window of 2 weeks, from mid until the end of March, in which efforts must be made to reach the population with emergency measures before a full scale famine will occur and people will begin to die in large numbers. This area around Xaaxi is experiencing the worst of the drought. On assignment for CARE International who have helped over 300,000 people since the drought situation became critical in October 2016, 200,000 of which have received water assistance. WASH (Water, Sanitation and Hygiene), access to clean safe water, the rehabilitation of wells and water transport are key elements in CARE's emergency response on the ground. . . . #vsco #documentary #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange #womenphotojournalism @Catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight #justbackfrom #waterislife #mycanon #visualsoflife #canonphotos #pastoralism #acolorstory #canon5dmarkiii @CareIntUk #climatechange #globalwarming #Somaliland #drought #water #safewater #sanitation #lenscultureportraits
tags: acolorstory, everydayclimatechange, lenscultureportraits, reportagespotlight, canon5dmarkiii, water, pastoralism, mycanon, photojournalism, canonphotos, climatechange, drought, justbackfrom, sanitation, somaliland, womenphotojournalism, documentary, visualsoflife, vsco, repost, waterislife, globalwarming, safewater

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by James Whitlow Delano @jameswhitlowdelano for @everydayclimatechange This Amazonian water world may seem eternal but, of course, it is not and it is quite vulnerable to climate change. Scientists say that Ecuador‚Äôs volcanos have lost 40% of their glacier cover since 1976 due to climate change. Those glaciers, like all Andean Peaks, are the water tower source for the Amazon Basin river system. As the glaciers melt, the source the major rivers of the Amazon Basin will be diminished and the upriver wetlands will be threatened. The Rio Napo already a broad river just 50 km (31 miles) from the Andes stretches out into the Amazon Basin. Coca, Ecuador. #water #climatechange #globalwarming #Amazon #everydayclimatechange #Amazonbasin #environment #andes #meltingglaciers

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . Sharing the magical dawn light and mist of the Aberdare Forest in Kenya on International Day of Forests 21 March2017, a platform to raise awareness of the importance of all types of woodlands and trees, and celebrate the ways in which they sustain and protect us. . Forests are important in determining the accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere; they absorb 2.6 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide each year, about one-third of the carbon dioxide released from the burning of fossil fuels. . Forests have four major roles in climate change: they currently contribute about one-sixth of global carbon emissions when cleared, overused or degraded; they react sensitively to a changing climate; when managed sustainably, they produce woodfuels as a benign alternative to fossil fuels; and finally, they have the potential to absorb about one-tenth of global carbon emissions projected for the first half of this century into their biomass, soils and products and store them - in principle in perpetuity. . By reducing forest loss, we can reduce carbon emissions and fight climate change. It's that simple. ... . . . . . #climatechange #globalwarming #ourplanetdaily #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #InternationalForestsDay #trees #Sunrise #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #openmyworld #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #natgeocreative #natgeohub #reframeclimate #ic_landscapes #mycanon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkIII #picoftheday #igkenya #vscokenya @vscokenya @magicalkenya #magicalkenya

caption: The United Arab Emirates‚Äô water consumption is among the highest in the world, with an estimated 350 liters per person per day. The thing that surprised me the most during my time in Dubai was the amount of water that was used in every corner of the city. Guinness-Record swimming pools, fountains and artificial lakes, conditioning systems, green areas and golf courses appear not to be an issue in a city built in the desert. An incredible amount of water is used in particular to keep the public gardens green. In the picture, a worker cuts the grass covering a helicopter landing zone outside a hospital facility. From the series ‚ÄúDubai: the aquarium in the desert‚Äù, 2012 [Archive] #water #grass #reportage #uae #dubai #whywastewater #worldwaterday #reportagespotlight #photojournalism #documentary #travel #travelgram #latergram #climatechange #everydayclimatechange

caption: Article on Climate Tracker - link in bio. ---In the northeastern town of Vienna, a few miles away from Youngstown, Michelle sits in her living room 200 feet away from an injection well. It is one of hundreds drilled in Ohio for the storage of frack waste. When she went to object during the sites construction she was told water contamination was not a valid concern, even though frack brine contains thousands of chemicals known to be carcinogenic and radioactive. Only weeks before the EPA reported that fracking can contaminate drinking sources, concluding what is only logical given the connectivity of groundwater. She‚Äôs been an active voice in the community, part of a band of retired professionals and activists who have dedicated their time to pushing back under the name Frackfree Mahoning Valley. Lynn is one of too, a spitfire woman with no shame in bashing the injustices of the industry. She talks to me about broken neighbor relationships; as one person benefits unequally, as one person is left out entirely, as one person gets hit with the upwind pollution. With irony, as smooth as it is devastating, she says, ‚Äúout of sight, out of mind, see you later, people downstream good luck.‚Äù

caption: Abshir*, 18 months, drinks from a cup of therapeutic feeding formula that is treating his malnutrition in the stabilisation centre for severely malnourished children in Garowe, Somalia. Abshir*, like children across Somalia, is suffering from malnutrition as a result of the severe drought that is affecting countries in the Horn of Africa. 16 million people are on the brink of starvation and in urgent need of food, water and medical treatment across East Africa. 1.4 million children are at imminent risk of starvation on East Africa. We are on the ground in each of the affected countries, urgently working to provide life-saving support to children and families. . . . #Fightingfamine #HornOfAfrica #Malnutrition #Somalia #Somaliland #EverydayClimateChange #Drought #Africa #Famine #DEC #SavetheChildren #Charity #Crisis #SaveLives #charitysunday Photographer credit: Colin Crowley/Save the Children *name changed to protect identity

caption: For World Water Day. . The UN estimates that more than 663 million people do not have a safe water supply close to home. Instead of turning on a tap, they must spend countless hours queueing or trekking to sources of water. This water is often contaminated, putting people at risk of infectious diseases and premature death. . Please use your water responsibly and use eco-friendly soap, detergents and roll papers to prevent further polluting the water resources. Turn off the tap water in between usages no matter how short it is. . . Photo taken farther in the desert of Thar, where the gypsies live with very difficult access to water resources. The woman was carrying home water on her head taken from a common well far away from home. Rajasthan, India. "Deserted and Away" collection. WIP. . . . . . . . . . . #worldwaterday #unitednations #rajasthan #rajasthandiaries #incredibleindia #thar #desert #deserted #desertlife #gypsy #gypsies #everydayindia #everydayasia #everydayeverywhere #everydayclimatechange #watershortage #bbctravel #natgeoyourshot #photographers_of_india #india_gram #desidiaries #postthepeople #stayandwander #worldnomads #nomads #instatraveling #documentaryphotography #adventurevisuals #liveadventurously #theoutbound

caption: Don't cities create illusions of the world we live in? // Last week Montreal - and most of the East coast - experienced a record snowfall of over 30cm ‚ùÑÔ∏è within a single day, this storm momentarily interrupted life in the city and, for a brief moment, we were reminded that beyond our comfortable bubbles, climate change is real and happens every single day. It's easy to forget - especially, when the majority of the world's population live in cities that are built to 'hide' these fluxes. We have very well designed systems that make it possible to live convenient lives in these constant environments: the snow has already been removed, rainfall is drained from our streets, our homes are heated in the winter, and cooled in the summer... the list goes on!! but, in the long run, can this constant comfort last? // thank you @ecielo for always having your phone out to snap a pic! üì∏ by @ecielo
tags: climatechange, montrealmoments, climateaction, montrealcity, snowstorm, everydayclimateaction, snow‚ùÑÔ∏è, montreal2017, everydayclimatechange, globalwarming

caption: We tend to take water for granted, especially the when it comes out of our taps. It is our most precious resource and one that is becoming ever more scarce in a warming world due to climate change. India faces one of its toughest challenges as a developing nation this century as water resources become more scarce amongst a growing and thirty population. Here a woman in a slum settlement in Delhi goes to collect water that only runs for two-hours per day every two days. - #worldwaterday #everydayclimatechange #everydayindia #india #water #globalwarming #reportagespotlight
tags: everydayindia, worldwaterday, reportagespotlight, everydayclimatechange, water, globalwarming, india

caption: What's more important than custom bikes? Almost everything. I've been thirsty but I've never been this thirsty. We encourage you to consider donating to help with famine relief to the charity of your choice as soon as possible. This is bad and its going to get worse. #Repost @ggkenya with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Want to know what drought looks like? Aerial view over Somaliland, the self-declared independent state in northwest Somalia, taken on 19 March 2017. After 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years the region is now experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 2011 and is on the verge of famine. At least 6.2 million people, more than half the population, need assistance. There is a window of 2 weeks, today - now - until the end of March, in which efforts must be made to reach the population with emergency measures before a full scale famine will occur and people will begin to die in large numbers. A de facto state of famine may exist before the government officially declares a state of famine. The question is will emergency aid get to those in need in time? . This week I'm on assignment for @careintuk documenting the drought and famine situation on the ground. Follow me on @ggkenya for more on this story. . . . . . #climatechange #globalwarming #ourplanetdaily #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #Somalia #HornofAfrica #Somaliland #famine #aerial #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #openmyworld #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #natgeocreative #natgeohub #reframeclimate #ic_landscapes #mycanon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkIII #picoftheday @catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight

caption: Always the right time to discuss and highlight problems around water shortage, and more so today, on #WorldWaterDay #Repost @harshavadlamani with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Villagers draw water from two pits they dug themselves in the ground at Honnur in Anantapur district in south-western #AndhraPradesh, #India. The district is Andhra Pradesh's largest and one of its poorest, and also the second driest region in #India, only after Jaisalmer in #Rajasthan. The average rainfall is 381 mm and these pits, about 2km outside the village, are the main source of water for a better part of the year. Farmers here grow peanuts, the only crop they say is suited to the bone dry and sandy terrain of the region while being commercially viable. May 23, 2013. #WorldWaterDay #EveryDropCounts #Water #ClimateChange #EverydayClimateChange #Drought #Raiyatnama
tags: everydropcounts, raiyatnama, andhrapradesh, worldwaterday, india, drought, water, repost, everydayclimatechange, rajasthan, climatechange

caption: Hong and her sister live in a flood prone area in the Mekong Delta. When it floods, transport to and from school is a major challenge and Hong and her siblings often have to stay at home. Local community members have taken flood prevention measures into their own hands, after receiving construction materials and technical training from the Rockefeller Foundation. As a result they have constructed several kilometres of erosion barriers along the riverside in a bid to tackle the issue. #climatechange #flooding #mekongdelta #vietnam #education #development #cantho #resilience #globalwarming #children #portrait #everydayclimatechange #southeastasia

caption: Because of dire working conditions, young #farmers in #Cambodia no longer want to farm. They move out to the city or to another country. This leaves old farmers to keep working in the farm. Recently, because of drought, there have been less harvest of rice and fruits, making it harder for farmers to earn money. Sharing the magical dawn light and mist of the Aberdare Forest in Kenya on International Day of Forests 21 March2017, a platform to raise awareness of the importance of all types of woodlands and trees, and celebrate the ways in which they sustain and protect us. . Forests are important in determining the accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere; they absorb 2.6 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide each year, about one-third of the carbon dioxide released from the burning of fossil fuels. . Forests have four major roles in climate change: they currently contribute about one-sixth of global carbon emissions when cleared, overused or degraded; they react sensitively to a changing climate; when managed sustainably, they produce woodfuels as a benign alternative to fossil fuels; and finally, they have the potential to absorb about one-tenth of global carbon emissions projected for the first half of this century into their biomass, soils and products and store them - in principle in perpetuity. . By reducing forest loss, we can reduce carbon emissions and fight climate change. It's that simple. ... . . . . . #climatechange #globalwarming #ourplanetdaily #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #InternationalForestsDay #trees #Sunrise #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #openmyworld #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #natgeocreative #natgeohub #reframeclimate #ic_landscapes #mycanon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkIII #picoftheday #igkenya #vscokenya @vscokenya @magicalkenya #magicalkenya

caption: Sharing my green beans lunch with a starving gerenuk. After 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years the region is now experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 2011 and is on the verge of famine. There is a window of 2 weeks, today - now - until the end of March, in which efforts must be made to reach the population with emergency measures before a full scale famine will occur and people will begin to die in large numbers. There are grey clouds in the sky today... a sign of hope. . On assignment with @CareIntUk documenting the current drought and famine on the ground in Somaliland. . . . #climatechange #globalwarming #ourplanetdaily #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #Somalia #HornofAfrica #Somaliland #famine #thatsdarling #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #openmyworld #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #natgeocreative #natgeohub #reframeclimate #mycanon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkIII #picoftheday #gettyimagescreative #dametraveler #TravelTuesday

caption: Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: Air pollution over South Korea's capital Seoul. This morning the Air Quality Index in Seoul hit 189, worse than Beijing at 158, according to aqicn.org. Despite this, there are barely any alerts advising people to stay indoors. Air pollution is a public health emergency. According to the World Health Organization over 7 million people die annually due to linked effects from indoor and outdoor pollution. Much of air pollution is sourced from the combustion of fossil fuels, which are also the main driving cause of climate change. . #everydayclimatechange #globalwarming #climatechangeisreal #seoul #southkorea #korea

caption: Small and traditional aspects about people's lifestyle has to be focused upon for a bigger impact. People are yet to be introduced to a sustainable form of living. Still most of the people around the world are practicing techniques like crop burning which causes massive air pollution which affects the entire world.Mass air pollution still being done for the sake of energy procurement for domestic use even after decades of development of sustainable and non -polluting energy sources. Empowerment is required and the only way to empower someone is by exposing them social and economic crisis caused by such activities and providing them with vast knowledge. We have limited time to save our planet. We will either be celebrated by the future generations or we will be vilified by them. Let's not wait for something disastrous to happen first and take initiative now for we are the last best chance for every living thing on this planet. #earth #climatechange #environment #sustainable #energy #pollution #airpollution #farming #renewablesources #world #article #cropburning #renewableenergy #ecosystem #nature #greenpeace #greenery #awareness #deforestation #everydayclimatechange #hope

caption: Photo by @matildegattoni for @everydayclimatechange A villager scraping the soil in search for mica. Mica mining employs everyone in Koderma, from grown-ups to children. Once dug, underground holes spread orizontally, like mine shafts. But the lack of proper instruments and the impossibility of strenghtening the walls means mines collapse frequently, burying and sometimes killing diggers. In a rebel-infested forest in India's poorest state, tens of thousands of illegal miners provide us with an unknown but essential material. Jharkhand has the world's best deposits of sheet mica, an indispensable mineral contained in thousands of items, utilities and machinery we use everyday. From microwaves to TV sets, from beauty products to canned food, from our car's engine parts and tires to the cement our houses are made of, up to sophisticated medical machines and the radar which guides our airplanes, mica is part of our everyday's life. Without it, the world we live in would not be the same. While India produces 60 percent of the globally commercialized mica, in Jharkhand 20,000 men, women and children work everyday in dangerous, collapsing mining pits, earning a little more than one dollar per day to quell the world's hunger for mica. Entangled in a cycle of poverty and indebtedness, miners are at the bottom of an illegal, multibillion-dollar-business which involves an array of complicit authorities, agents, dealers and exporters supplying mica to the rest of the world. #jharkhand #india #mica #mineral #micamining #mines #slavery #deforestation #climatechange #globalwarming #asia #everydayclimatechange
tags: mica, climatechange, jharkhand, deforestation, micamining, asia, india, mineral, everydayclimatechange, slavery, globalwarming, mines

caption: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . Want to know what drought looks like? Aerial view over Somaliland, the self-declared independent state in northwest Somalia, taken on 19 March 2017. After 4 consecutive seasons of failed rains over 3 years the region is now experiencing a drought on a scale not seen since 2011 and is on the verge of famine. At least 6.2 million people, that's more than half the population, need assistance. There is a window of 2 weeks, today - now - until the end of March, in which efforts must be made to reach the population with emergency measures before a full scale famine will occur and people will begin to die in large numbers. A de facto state of famine may exist before the government officially declares a state of famine. The question is will emergency aid get to those in need in time? . This week I'm on assignment for @careintuk documenting the drought and famine situation on the ground. Follow me on @ggkenya for more on this story. . . . . . #climatechange #globalwarming #ourplanetdaily #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #Somalia #HornofAfrica #Somaliland #famine #aerial #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #openmyworld #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #natgeocreative #natgeohub #reframeclimate #ic_landscapes #mycanon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkIII #picoftheday @catchlight.io #ReportageSpotlight

caption: Abshir*, 18 months, drinks from a cup of therapeutic feeding formula that is treating his malnutrition in the stabilisation centre for severely malnourished children in Garowe, Somalia. Abshir*, like children across Somalia, is suffering from malnutrition as a result of the severe drought that is affecting countries in the Horn of Africa. 16 million people are on the brink of starvation and in urgent need of food, water and medical treatment across East Africa. 1.4 million children are at imminent risk of starvation in Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia and South Sudan. . We are on the ground in each of the affected countries, urgently working to provide life-saving support to children and families. . . . #Fightingfamine #HornOfAfrica #Malnutrition #Somalia #Somaliland #EverydayClimateChange #Drought #Africa #Famine #DEC #SavetheChildren #Charity #Crisis #SaveLives #charitysunday Photographer credit: Colin Crowley/Save the Children *name changed to protect identity

caption: After declining off from a peak in the 1990s and early 2000s, Amazon deforestation increased last year for the first time in the past decade. The forces behind deforestation are myriad: industry, agriculture, mining, but ‚Äúprogress" often comes at an untold cost. https://goo.gl/EEdDdW I just returned from a month long assignment for @greenpeace to document this increase in deforestation This is an aerial view of a ghost forest inundated by the construction of a dam on the Rio Araguari, approximately 50 miles north of Macap√°, Brazil. One large dam has been built in the northern state of Amap√°, destroying hundreds of square kilometres of forest, and many more small- and medium-sized dams are planned. The protection of these lands and ecosystems is vitally important in efforts to stem global warming and climate change. While the new American presidential administration is choosing to ignore, lie and cast doubt about man‚Äôs impact on the climate, these alternative facts don‚Äôt mean we too can ignore it. We all have to make efforts locally - and globally - to ensure that future generations have a healthy Earth to call home. See more of my images of the Amazon at The Guardian. https://goo.gl/HK85RQ #amazondeforestation #amazonrainforest #amazon #climatechange #globalwarming #environment #environmentalism #conservation #brazil #rainforest #trees #amapa #ghostforest #everydayclimatechange #greenpeace #greenpeaceuk

caption: Photo by Amnon Gutman @gutmanen for #everydayclimatechange. A local national park ranger patrolling the peak of Nyiragongo volcano, an area were clashes between armed groups and FARDC are taking place for control over the park taking place. Virunga national park. North Kivu, DRcongo. The last time the volcano erupted ‚Äî in 2002 ‚Äî it killed 147 people and forced 400,000 people to flee the nearby city of Goma.The eruption effectively split Goma in two, destroying a third of the city. Lava even covered about 80 percent of the airstrips at Goma International Airport, making it almost impossible to evacuate people or get outside aid to survivors.Goma sits right on the shore of Lake Kivu, one of the African Great Lakes. The lake straddles the border between the DRC and Rwanda, and holds massive amounts of methane and dissolved carbon dioxide because of its proximity to volcanic vents, among other reasons.The shores of Laku Kivu are packed with about 2 million people. And with much of the infrastructure destroyed by years of a civil war and little to no upkeep, many experts agree that it would be impossible to evacuate them quickly. #climatechange #globalwarming #climatechangedrcongo
tags: climatechange, globalwarming, everydayclimatechange, climatechangedrcongo

caption: Damned: The Growing Thirst for Water March 18 to April 8 In March 2010, photographer Gigie Cruz @cruzgigie worked on a personal project documenting the fish kill at the Magat Dam in Isabela province. Upon arriving at Magat, she found that the dam‚Äôs depleted water levels had reached alarming proportions that were exacerbated by the El Ni√±o phenomenon that same year. Farming families in Isabela and other parts of Northern Luzon that were dependent on the dam for irrigation were devastated by widespread drought, leaving them with dead crops, empty coffers, and huge debts. For them, even the simple act of putting food on the table became an almost insurmountable challenge. An opportunity to participate in monitoring the decreasing water level in Angat Dam in Bulacan in April 2010 also arose, providing the photographer another glimpse into the impacts of climate change not only on Metro Manila‚Äôs primary source of water, but also on provinces dependent on Angat‚Äôs irrigation system. With an exploding population growing thirstier every day and water sources dwindling, how will we be able to survive? Are we damned? Or can we break out of this cycle of destruction? Ms. Cruz‚Äôs first solo exhibit aims to show viewers the impact of climate change on our country‚Äôs fresh water resources. Her experience in documenting this phenomenon motivated her to continue pursuing this story in the hope of helping people realize the value of water amid the uncertainty triggered by climate change. Her work is her contribution towards encouraging dialogue and action for adaptation measures towards water and food security in the light of this devastating crisis. Curated by: Mr. Sonny Yabao @sonny.yabao Kanto Founder: Mr. Toshihiko Uriu #KantoArtistRunSpace #ArtPH #climatechange #photoexhibition #everydayclimatechange #photojournalismPH #environment #water
tags: water, climatechange, kantoartistrunspace, artph, photojournalismph, environment, everydayclimatechange, photoexhibition

caption: Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: By no comparable measure, women across the worlds developing, harsh, and remote areas carry the heaviest burdens. They are the carers, the workers, the cooks, and the managers. In a world where the climate is warming dramatically, women in these areas are on the front lines. On top of their already heavy workloads they are now having to walk further and worker harder due to a range of climate related issues such as drought. Pictured, is a a woman of India's remote Spiti Valley at dusk storing fodder for the livestock to eat over the long and cold Himalayan winter. #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #climatechangeisreal
tags: everydayclimatechange, climatechange, climatechangeisreal, globalwarming

caption: Wings sprawled open, a dead pelican lays on the receded salt-crusted bed of the Great Salt Lake next to the Spiral Jetty. American white pelicans fly miles from their nesting site on Gunnison Island across the strawberry waters of the salty lake, over the Jetty, to forge for food and fresh water in the Bear River Refuge and Farmington Bay. But with water levels dropping in the freshwater bays due to diversions and changing climate, researchers believe that the birds may have to fly farther, causing dehydration and starvation in the pelicans, especially in fledglings during their first flight of the season. @everydayclimatechange #climatechange #research #birds #everydayclimatechange

caption: The Great Salt Lake is drying up and shrinking. Both nature and man have a hand in the change. The Great Salt Lake is largest water body in the United States after the Great Lakes. It is a terminal basin, which means the water that pours into the lake from rivers and streams has no outlet other than evaporation. This allows salts and minerals to concentrate in the lake such that it is three to five times saltier than the ocean. And yet this briny lake is a haven for more than 250 species of migratory birds who feast on the brine shrimp and flies that thrive there. But now the lake is facing a problem. For more than 150 years, humans have been taking more water out of the Salt Lake watershed than is flowing into it. They are now diverting about 40 percent of the river water (which would normally fill the lake) and using it for farming, industry, and human consumption. In October 2016, the Great Salt Lake reached its lowest recorded level: 1277.5 meters (4,191.2 feet), averaged between the lake's north and south arms. As of March 11 2017, the lake levels were at 4193.9 feet, due to snowfall received over the winter months. But the region has seen dry cycles before, and according to scientists, there has not been a significant long-term change in precipitation in the basin. Nonetheless, the volume of water in Great Salt Lake has shrunk by 48 percent and the lake level has fallen 3.4 meters (11 feet) since 1847. @everydayclimatechange #climatechange #research #onassignment #fieldnotes #everydayclimatechange

caption: @everydayclimatechange outdoor exhibition, now on till 30 Apr. . @everydayclimatechange shares images by photographers from all over the world regarding climate change. As these photographers are diverse and have different cultures, the assortment of images gathered reflects these varying perspectives. The photographs chosen illustrate the causes and effects of everyday climate change, and possible solutions that different communities are undertaking. . Part of #storiesthatmatter. Stories That Matter, is an @objectifscentre programme that looks at critical issues in our world through photography and film. Thanks to the @everydayclimatechange contributors who are sharing these important stories with us, to @jameswhitlowdelano for pulling everything together, and to the support from @tomwhitephoto and @yalenuscollege. More info in our profile link üëÜüèº . #climatechange #climatechangeisreal #everydayclimatechange #objectifsgallery (images seen here by @jameswhitlowdelano @lens_pacific @johnnovis)

caption: #climatechangeisreal ‚Äú Italy's coastline is fast disappearing. Photos by Paolo Patrizi @paolopatrizi for @everydayclimatechange From the Veneto region in the north, to Puglia in the south, Italy is losing around 75,000 sq m ‚Äì the equivalent of 10 football pitches ‚Äì every year. Between 1950 and 1999, Italy lost a total of 54 sq km of coastline, according to Italy‚Äôs National Institute for the Environment. While between 1999 and 2007 the coastline shrunk by 600,000 sq m ‚Äì around 75,000 sq m a year. Loss of valuable land due to sea level rise, will affect economic activities on the coasts, infrastructures and urban settlements, as well as recreational areas, protected natural areas and natural heritage sites. If at the end of the 1980s 15% of the territory was beneath the sea level, in 2020 the lowlands could amount to the 48% of the coastal zone." #everydayclimatechange #coastalerosion #risingsealevel #globalwarming #climatechangeisreal

caption: Exploring Utah's open spaces, I quickly realized how important federal, state and private lands are for wildlife species outside the boundaries of protected areas and refuges. Animals don't understand man's demarcated boundaries. As environment and landscape get altered , species move too, from low elevation to high elevation, towards more cover, towards cooler water. Then how can boundaries of national parks and protected areas remain rigid geographical units? Conservation needs to be reimagined in light of climate change and administration polices. In times to come, unobstructed wildlife corridors around these protected areas, be it private land, state land or federal land, will play a pivotal role in the fate of this planet's several species. PIC : A herd of deer spotted in pastures of private land located next to the Spiral Jetty. @everydayclimatechange #climatechange #research #onassignment #fieldnotes #everydayclimatechange

caption: Here's an informative post from an account worth following @climateedge a social enterprise using technology to improve climate resilience in smallholder farms............. - The fungi that cause Coffee Leaf Rust or Ojo de Gallo are only some of the threats that are becoming more difficult to manage because of #climatechange. They infect the leaves and cause them to eventually fall of. This has been devastating for millions of #coffeefarmers, although with the right information and tools these threats can be managed. However, many farmers don't have access to this information. Climate Edge is trying to change this. . . . .

caption: Aerial of illegal cattle, a sign of human encroachment, in Mwiba Game Reserve and the adjacent Wildlife Management Area in central Tanzania. East Africa is currently undergoing an intense drought period brought on by failed rains which has sparked a severe chain reaction effect on the environment. Longer and more intense drought periods are occurring due to climate change, now we put that together with massive increased pressure on resources by burgeoning human and livestock populations and we are seeing now not just sporadic but constant human-wildlife conflict and a complete block of the environments ability to recover from over-grazing by cattle in areas that should be protected for wildlife. Very little support if any is given by the Tanzanian Government to privately-funded anti-poaching teams trying to save what remains of the country's precious wildlife areas. As the livestock invade they eat and trample what remaining vegetation is available pushing wildlife further into smaller and smaller areas. It is in this cycle of climate change affecting and being affected by an ever-increasingly human population and it's unsustainable demand on land and resources, a cycle which continues unabated, that we are seeing the demise of Africa's wildlife and wild spaces. „Éª„Éª„Éª #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp. Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. . . #climatechange #globalwarming #ourplanetdaily #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #tanzania #aerial @gettyimagescreative #gettyimagescreative #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #openmyworld #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #reframeclimate #ic_landscapes #mycanon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkIII #picoftheday

caption: Robert Smithson‚Äôs Spiral Jetty, located at Rozel Point on the northeastern shore of Great Salt Lake in Utah, is one of the most remarkable examples of land art in the world. He created his art at a time when water levels were particularly low in 1970, the ebb and flow of the lake circulating in between the spiral coil. The jetty was submerged in 1972 due to increased precipitation. Droughts caused the lake to recede in 2002, and the sculpture has remained visible ever since. In November 2016, NASA published satellite photographs of the Great Salt Lake from 2011 and 2016, revealing a significant shrinkage of its boundaries. Smithson's sculpture has receded from the shoreline dramatically and soon, it could be marooned in salt. When Smithson began the work, he was cognisant of the spiral‚Äôs temporal state. He was not building a permanent monument, but rather, a fluctuating, changing artwork that was entropic by design. Smithson embraced climate as entropy in his work and it serves as a philosophical underlining in Spiral Jetty, where the coil functions as a microcosm of the universe where disorder is increasing, and the salt deposit and erosion of the Spiral Jetty can be understood as the effect of climate change and a material witness to time. @everydayclimatechange #climatechange #research #birds #everydayclimatechange

caption: #Repost @savechildrenuk Hamda leaning on the shoulder of her mum, Asha, outside their hut at the outskirts of Dila Town. They moved from Odwayne after the drought hit the region and killed all their livestock. Somalia is now on the brink of famine. Severe food and water shortages have killed livestock and driven families like this one from their homes. Our teams are working across East Africa to tackle the worst effects of the drought ‚Äì treating children who are malnourished, transporting water, running mobile health clinics, providing child protection and more support where we can. But the lives of millions are at stake. Visit the link in our bio to help us reach children in East Africa before it‚Äôs too late. #Dila #Somaliland #Somalia #Odwayne #Oodweyne #Drought #Droughts #EverydayClimateChange #EverydayHornOfAfrica #My252 #HornOfAfrica

caption: Setting up @objectifscentre: EverydayClimateChange Outdoor Exhibition, 16 Mar to 30 Apr. . @everydayclimatechange shares images by photographers from all over the world regarding climate change. As these photographers are diverse and have different cultures, the assortment of images gathered reflects these varying perspectives. The photographs chosen illustrate the causes and effects of everyday climate change, and possible solutions that different communities are undertaking. . Part of #storiesthatmatter. Stories That Matter, is an @objectifscentre programme that looks at critical issues in our world through photography and film. Thanks to the @everydayclimatechange contributors who are sharing these important stories with us, to @jameswhitlowdelano for pulling everything together, and to the support from @tomwhitephoto and @yalenuscollege. More info in our profile link üëÜüèº . #climatechange #climatechangeisreal #everydayclimatechange

caption: The downside of development in KL is the amount of waste that is produced. According to the Global Environmental Centre's (GCE) website, it states "Currently, over 23,000 tonnes of waste is produced each day in Malaysia. However, this amount is expected to rise to 30,000 tonnes by the year 2020. The amount of waste generated continues to increase due to the increasing population and development, and only less than 5% of the waste is being recycled" These problem also affects the rivers in KL. According‚Äã to GCE "Rivers represent the lease of life which pulses through the earth.It is a finite and only source of water. In Malaysia, there are almost 1800 rivers. Sadly, more than half of these rivers have been polluted and destroyed. Improper solid waste management contributes greatly to river pollution." The least we can do is make sure we dispose waste in an orderly manner which would help in small doses but will go a long way. #Malaysia #KL #thisiskualalumpur #foreignworkers #huaweip9plus #leica #photostories #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange
tags: leica, everydayclimatechange, photojournalism, thisiskualalumpur, foreignworkers, photostories, huaweip9plus, malaysia, kl

caption: Kuala Lumpur is constantly changing. The changes are rapid and many well known smaller villages are brought to the ground in the name of development. These structures gets built really fast and the original residents are usually given a new low cost flat nearby. What is left of these villages are make shift house built by foreign workers for the duration of the development. Once completed, it is just another high end residences but no one knows the former residents of the area. #thisiskualalumpur #ampang #kampung #foreignworkers #huaweip9plus #leica #photostories #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange

caption: There is a glacier in Iceland, S√≥lheimaj√∂kull, which has retreated an average of one Olympic pool-length (50 m) every year for the past two decades due to climate change. It has thinned almost 150 m since 1960. That's a rate of -3 m per year in thickness. Every time I look at older pictures and see what's not there any more, it does something to the heart. A gigantic natural element that just disappears, without coming back. Iceland, lying just below the Arctic Circle, is one of the fastest-warming places on the planet ‚Äì as much a four times the Northern Hemisphere average. The 300-some glaciers that cover more than 10 percent of the island are losing an average of 11 billion tons of ice a year. The annual volume carried away from Iceland's glaciers and not replaced by new snow would fill 50 of the world's largest trucks. every. minute. for the entire year. Awareness is the first step. ---- #everydayclimatechange #visitsiceland #glacier #hiking #earthfocus #landscape #outdoors #lifestyle #photooftheday #yourshotphotographer #exploretocreate #wondermore #neverstopexploring #climatechange
tags: yourshotphotographer, lifestyle, everydayclimatechange, landscape, hiking, earthfocus, exploretocreate, photooftheday, climatechange, outdoors, wondermore, neverstopexploring, glacier, visitsiceland

caption: Unearthing the first signs of death on Gunnison Island. Gunnison Island in the Great Salt Lake is a harsh remote place to nest for the American White Pelicans. But the migratory birds choose to breed here in one of the largest colonies of North America because of those same reasons, because of how untouched and inaccessible it is to human or animal invasion. The nesting survival rate for the pelicans on the island is low (close to 0.25) as the birds have to fly far to forage for food and freshwater bays. The eggs either get destroyed in harsh weather conditions and if they do hatch, then the fledglings have to learn to fly miles to learn how to feed themselves. Now, with the lake levels going down due to water diversions and climate change, a land bridge has formed to Gunnison, giving access to predators such as coyotes who can destroy colonies at a time. Furthermore, freshwater bays like Bear River Bay are drying up, due to which the birds may have to fly farther in many trips to feed their juveniles, causing starvation and dehydration for the chicks who are waiting to be fed. A baby pelican needs to be fed almost 150 pounds of fish before it turns into a fledgling and learns to fend for itself. @everydayclimatechange #climatechange #research #birds #everydayclimatechange
tags: instagood, research, earth, everydayindia, gunnisonisland, climatechange, ngtdailyshot, yourshot, birds, ig_worldtravelshot, pelicans, reportagespotlight, natgeo, everydayclimatechange, dailylife, vscocam, gaia, greatsaltlake, remoteisland, natgeotravelpic, environment, vscofeature, usa, instaearth, slowjournalism, love, utah

caption: Gunnison Island in the Great Salt Lake is a harsh remote place to nest, even for the American White Pelicans. But the migratory birds choose to breed here in one of the largest colonies of North America because of those same reasons, because of how untouched and inaccessible it is to human or animal invasion. The nesting survival rate for the pelicans on the island is low (close to 0.25) as the birds have to fly far to forage for food and freshwater in bays. The eggs either get destroyed in harsh weather conditions and if they do hatch, then the fledglings have to learn to fly miles to learn how to feed themselves. Now, with the lake levels going down due to water diversions and climate change, a land bridge has formed to Gunnison, giving access to predators such as coyotes who can destroy colonies at a time. Furthermore, freshwater bays like Bear River Bay are drying up, due to which the birds may have to fly farther, causing starvation and dehydration for the chicks who are waiting to be fed. Seen here, a mummified pelican found at the water's edge on Pelican Bay at Gunnison Island. @everydayclimatechange #climatechange #research #birds #everydayclimatechange

caption: Separated from Hialeah by the Miami Canal, Miami Springs too faces the impacts of sea level rise. Begun as a planned community in the 1920s and close to the airport for many years many of its inhabitants worked in the airlines business. caption: Let's save the bees, honey! . Honey bees are the most efficient pollinators and very important in the food chain. They ensure the fertilization of the flowering plant species whose pollen they feed on. The number of bees in the world is on decline due in part to the ill effects of voracious mites, fungal gut parasites and a wide variety of debilitating viruses. The reasons are monoculture farming, pesticides and other chemicals, air and water pollution and climate change. . #spring #bees #bee #flowers #apricottre #pollination #pollution #climatechange #honeybee #springisintheair #flyaway #capturedmoment #colorshots #parasites #pesticides #honey #profumodiprimavera #primavera #api #everydayclimatechange #animals #animali #natgeo #inquinamento #albicocco #capturethemoment #friendsinperson #yourshotphotographer #streetphotographer #streetphotos

caption: Monrovia, photograph by @paolopatrizi for @everydayclimatechange. Thousands of people and businesses are literally being swept away because of rising seas along the Liberian coast. Liberia is home to 4 million people, many living along coastal areas of the country. Rising sea levels have been of increasing concern for the country‚Äôs Environmental Protection Agency over the past few years, not only because of the severe erosion seen in many areas, but because of the need to move families and businesses inland to safety. Liberia‚Äôs 350 miles of coastline encompasses coastal lagoons and mangroves as well as beach fronts. Climate change has already started to impact the country, with heavy rains, flooding, storm surges and erosion along the coast. Along with these concerns can be added the fact that nearly 80 percent of the population live in poverty. #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #coastalerosion #risingsealevel #globalwarming #climatechangeisreal
tags: coastalerosion, climatechange, everydayclimatechange, risingsealevel, climatechangeisreal, globalwarming

caption: After declining off from a peak in the 1990s and early 2000s, Amazon deforestation increased last year for the first time in the past decade. https://goo.gl/EEdDdW The protection of these lands and ecosystems is vitally important in efforts to stem global warming and climate change. While the new American presidential administration is choosing to ignore, lie and cast doubt about man‚Äôs impact on the climate, that doesn‚Äôt mean we too can ignore it. We all have to make efforts locally - and globally - to ensure that future generations have a healthy Earth to call home. I (@danielbeltraphoto) just returned from a month long assignment to document this increase in deforestation. In this photo, an aerial view of the Amazon rainforest 60 miles southwest of Macap√°, Brazil, in February, 2017. Nearly 90% of Brazil‚Äôs Amap√° state is unexplored, protected rainforest. It includes Tumucumaque Mountains national park, the largest tropical forest park in the world. See more of my images of the Amazon at The Guardian. https://goo.gl/HK85RQ #amazondeforestation #amazonrainforest #amazon #climatechange #globalwarming #environment #environmentalism #conservation #brazil #rainforest #trees #everydayclimatechange
tags: conservation, climatechange, everydayclimatechange, rainforest, brazil, amazonrainforest, environmentalism, globalwarming, amazondeforestation, amazon, trees, environment

caption: Frustration with sustainable water use policies has put much of CA farming country in the Trump camp, but I wonder how that would change if we had a sensible #immigration policy Further scattered thoughts and questions: Climate change is invisible here, driving a wedge further between cities and rural communities, hitting the livelihoods of farm owners and workers. Farmers blame their representatives for policies designed to avoid catastrophic water shortages. How do we bridge the gap between city-dwelling politicians and their constituents who actually know farming, but who seemingly want to ignore that long-term resource planning is necessary? And what if immigrant communities that call California their home but don't have documents proving that such is the case, what if they had the vote? What if we didn't employ our immigration control as a force of intimidation and fear? Our immigration policy attempts to erase the voices of migrants from our national conversation. #rightsforall #notruescotsman #todossomosamericanos Cycling the world, telling the human story of climate change. #climate #climatechange #fossilfuels #renewables #renewableenergy #renewablefuture #cycling #bicycling #biking #worldbybike #cycletouring #bicycletouring #activetransport #hesterthebike #travel #travelphotography #landscape #nikon #California #ca #water #everydayclimatechange
tags: notruescotsman, landscape, biking, nikon, climatechange, travelphotography, everydayclimatechange, travel, hesterthebike, fossilfuels, climate, bicycletouring, bicycling, renewables, cycletouring, worldbybike, cycling, california, rightsforall, renewablefuture, activetransport, immigration, renewableenergy, ca, todossomosamericanos, water

caption: @Regrann from @jbrussell - Photo @jbrussell for #everydayclimatechange A local inhabitant felling #trees for the production of charcoal in the #Kalounayes managed #forest reserve in the #Casamance region of southern #Senegal. Charcoal is the primary energy used for cooking and heating in much of #WestAfrica and many local communities depend on charcoal production for their economic livelihoods. However, unchecked #deforestation is a major contributor to #globalwarming, #climatechange, soil erosion and a litany of other #environmental woes. In the Kalounayes reserve, the exploitation of the forest's #naturalresources are managed in a sustainable way. Charcoal production is restricted to certain tree species on designated lots for a limited amount of time. The lots are regularly rotated and replanted, allowing local communities to preserve the forest and earn a living. #climatechangeisreal #Africa - #regrann
tags: environmental, casamance, climatechange, globalwarming, trees, everydayclimatechange, kalounayes, senegal, naturalresources, regrann, forest, deforestation, africa, climatechangeisreal, westafrica

caption: By no comparable measure, women across the worlds developing, harsh, and remote areas carry the heaviest burdens. They are the carers, the workers, the cooks, and the managers. In a world where the climate is warming dramatically, women in these areas are on the front lines. On top of their already heavy workloads they are now having to walk further and worker harder due to a range of climate related issues such as drought. Pictured, is a a woman of India's remote Spiti Valley at dusk storing fodder for the livestock to eat over the long and cold Himalayan winter. #internationalwomensday #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming
tags: internationalwomensday, globalwarming, everydayclimatechange, climatechange

caption: @Regrann from @jbrussell - Photo by @jbrussell for #everydayclimatechange A woman walks home across the #mangroves at low tide after collecting shellfish in the tidal channels. According to a recent report by the United Nations Environmental Programme (UNEP), the world's mangroves are being destroyed at a rate three to five times faster than global deforestation. The report calls mangrove forests "one of the most threatened ecosystems on the planet." The #UNEP Executive Director Achim Steiner says "This has potentially devastating effects on biodiversity, food security and the livelihoods of some of the most marginalized coastal communities in developing countries, where more than 90% of the world's mangroves are found." The Atlantic coast of West Africa contains some of the world's most important mangrove #forests. The #biodiversity that they nurture help regulate #climate, act as important carbon sinks to reduce #greenhousegas emissions, their complex network of roots reduce wave energy, limit erosion and form a protective barrier against the devastation wrought by ever more frequent and powerful tropical storms, cyclones and tsunamis. Mangroves improve food security, act as nurseries for marine and commercial fish stocks and help reduce poverty. Nearly one fifth of global emissions from #deforestation are a result of mangrove loss. #Canchungo #GuineaBissau #Africa #climatechangeisreal - #regrann
tags: climate, forests, biodiversity, unep, everydayclimatechange, mangroves, regrann, greenhousegas, deforestation, africa, climatechangeisreal, guineabissau, canchungo

caption: Post ‚ù§Ô∏è on @ecosphere to show some love to AIDER and all their sustainable development and environmental conservation work. Photo taken in Peru.

Photo by @JshPhotog - The 5,000-year old Neolithic settlement of Skara Brae, in Orkney, Scotland, standing beside the coast in Sandwick. The village, which had been inhabited between 3,200 and 2,300 BC, was discovered in 1850 after being exposed by a storm. A 2016 report from Union of Concerned Scientists (UCS), UN heritage body Unesco and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) highlights the risk to heritage sites worldwide from the effects of climate change. Orkney islands in Scotland are renowned for the quantity and quality of Neolithic archaeological sites, gaining the islands the Heart of Neolithic Orkney World Heritage status listing, but many of those sites are situated on the coast and thus at risk from rising sea levels, sea erosion of the coastline and harsher weathers. Deputy director of the climate and energy programme at UCS, and author of the report, Adam Markham, quoted in the Glasgow Herald says "Orkney and the whole of Scotland is the poster child for eroding archaeology sites. There are thousands of them and many of them are being lost to coastal erosion and storms. If sea level rise and storms get worse because of global warming then we are going to be losing huge amounts of British heritage directly into the sea‚Äù, and continues, ‚Äúthe report is representative of the kind of threats these iconic places are experiencing, some are in direct and immediate danger. At every one of these sites we can see the impacts of climate change already. Not in every place is it threatening it yet but it will threaten it in the future." The report can be found here: http://www.ucsusa.org/global-warming/global-warming-impacts/world-heritage-tourism-sites-climate-change-risks#.WL_NybSN2fR And UNESCO World Heritage listing: http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/514 #UNESCO #WorldHeritage #SkaraBrae #Orkney #Scotland #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #risingsealevels #Neolithic #NeolithicOrkney #JeremySuttonHibbert
tags: climatechange, unesco, globalwarming, scotland, everydayclimatechange, skarabrae, jeremysuttonhibbert, neolithicorkney, risingsealevels, worldheritage, orkney, neolithic

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by @JshPhotog - A child makes a heart shape with her hands, at Whitelee Wind farm, on Eaglesham Moor, near #Glasgow, Scotland. In new data released today by #WeatherEnergy, wind power output in Scotland has jumped by over two-fifths compared to the same period last year, and on four separate days in February 2017, wind turbines generated output equivalent to more than Scotland‚Äôs total power needs for each entire day ‚Äì equivalent to 118%, 110%, 127% and 128% of each day‚Äôs demand, respectively. In the same month, wind power generated the equivalent of 67% of Scotland‚Äôs entire electricity needs for the month. @WWF Scotland‚Äôs director Lang Banks said: ‚ÄúThanks to a combination of increased capacity and stronger winds, output from turbines was up more than two-fifths compared to the same period last year. This was enough power to provide the equivalent of the electrical needs of almost four million homes. As well as helping to power our homes and businesses, wind power supports thousands of jobs and helps Scotland to avoid over a million tonnes of polluting carbon emissions every month. ‚ÄúEvery one of the main political parties supports the aim of generating half of all Scotland‚Äôs energy needs from renewables by 2030 - including heat, electricity and transport. With this level of political backing, we call upon all of the parties to now bring forward policies that will help maximise the benefits to Scotland‚Äôs economy, as we transition to a renewable future.‚Äù More information here: http://www.wwf.org.uk/updates/massive-jump-scotlands-wind-power-output-new-data-published #EverydayClimateChange #WindPower #renewables #Greenenergy #energy #climatechange #JeremySuttonHibbert #Scotland
tags: renewables, energy, windpower, greenenergy, jeremysuttonhibbert, glasgow, weatherenergy, scotland, climatechange, everydayclimatechange, repost

caption: Photo by Amnon Gutman @gutmanen for #everydayclimatechange. Members of the Nasa guard climbing Mt Dantas, in order to patrol disputed areas where the Colombian army has been stationed in. Miranda, North Cauca. Colombia is at high risk from climate change impacts. The majority of the population lives in the elevated Andes, where water shortages and land instability are already a reality, and on the coast, where the increase in sea level and floods can affect key human settlements and economic activities. Furthermore, the country has a high incidence of extreme events with growing emergencies associated with climate conditions. Colombia has made strides in the attainment of the MDGs. However, these goals are still fragile and marked by a scenario burdened with social conflicts teeming with regional inequalities and social gaps, including a high percentage of vulnerable populations that may suffer serious setbacks in their human development due precisely to climate change. The climate scenarios presented in Colombia's Second National Communication on Climate Change, predict an increase in the average temperature between 2¬∞ and 4¬∞ C by 2070, along with changed hydrological conditions. #climatechange #globalwarming #climatechangecolombia
tags: everydayclimatechange, globalwarming, climatechangecolombia, climatechange

caption: Photo by @JshPhotog - A child makes a heart shape with her hands, at Whitelee Wind farm, on Eaglesham Moor, near #Glasgow, Scotland. In new data released today by #WeatherEnergy, wind power output in Scotland has jumped by over two-fifths compared to the same period last year, and on four separate days in February 2017, wind turbines generated output equivalent to more than Scotland‚Äôs total power needs for each entire day ‚Äì equivalent to 118%, 110%, 127% and 128% of each day‚Äôs demand, respectively. In the same month, wind power generated the equivalent of 67% of Scotland‚Äôs entire electricity needs for the month. @WWF Scotland‚Äôs director Lang Banks said: ‚ÄúThanks to a combination of increased capacity and stronger winds, output from turbines was up more than two-fifths compared to the same period last year. This was enough power to provide the equivalent of the electrical needs of almost four million homes. As well as helping to power our homes and businesses, wind power supports thousands of jobs and helps Scotland to avoid over a million tonnes of polluting carbon emissions every month. ‚ÄúEvery one of the main political parties supports the aim of generating half of all Scotland‚Äôs energy needs from renewables by 2030 - including heat, electricity and transport. With this level of political backing, we call upon all of the parties to now bring forward policies that will help maximise the benefits to Scotland‚Äôs economy, as we transition to a renewable future.‚Äù More information here: http://www.wwf.org.uk/updates/massive-jump-scotlands-wind-power-output-new-data-published #EverydayClimateChange #WindPower #renewables #Greenenergy #energy #climatechange #JeremySuttonHibbert #Scotland
tags: glasgow, weatherenergy, windpower, scotland, everydayclimatechange, greenenergy, energy, renewables, climatechange, jeremysuttonhibbert

caption: Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: Rainfall patterns across the Indian subcontinent are continuing to change for the worse. Many parts of the country are receiving too little or too much. However, the overall trends point to a much drier landscape in the middle and long-term future due to the increasing effects of climate change. Both rural and urban communities are facing the consequences of these water shortages, especially those peoples found at the bottom of the socio-economic ladder. Pictured are women in a slum settlement on the outskirts of New Delhi washing their bowls and collecting as much water as they can for storage. . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #india #asia #climatechangeisreal
tags: india, climatechange, climatechangeisreal, everydayclimatechange, globalwarming, asia

caption: Two cows affected by drought, Bastrop, Texas, USA, 2011 In September 2011, I had heard a story on the radio about how Texas ranchers were selling their cattle because they could not keep up with rising feed costs due to one of the worst droughts in the state‚Äôs history. When I was in East Texas that October, with temperatures near 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius) and no rain in the forecast, the cows I saw looked thin, hot, and unhappy. #witnesstreeproject #animals #environment #climate #climatechange #drought #everydayclimatechange #globalwarming #cows #texas #risingtemperature

caption: @ravimishraindia #thevisualactivist Salman (10) looks on, as he carries a basket full of scavenged coal in Jharia, Jharkhand. I dream of becoming an engineer and help my family by getting a Job where I can earn more then 100 - 120 RS (approx 2 USD), I get very tired because we start walking (working) at around 4 A.M everyday, and walk (work) till late in the afternoon. The scavengers around this region start their day long before the sun rises in the sky, a big group of scavengers, especially women and young children between the age group of 8 to 15, begin the first of countless treks down a steep and narrow switchback into the open pit mine to scavenge chunks of coal, which they carry back to the surface in baskets balanced atop their heads. This year I will be sharing some of my favourite stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #February2017 #u4humanrights
tags: life, fire, india, u4humanrights, february2017, everydayclimatechange, nature, people, pollution, everydayeverywhere, natgeoearthday, asia, reportagespotlight, thevisualactivist, climatechange, landscape, everydayindia

caption: Mother polar bear and two cubs, Cape Mercy, Davis Straight, Canada, 2013 Hunters, both human and animal, rely on sea ice to help them stalk and catch their prey. caption: @Regrann from @edkashi - Photo by @edkashi/@viiphoto: An employee prepares to work at a yeast factory in the Sao Manoel Usina, where #ethanol is produced in Sao Manoel, Brazil on Sept. 26, 2011. #Brazil is host to the largest sugar and ethanol producers in the world. According to a report on sugarcane.org, the use of low-carbon, renewable energy is an important strategy for mitigating emissions of greenhouse gases and combating #globalwarming. In 2006 the reduction of GHG emissions attributable to the use of #ethanol (as a gasoline substitute) reached 22% of final emissions for the transportation and electricity generation sectors in Brazil, and could reach 43% in 2020. #climatechange #positivechange @everydayclimatechange EverydayClimateChange is pleased to support@DECCgovUK's #BackClimateAction #photography #competition, with #EverydayClimateChange photographer @JshPhotog, in UK, being asked to be on the competition's judging panel. ‚Ä®The @DECCgovUK competition: What does Climate Change mean to you? Show us in a picture and share on Instagram or Twitter from 20 Feb ‚Äì 6 March. Please include hashtag #BackClimateAction. The winner will win a photography workshop & a boat trip to photograph an offshore wind farm! Winner will be announced w/c 16 March. Terms & conditions at bit.ly/BCAPic - #regrann

Pine trees killed by bark beetle infestation, Grand Lake, Colorado, USA, 2011 Over 4 million acres of lodge pole pines have been decimated in the Colorado Rockies by the bark beetle infestation and more than 60 million acres of forest in the US and British Columbia have been affected to varying degrees. caption: LAND SHARKS CLOSE IN ON FLAMIMGO SANCTUARY AT THANE Even as their song is drowned by the growl of the dumper trucks that discard construction debris in their habitat, the bulbuls, prinias and sunbirds continue their crooning. As we celebrate World Wetlands Day, these unique ecosystems that support myriad life forms, contain the impacts from storm damage and flooding, and store carbon are being rapidly and systematically destroyed at various locations in Mumbai, Thane and Navi Mumbai regions. caption: Don't be surprised if you see a red cross such as this on the trees in your neighbourhood. The construction of Mumbai's newest Metro lines means the destruction of 5,000 trees. 100 of them are in my lane at Churchgate alone. It breaks my heart to see the trees that have seen so many generations of humans grow up, be destroyed in the name of 'progress'. A group of citizens have challenged the decision in court and it now all comes down to the tribunal to decide what the true cost of progress is. #everydaymumbai #mumbai #bombay #progress #mumbaimetro #everydayclimatechange #tree Photo @tunalimukherjee
tags: bombay, mumbaimetro, mumbai, everydaymumbai, tree, progress, everydayclimatechange

caption: This amazing picture by @paolosolaribozzi is part of the photo exhibition Artico, ultima frontiera (Arctic, the last frontier) that will run until 2 April 2017 in Casa dei Tre Oci, #Venice, Italy. The Arctic is a vast region of our planet that includes Greenland, Siberia, Canada, Alaska and Iceland, and plays an important role in regulating the climate of the Earth, where ecosystems are threatened by climate change. These pictures investigate this extreme environment and the Inuit‚Äôs culture, threatened by economic, social and environmental change. ITA‚Ä¢ Questa bellissima foto di Paolo Solari Bozzi fa parte della mostra fotografica Artico, ultima frontiera ospitata fino al 2 aprile a Casa dei tre Oci a Venezia. L‚ÄôArtico √® un‚Äôampia regione del pianeta, che comprende Groenlandia, Siberia, Canada, Alaska e Islanda e che svolge una funzione fondamentale per la regolazione del clima a livello mondiale, la cui delicata rete di ecosistemi √® minacciata dai cambiamenti climatici in atto. Le foto indagano la realt√† di questo ambiente estremo e della vita del popolo #Inuit che, a causa dei mutamenti economico-sociali ed ambientali, vede minacciata la sopravvivenza della propria cultura. . . . #nature #wild #wilderness #white #arctic #climatechange #everydayclimatechange
tags: venice, wilderness, white, nature, climatechange, wild, inuit, everydayclimatechange, arctic

caption: Isn't this the most beautiful thing you've seen all day? This was from our adventure in Peru. Type "YES" if you agree.

Flamingos at the mudflats of sewri against the hazy Mumbai skyline. These migratory birds visit the city in the winter months and are mostly concentrated at this very spot where the Mumbai Trans-Harbour Link is scheduled to begin. Suggestions to move the link a few hundred meters have been shot down. So ecologists say its a wait-and-watch scenario to see how the birds will react once work begins in the second half of this year. While the birds themselves have high resistance to noise levels, the remnants of construction related cement on the mudflats will make it unfavorable feeding ground (the birds feed on salt water algae). Whether they will return after construction work ends is anybody's guess. The govt has declared a wetland sanctuary nearby so there is a sliver of hope. #EverydayMumbai #mumbai #sewri #flamingos #mudflats #everydayclimatechange Photo @soniafilinto
tags: flamingos, mumbai, mudflats, everydaymumbai, sewri, everydayclimatechange

caption: Photo by Matilde Gattoni @matildegattoni for @everydayclimatechange A little girl stands on the beach covered with seaweed left after the massive high tide that stroke the village of Fuvemeh the day before. Nestled between the ocean and the Volta river estuary, the village of Fuvemeh has seen its territory reduced from several kilometers to few hundred meters. Nowadays, the village sits on a narrow strip of land which separates the coastline from the adjacent lagoon. Haunted by coastal erosion, its 1,000 inhabitants have literally nowhere to move. #ghana #africa #fuvemeh #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #coastalerosion #risingsealevel #globalwarming

caption: Would you get lost in a jungle for a day with @ecosphere? Type "YES" if you'd love to come out on an adventure with us out into the Peruvian wilds!

That's how 'the lungs of Kolkata' is congested... Passing through this part of the city had always offered a sense of pleasure and comfort. So after attending an enlightening session on Adi-Ganga or 'Tolly's Nulla' that took place very close to Maidan, did not think twice to take a stroll through the greenery. It was quite disheartening to find Kolkata Maidan in this state, it looked more like a waste dumping ground. Coincidentally the symposium on Adi-Ganga also talked about improper waste management, lack of public awareness, need for conservation and planned decision making towards better resilience. #ailinglungsofKolkata #KolkataMaidan #wastedisposal #improperwastemanagement #IndianShutterBugs #ISBtraveler #EverydayIndia #creativeimagemagazine #everydayclimatechange #natureinfocus #kolkata #disheartening #needaction #lackingawareness

caption: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. As the sun sets high up at the base of Kilimanjaro's tallest Kibo peak, the second peak Mawenzi casts a sunset shadow across the horizon with the moon in the sky. There is not a trace of snow. What was once a solid ice climb is now a scree and rock climb with the ice that forms over the very cold nights quickly disappearing as the sun rises. Kilimanjaros remaining slivers of white glaciers are at least 11,700 years old, and over a million people in local villages depend upon them. They are, however, now under threat from climate change on Mount Kilimanjaro. In 2009, the most recent study of the mountain warned that climate change could cause Kilimanjaro‚Äôs snows to disappear within 20 years. In the course of the seven years of the study, data as old as almost a century was employed, six tons of equipment was carted to the mountain‚Äôs plateau and deep drilling took place. It was found that ice between six and 17 feet thick had vanished since 2000. Almost a quarter of the ice was lost from 2000 to 2006: no factor other than climate change on Mount Kilimanjaro can account for this sudden change. The snows of Kilimanjaro survived a 300-year drought about 4,200 years back, but human behaviour clearly threatens them now. #climatechange #globalwarming @everydayclimatechange #ourplanetdaily #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #kilimanjaro #tanzania #mindthemountains #sunsetsniper @gettyimagescreative #gettyimagescreative #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #openmyworld #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #reframeclimate #ic_landscapes #canon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkIII #picoftheday
tags: followmetoo, ic_landscapes, canon, kilimanjaro, sunsetsniper, tanzania, ourplanetdaily, climate, toldwithexposure, openmyworld, documentary, mindthemountains, photojournalism, reframeclimate, canonphotos, globalwarming, picoftheday, climatechangeisreal, climatechange, gettyimagescreative, visualsoflife, canon5dmarkiii, everydayclimatechange
