caption: They clear cut this hill a few years ago - took 300 feet off the top of a historical Indian mound. Now it‚Äôs one of the biggest frack pads in Ohio. The drill rig is up, but they were getting ready to inject sand, toxic chemicals and millions of gallons of fresh water. Some of the laterals running off this pad are 18,000 feet into our earth, making a diagonal decline that ends under a nearby lake. Nothing is regulated in this rural land - oil and gas have leased and unitized nearly everyone. In the hope of jobs and economic growth people welcomed the industry - only to be covered in pipelines, steady unemployment and health concerns. The air, water and land continue to be polluted as the multi billion dollar companies take advantage of their federal exemptions. #climatechange #nofracking #nodapl #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #ohio #nopipelines
tags: nofracking, climatechange, everydayclimatechange, globalwarming, environmentaljustice, ohio, climatechangeisreal, nopipelines, nodapl, frackoff, environment

caption: Today struck me hard. The approval of the Dakota Access pipeline, although we knew it was coming, was the trigger among all these other miserable government developments. I am mid-process of writing about fracking in Ohio, an industry that serves as a local example of what is happening with oil and gas development all over the United States. Thousands of pipelines cross the land, lateral wells run under homes, frack waste is buried in unassuming fields and landowners are all but silenced. Local governments have no power to regulate, methane clouds hover invisibly in the night sky, and people in proximity to activity are developing respiratory illnesses and cancer. Conservancy districts are selling clean lake water to frack, injection wells hold millions of gallons of radioactive toxic waste, and compressor stations howl twenty-four-seven. I talked to enough people to know that no one is happy - there are no local jobs, no millionaires and nothing to be gained in a two year boom-bust cycle. This can not be our energy solution. #everydayclimatechange #cleanair #environment #climateaction #nodapl #nofracking
tags: cleanair, nofracking, climatechange, everydayclimatechange, globalwarming, nopipelines, nodapl, environment, climateaction

caption: Regram from @climatetracker - "We have been living here for the last 40 years. Every time it rains, we have to evacuate. Children miss out on the school and we can't find work, losing out on our daily income". This photo-series is from the Slums of Mattakkuliya (Colombo), following the floods that struck Srilanka in 2016. Beginning on 14 May 2016, a low pressure area over the Bay of Bengal caused torrential rain to fall across Sri Lanka, causing floods and landslides which affected half a million people. Slums of Mattakuliya houses communities right on the edge of the Kelani river. Consisting of jam packed, unplanned improvised and semi-permanent housing constructions, living right on the edge of the river. Most of the people living here are poor, and work on daily basis. Following the heavy rains and floods of May, homeowners had to evacuate when water entered their houses. Leaving these poor people with flooded basements, costly roof repairs and damaged electrical appliances. caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. 8 year old Janet and 10 year old Asunta dig a hole in the sand to collect water from the drying Uaso Nyiro river, which is in some areas the only source of water. ‚ÄòExtreme‚Äô and ‚Äòarid‚Äô are not new to north Kenya‚Äôs Samburu region. However what we are seeing is drought becoming persistent and rains failing more frequently. Women tend to be the ones that suffer from environmental catastrophe. Against ever-increasing odds women must find a way to tend the cattle and find food and water for their family. A study on the impact of climate change and gender roles in community adaptation highlights the interesting fact that the impacts of climate change are unequally felt along the gender lines in certain cultures. Due to way the Samburu community have very strong divided gender roles within their culture with women being the basic needs suppliers, women are more vulnerable to climate change. However, the study also shows that women are able to adapt more easily than men using better strategies that help them to cope more successfully. caption: Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: Building new homes in an uncertain future. The village of Kumik in the Zanskar Himalayan range in India‚Äôs north-west has watched their glacier disappear over recent decades from warming temperatures. The ice once upon a time ran right down to the village. These days, as pictured in the background, it has fully retreated and melt water from the ice no longer flows to Kumik. This massive loss of regular water has contributed or arguably is the cause of so many of the village‚Äôs problems. From lowering yields, crop failures, lack of fodder for livestock and increasing political divisions within the village. Water binds all these together. As the globe warms water issues, here and elsewhere in the world, will be one of the most paramount issues that humanity faces and must address and adapt to. A drier planet will most certainly shift the way we have developed our species over thousands of years. #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #asia #india #climatechangeisreal
tags: globalwarming, climatechangeisreal, everydayclimatechange, asia, climatechange, india

caption: @thevisualactivist for #everydayindia Watching Karu, a small child sitting alone on top of a pile of rocks surrounded by coal, soiled by black dust, turning his back to the rest of the world makes me reflect on the state of existence of children in the coalfields of Jharia. The kid seems to have become more familiar with coal than anything else around. This makes me recall the days when I was a child and how cluelessly, at the age of 13, I embarked on an unknown journey of life, with no one else around me, it reminded me of the time when I had to take tough decisions in situations that offered hardly any choices and how I had to work for 20-21 hours to ensure survival. The plight of kids here in Jharia is disheartening. Almost every child lives a life that many of us can't even think of. The word 'childhood‚Äô holds no meaning in their lives. Working conditions in the coalfields are such that a mere slip of foot would result in death from coal fire. Children who have hardly completed a decade of their lives, have dry scaly skin, already. The limbs that are supposed to be nurtured with oil and sports are found smeared in coal and black dust. The air that they respire does no good, either. Their faces are smudged with ashes and soot. Their growth stunted. It is difficult to digest the fact that children as young as 5 get up at 4 in the morning and walk for hours- only to earn a living! It feels terrible to watch such small kids scavenging coal, picking up numerous baskets, making countless treks up and down the hills, getting stained with black coal in a dangerously polluted and unsafe region, leaving behind their childhood- only to find means of survival. But, there's a gleam of hope that comes out of their sparkling eyes as they speak. The smile that shoves off every dust particle on their face overpowers all odds.‚Ä® #everydayindia #PVCHR #u4humanrights #India #Asia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #tybitto #reportagespotlight #Jharia
tags: u4humanrights, everydayindia, everydayeverywhere, pvchr, jharia, asia, india, tybitto, reportagespotlight, everydayclimatechange

caption: "We have been living here for the last 40 years. Every time it rains, we have to evacuate. Children miss out on the school and we can't find work, losing out on our daily income". This photo-series is from the Slums of Mattakkuliya (Colombo), following the floods that struck Srilanka in 2016. Beginning on 14 May 2016, a low pressure area over the Bay of Bengal caused torrential rain to fall across Sri Lanka, causing floods and landslides which affected half a million people. Mattakuliya Slums houses communities right on the edge of the Kelani river. Consisting of jam packed, unplanned improvised and semi-permanent housing constructions, living right on the edge of the river. Most of the people living here are poor, and work on daily basis. Following the heavy rains and floods of May, homeowners had to evacuate when water entering their houses. Leaving these poor people with flooded basements, costly roof repairs and damaged electrical appliances. Photo by @munazzaanwaar #Srilanka #Floods #flooding #ClimateChange #globalwarming #environment #climate #climatefacts #photojournalism #everydayeverywhere #everydayclimatechange #ClimateAction #ClimateTracker

caption: #Repost @leonardodicaprio with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª #Regram #RG @everydayclimatechange: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. Empusel, the name the Maasai call the salty, dusty plains and from which the word ‚ÄòAmboseli‚Äô is derived, is about to relish in the first of the rains. The Amboseli basin, a semi-arid, open savannah area of southern Kenya, has experienced extensive changes in habitat since the early 1960's with daily temperatures increasing dramatically at a greater rate than that attributed to global warming. Amboseli has experienced an extensive loss of the trees due to a rising water table and the related rise of the salt layer in the soil, to grazing patterns, to a natural ageing of the woodlands, and to damage from an increasingly resident elephant population now unable to move the distances they used to due to growing human population around the reserve. The temperature changes here are now causing the landscape changes, and to confuse matters the temperature pattern may itself have been caused by the landscape changes. The climate change discussion is as dynamic and as important as ever. #climatechange #globalwarming #ic_landscapes #travel #natgeohub @natgeotravel #desertification #dust #everydayclimatechange #drought #deforestation #trees #colorcrush #horizon #canon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkiii

caption: Regram from @climatetracker - A girl sits on bike on top of the debris of a damaged home during the 2016 floods, in Mattakkuliya, Colombo, Srilanka. I am taking over @climatetracker for this week to share climate change stories. Today‚Äôs photo is from the Slums of Mattakkuliya (Colombo), following the floods that struck Srilanka in 2016. Beginning on 14 May 2016, a low pressure area over the Bay of Bengal caused torrential rain to fall across Sri Lanka, causing floods and landslides which affected half a million people. Slums of Mattakuliya houses communities right on the edge of the Kelani river. Consisting of jam packed, unplanned improvised and semi-permanent housing constructions, living right on the edge of the river. Most of the people living here are poor, and work on daily basis. Following the heavy rains and floods of May, homeowners had to evacuate when water entered their houses. Leaving these poor people with flooded basements, costly roof repairs and damaged electrical appliances. Not to mention it was already hard finding work with children to takecare of and search for temporary places to stay. #srilanka #floods #flooding #climatechange #globalwarming #environment #climate #climatefacts #photojournalism #everydayeverywhere #everydayclimatechange #climateaction #climatetracker @everydayclimatechange #etribune #dawndotcom #yourshot #instadaily #instagram #life

caption: Interesting read...on the dangers of air pollution and the resistance of coal #makeearthgreenagain #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Katharina Hesse /@hessekatharina A hazy view of Hebei province near Shijiazhuang in the morning. Two of the most toxic components of smog saw their readings exceed 1,000 on the air quality index in Shijiazhuang in China‚Äôs northern Hebei province late last year, state media reported. One resident said her lungs felt ‚Äúextremely uncomfortable‚Äù after she went walking outside for just a few minutes. The amount of PM2.5 and PM10 recorded in Shijiazhuang was greater than 1,000 micrograms per cubic metre at around 1pm, according to Xinhua. Both are types of suspended respirable particles that pose a risk to human health. The World Health Organisation recommends exposure to PM2.5 be limited to 25 micrograms per cubic metre over 24 hours, and 50 micrograms per cubic metre for PM10. Air pollution usually worsens in northern China during the winter, as coal is used to heat homes. Beijing issued a red alert for smog in December 2016, its first of the year, and 10 cities in Hebei have followed suit. Under China‚Äôs four-tiered warning system, a red alert will force suspension of factory production and school classes, as well as traffic reduction measures. In China alone, more than 1.6 million people die annually from air pollution. Heavy coal use has resulted in high carbon emissions. Although China has reduced greenhouse gas emissions by 250,000 tons, the nation continues to emit 25 million tons of greenhouse gases, according to Environment Minister Chen Jining. Enforcement of environmental laws has improved, but slowly, and air pollution continues to be a fact of life in most cities. This has contributed to an accelerated pace of climate change, which has been noticed in the past few years. According to scientists at the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, temperatures are rising at a faster rate than they have in the past 1,000 years, about 2.5 times as rapidly according to Forbes magazine. #climatechange #Katharinahesse #china. #airpollution #smog #everydayclimatechange

caption: #Regram #RG @everydayclimatechange: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. Empusel, the name the Maasai call the salty, dusty plains and from which the word ‚ÄòAmboseli‚Äô is derived, is about to relish in the first of the rains. The Amboseli basin, a semi-arid, open savannah area of southern Kenya, has experienced extensive changes in habitat since the early 1960's with daily temperatures increasing dramatically at a greater rate than that attributed to global warming. Amboseli has experienced an extensive loss of the trees due to a rising water table and the related rise of the salt layer in the soil, to grazing patterns, to a natural ageing of the woodlands, and to damage from an increasingly resident elephant population now unable to move the distances they used to due to growing human population around the reserve. The temperature changes here are now causing the landscape changes, and to confuse matters the temperature pattern may itself have been caused by the landscape changes. The climate change discussion is as dynamic and as important as ever. #climatechange #globalwarming #ic_landscapes #travel #natgeohub @natgeotravel #desertification #dust #everydayclimatechange #drought #deforestation #trees #colorcrush #horizon #canon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkiii #life #earth #environment #environmentalist #planet #animals

caption: Photo by Amnon Gutman @gutmanen for #everydayclimatechange. A mother and child standing outside their home in one of the slums of Kampla, during a hot summer day. Uganda is one of the countries that are greatly vulnerable to climate change impacts, in respect of climate variability including increasing temperatures, increased frequency and intensity of rainfall, heat waves, droughts, floods and storms. The regions and ecosystems across the country, like the mountain regions, the lowlands and the cattle corridor, differ in their vulnerability and adaptive capacity. In general the sectors most vulnerable to climate change impacts are agriculture, water supply, health, transport, housing and personal safety and security. The economy and the well being of the people of Uganda are tightly bound to climate, especially because over 80% of the population is rural and depending on rain fed agriculture, that is prone to impacts of climate variability. The climate change and variability in the coming century will inflate the frequency and intensity of extreme weathers events and has the potential to halt or reverse the country‚Äôs development trajectory. In particular this will reveal in increased food insecurity, shift in the spread of diseases like malaria, soil erosion and land degradation followed by landslides, flood damage to infrastructure as well as settlement and in lower productivity of agriculture and natural resources. #climatechange #globalwarming #climatechangeuganda
tags: everydayclimatechange, climatechangeuganda, globalwarming, climatechange

caption: Climate Change in Bangladesh ~ After cyclone SIDR a family livening under sky without any shelter and than they try to making some food at the village near the Barguna Sadat area on 19 November 2007 in Bangladesh. People become homeless and suffering shortage of food, drinking water and medicines especially children and woman suffer much more. Rising sea levels and the growing number of natural disasters forced by climate change are already driving migration and displacement.Climate Change is my long-term project where I began to document of marginal condition in my own country of Bangladesh. caption: A fisherman fixing his net on the Tonle Sap, SE Asia's largest freshwater lake. The 'Great Lake' provides more than a third of all the protein eaten by Cambodia‚Äôs 15 million people, but fish stocks are dwindling. caption: Hello, I am Munazza Anwaar, an independent photojournalist from Pakistan. I am thrilled and honored to be taking over the Climate Tracker Instagram account this week. I will be sharing my photo wanderings around Pakistan, some of my throwback photos plus current work from my Instagram account @munazzaanwaar. Today‚Äôs photo is from the Slums of Mattakkuliya (Colombo), following the floods that struck Srilanka in 2016. Beginning on 14 May 2016, a low pressure area over the Bay of Bengal caused torrential rain to fall across Sri Lanka, causing floods and landslides which affected half a million people. Slums of Mattakuliya houses communities right on the edge of the Kelani river. Consisting of jam packed, unplanned improvised and semi-permanent housing constructions, living right on the edge of the river. Most of the people living here are poor, and work on daily basis. Following the heavy rains and floods of May 2016, homeowners had to evacuate when water entered their homes. Leaving poor people with flooded basements, costly roof repairs and damaged electrical appliances. Not to mention it was already hard to find work with children to takecare of and search for temporary places to stay. A girl sits on bike on top of the debris of a damaged home during the 2016 floods, in Mattakkuliya, Colombo, Srilanka. #Srilanka #Floods #ClimateChange #globalwarming #environment #climate #climatefacts #photojournalism #photography #everydayeverywhere #everydayclimatechange #climatechange
tags: photography, globalwarming, environment, climatechange, photojournalism, floods, climate, everydayclimatechange, srilanka, everydayeverywhere, climatefacts

caption: 2015. A protest for the right to water in Malad, Mumbai, by the residents of Ambujwadi, an informal settlement. Organized by grassroots movement Ghar Bachao Ghar Banao, thousands of mostly women carried empty water pots to surround the municipal office. On the 28th of July 2010, the General Assembly of the United Nations, recognized access to clean water and sanitation as a human right, with a vote of 121 nations voting for the resolution, with none voting against, along with 41 abstentions. India voted for water as a human right. Meanwhile the municipal authorities of Mumbai deprive hundreds of informal settlements of water, leaving them at the mercy of mafias. #mumbai #resistance #peoplesmovements #housingrights #water #righttothecity #therighttowater #urbanization #realestate #governance #misgovernance #womenpower #humanrights #gharbachaogharbanao #builderlobby #watermafia #everydaymumbai #everydayclimatechange #unicefwater #instagram #capitalism #landrights #community #cities #protests #cityscape

In China alone, more than 1.6 million people die annually from air pollution. Heavy coal use has resulted in high carbon emissions. Although China has reduced greenhouse gas emissions by 250,000 tons, the nation continues to emit 25 million tons of greenhouse gases, according to Environment Minister Chen Jining. Enforcement of environmental laws has improved, but slowly, and air pollution continues to be a fact of life in most cities. This has contributed to an accelerated pace of climate change, which has been noticed in the past few years. According to scientists at the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, temperatures are rising at a faster rate than they have in the past 1,000 years, about 2.5 times as rapidly according to Forbes magazine. #Repost @everydayclimatechange „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Katharina Hesse /@hessekatharina #climatechange #Katharinahesse #china. #airpollution #smog #everydayclimatechange
tags: repost, smog, climatechange, everydayclimatechange, airpollution, katharinahesse, china

caption: Photo by Katharina Hesse /@hessekatharina A hazy view of Hebei province near Shijiazhuang in the morning. Two of the most toxic components of smog saw their readings exceed 1,000 on the air quality index in Shijiazhuang in China‚Äôs northern Hebei province late last year, state media reported. One resident said her lungs felt ‚Äúextremely uncomfortable‚Äù after she went walking outside for just a few minutes. The amount of PM2.5 and PM10 recorded in Shijiazhuang was greater than 1,000 micrograms per cubic metre at around 1pm, according to Xinhua. Both are types of suspended respirable particles that pose a risk to human health. The World Health Organisation recommends exposure to PM2.5 be limited to 25 micrograms per cubic metre over 24 hours, and 50 micrograms per cubic metre for PM10. Air pollution usually worsens in northern China during the winter, as coal is used to heat homes. Beijing issued a red alert for smog in mid December 2016, its first of the year, and 10 cities in Hebei have followed suit. Under China‚Äôs four-tiered warning system, a red alert will force suspension of factory production and school classes, as well as traffic reduction measures. In China alone, more than 1.6 million people die annually from air pollution. Heavy coal use has resulted in high carbon emissions. Although China has reduced greenhouse gas emissions by 250,000 tons, the nation continues to emit 25 million tons of greenhouse gases, according to Environment Minister Chen Jining. Enforcement of environmental laws has improved, but slowly, and air pollution continues to be a fact of life in most cities. This has contributed to an accelerated pace of climate change, which has been noticed in the past few years. According to scientists at the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, temperatures are rising at a faster rate than they have in the past 1,000 years, about 2.5 times as rapidly according to Forbes magazine. #climatechange #Katharinahesse #china. #airpollution #smog #everydayclimatechange

caption: The Earth‚Äôs average temperature has risen 1.5 degrees F in the past 50 years. While that may not seem true when heavy snowstorms are burying streets near the offices of American politicians, it‚Äôs a very large jump compared to the total temperature rise of 2.5 degrees in the past 250 years. During this time, the atmospheric levels of CO2 have risen dramatically to 400ppm. Considering that the levels of CO2 in the atmosphere have never surpassed 300ppm for hundreds of thousands of years, such high levels in the past 50 years are troubling. Countries that we've already stripped of their resources are being further drained, quite literally, of their water sources by increasing global temperatures. As one of the largest contributors of CO2 emissions, America has a very large impact on the world‚Äôs climate. Although it cannot wean itself from fossil fuels overnight, it can work towards policies that will lower our carbon footprint. Greenhouses are wonderful saunas for our succulent pups post workout, but not so much for the Earth‚Äôs atmosphere. This is our frosty pachyphytum in our Melting Glacier teacup. - ‚ùÑÔ∏èüå° This piece and all others will be available on our online shop coming soon, May 2017. caption: Rotting food and other decaying organic waste allows methane and carbon dioxide to seep out of the ground and up into the air. Methane is a potent greenhouse gas, and can itself be a danger because it is flammable and potentially explosive. In properly managed landfills, gas is collected and utilized. This could range from simple flaring to landfill gas utilization. Carbon dioxide is the most widely produced greenhouse gas. It traps heat in the atmosphere, contributing to climate change. #thenewtopography #ecooko #everydayclimatechange #ecologyproblems #documentaryphotography #docudaysua #rentalmag #yetmagazine #landscapes #phasesmag #phroommagazine #akasimagazine #somewheremagazine #foammagazine #garbagedump #humbleartsfoundation #kievgram #newtopographics #noicemag

caption: This image is part of my series "The Secret Environmentalist" Before starting this project, I always used to wonder where our daily garbage goes. The country generates 62 million tons of waste annually. This is expected to increase to 165 million tons by 2030 and 450 million tons by 2050. More than 90 percent of India doesn‚Äôt have a proper waste disposal system, so the whole responsibility of the garbage dumping relies on the shoulders of rag pickers ‚Äì one of India‚Äôs poorest and most marginalized groups. They are not paid by the state; they rely on meagre salaries received from the communities they serve and on meagre profits from the sale of discarded items. These are some untold facts I came to know when I started researching the lives of rag-pickers. There is a large workforce of rag-pickers in BK Guda Basti, Hyderabad, which segregate garbage. People assume that municipalities are responsible for waste management, but these rag-pickers have a prominent role when it comes to managing waste in every city. Rag picking is effectively the primary recycling system in India. While talking to Anjali (20) and her mother Sakshi (50), who earn their livelihood by picking garbage, I realized their work is by no means environmentally friendly, and very far from being secure. While the rag pickers offer invaluable services to the city, they have few rights. Every day, they deal with deadly poison bare handed just to earn Rs 2700 a month which is in any way not sufficient for a family of three. ‚ÄúWe sort human hair from the garbage and sell them at Rs. 30/- per kg and it takes ages to collect them.‚Äù ‚Äì stated Rohini (24), who works with her 6-year-old daughter, Meenakshi. They are the secret environmentalist. They may not be aware of it or may not even understand the term, but they are the few among 300,000 rag-pickers who perform a vital role for the city. This body of was created under the aegis of Neel Dongre Grant 2016 by India photo archive foundation . . . #everydayeverywhere #instagram #photojournalism #Hyderabad #dailylife #TheWeekOnInstagram #everydayclimatechange #environmentalissue #ragpickers #recycling#neeldongregrant2016 #india #asia #friendsinperson_08
tags: theweekoninstagram, dailylife, india, neeldongregrant2016, everydayclimatechange, friendsinperson_08, asia, instagram, ragpickers, recycling, everydayeverywhere, photojournalism, hyderabad, environmentalissue

caption: The only way I know how! At first glance this seems like another mystical seascape however on further investigation you'll discover this image is part of a documentary series I've been working on. SEALEVEL - 'The Art of Awareness' is my creative photographic interpretation of an event. ‚ûïThe Art of Awareness is just that, creating awareness through art, through documenting the beauty of our ocean - sea level. Capturing mother natures elements at play - it's an 'Adventure in Light'. ‚ûïTo date there is an Exhibition Series of 20 frames and the Sealevel Collection (which continues to grow) both are up now in the gallery. ‚ûïlink in my bio @tedgrambeau to fully experience this body of work or search www.tedgrambeauphotography.com

caption: Amanolah and 9 person in his family (4 girls and 5 boys ) live in small village near Afghanistan and Iran border , all of them don‚Äôt have an identity card, Neither government ever recognized them as their own. Thus they can not move in Iranian towns. Amanolah‚Äôs wife is Iranian. She is only allowed to go in town to shop and ... sistan,Iran,2015 In Commemoration of #worldwetlandsday Hamoon Lake and wetlands, which holds the seventh international rank in the world and most of it is located in Iran and also Afghanistan.It is a long time that Hamoon lake faces water scarcity and its wide drought has led to different problems such as environmental, social and economic in that area. This has caused interference in the life of 400000 people in eastern lands of Iran plus poverty and insecurity by drug smugglers and terrorists active gangs and large number of emigration to other parts of Iran.Every year,as summer and 120 to 160 day storms starts,a big amount of dust and sand storm attacks life of the people and when the other seasons begin, the aimless and bloomless life continues. #iran #hamoonlake #sistan #baluchistan #water #worldwetlandsday2017 #identity #people #man #mahdibarchian #storiesofiranians #lensculture #natgeo #natgeoyourshot #instalike #instagram #portrait #picoftheday #everydayeverywhere #everyday #ReportageSpotlight #ramsarconvention #alone #everydayclimatechange #unicefwater

caption: It hasn't rained since October. People have been loosing their crops to drought so they've had to buy food instead of relying on their harvest. This has had a huge impact on communities, particularly with the start of school approaching and the inevitable cost of school fees weighing heavily on the shoulders of ordinary men and women. But for the last five nights the welcome relief of rain has brought hope and respite from the burning sun. The earth is rejoicing, as is everyone üå∫ #leoandindie
tags: leoandindie

caption: A farmer at work on a field in the outskirts of #Ranchi, #Jharkhand, #India. A recent initiative by the Jharkhand government under which #SolarPanels are being provided to the farming community, has proved to be of great advantage. The power generation through these panels aids in irrigation and also provides electricity for running their homes. As per the scheme, farmers have to bear only 20% of the total cost of installation and the rest is borne by the government. This has also opened up avenues for encouraging the use of sustainable and eco-friendly sources of energy. #EverydayEverywhere #EverydayClimateChange #EverydayIndia #DailyLife #Photojournalism #ReportageSpotlight #IndiaPhotoProject #OnePlusLife

caption: @leonardodicaprio #Regram #RG @natgeo: üì∏ by @edkashi & @viiphoto: A field of crops is covered by plastic bags in California‚Äôs Central Valley in December 2016. Prolonged droughts in the Valley have caused extreme weather conditions, damaging crops due to lack of rainfall and absence of moisture in the air. In a recent article posted in cropinsuranceinamerica.org, Doug Benik, a farmer and crop insurance agent explains, ‚ÄúThe lack of moisture in the air allows air temperatures to get much colder in the winter and much hotter in the summer.‚Äù Due to the much colder temperatures, farmers use different methods for protecting their crops from frostbite, such as covering them with bags. #everydayclimatechange #actonclimate #California #CentralValley #crops #climatechange
tags: rg, centralvalley, everydayclimatechange, california, regram, climatechange, crops, actonclimate

caption: üò¢ #Repost @leonardodicaprio „Éª„Éª„Éª #Regram #RG @everydayclimatechange: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. This image of an Amhara boy and his horse in barren fields that should be full of wheat and teff was taken in Wollo 600kms north of Ethiopia's capital Addis in 2008 when the entire region suffered major drought as both the years' rains failed. Ethiopia continues to face the same issues of failed rains and are currently suffering the worst drought in 30 years exacerbated by the El Ni√±o phenomenon. A recent climate change study in the Horn of Africa finds that the land is drying out at an unusually fast pace as a result of soaring greenhouse gas emissions. Associate professor at the University of Arizona and lead author of the study Jessica Tierney said in a statement in the IBTimes, "Given the scale of threats in Africa and across the world, studying the hyper-local impacts of climate change will be critical to helping communities adapt and prepare". In a country where more than eight in ten people depend on rain-fed agriculture, the drought is having a significant impact and the Ethiopian government estimates that more than 9 million people will need humanitarian assistance in 2016. #climatechange #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #ethiopia #documentary #photojournalism #climate #visualsoflife #ethiopia #GlobalClimateChange2015 #News #environment #famine
tags: globalwarming, rg, repost, famine, everydayclimatechange, climate, visualsoflife, documentary, globalclimatechange2015, regram, climatechange, environment, news, photojournalism, ethiopia

caption: Floating Cow...I love cows so while these guys are free range and the farmers around here have never done live exports I still hear their cries when they are loaded on the trucks to be sent to the abattoir... its heart wrenching. Cows are not great for the environment either releasing tons and tons of methane gas and causing soil erosion..and too much beef is not tremendously good for your health. So why do we have cows in Australia.. where we have cleared the land, causing erosion, methane gases, dispossession of First Nations people, war and heart attacks... doesn't seem very sensible to me... day 31 of a photo a day for a year #blackandwhite #monogram #instagood #instadaily #everydayclimatechange #burnmagazine @burnmagazine @burndiary #justgoshoot #photooftheday #bnw #monoart #yourshotphotographer #my_365 #everydayaustralia #australianlife

caption: The Fallen... it seems like I am making images with an apocalyptic overtone in the last few days... perhaps it's the influence that a figure like Trump has...the removal of any mention of Climate Change on the Whitehouse website seems to enhance this image... this small beautiful bird was still warm when I found it... I have no idea why it suddenly died... but such beauty is fragile and we must do as much as we can to nurture and preserve our native environments...in this respect Trump terrifies me... day 29 of a photo a day for a year photo @lisahogben #everydayclimatechange #yourshotphotographer @burnmagazine @burndiary #canon #picoftheday #bestoftheday #art #birdsofinstagram #justgoshoot #peoplescreative #my_365

caption: Climate protection The Rockies and other mountain ranges in the world are, through their increasing rate of glacial retreat, showing the signs of climate change. caption: Rocky Mountain Field Institute staff and volunteer crews work on an erosion control structure in Colorado Springs Waldo Canyon Burn Scar area. The 2012 fire burned over 18,000 acres and almost 350 homes were list, along with two lives. Drought, Beetle-Kill pines compounded by Climate Change contribute to damaging fires in Colorado every year. #everydayclimatechange #rmficolorado #climatechange #forestfires #waldocanyonfire #coloradosprings #conservation #conservationphotography #restoration #drought #beetlekill #bolunteers #canoneos
tags: coloradosprings, everydayclimatechange, conservationphotography, drought, conservation, canoneos, beetlekill, waldocanyonfire, restoration, climatechange, rmficolorado, forestfires, bolunteers

caption: Drought and Beetle-Kill pines compounded by Climate Change can be devastating to a forest and community. Colorado Springs' Waldo Canyon Fire of 2012 burned over 18,000 acres and nearly 350 homes were lost. It is the 2nd most destructive fire in Colorado's recorded history. Conservation groups like Colorado Springs' Rocky Mountain Field Institute stay busy restoring such areas like the Waldo Canyon Burn Scar. RMFI continues to stabilize and revegetate the slopes affected by the fire. Erosion has been a major concern following the fire as steep slopes combined with Colorado's flash floods can cause dire consequences below. RMFI's crews consist of staff members and numerous volunteers who care about the local environment. #everydayclimatechange #rmficolorado #conservation #restoration #burnscar #waldocanyonburnscar #waldocanyonfire #coloradosprings #climatechange #drought #fire #forestfire #volunteerworkers #volunteers #conservationphotography #canoneos

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. A Masai woman brings her cows home at sunset during the dry season in Kenya's south Rift. Kenya, like the rest of the world, is experiencing climate change and variability and the associated adverse impacts. There is a gradual climate change of less rainfall, with failed rains becoming increasingly likely. These changes are gradual but are noticeable. The level of the Ewaso Nyiro river, the areas lifeline, in some areas fell by 12ft. The grass has literally vanished leaving pastures of thick fine dust. Livestock now needs to travel greater distances from the homesteads to find any form of pasture which means they now return at dusk. As pressure on resources continues to increase, our need to implement protection and mitigation strategies becomes even greater. #climatechange #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #vscokenya #igkenya #environment #desert #desertification #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #justbackfrom #sunsetsniper #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #reframeclimate #dust #canon #ic_landscapes #canon5dmarkIII #photooftheday
tags: toldwithexposure, sunsetsniper, visualsoflife, everydayclimatechange, desertification, followmetoo, reframeclimate, documentary, vscokenya, photooftheday, repost, photojournalism, igkenya, canon5dmarkiii, canon, desert, globalwarming, justbackfrom, climatechangeisreal, ic_landscapes, climate, climatechange, environment, dust

caption: The first heavy snow of the South Korean winter fell down on the planet last week. The winter has been extremely mild and significantly warmer than in times past. 2016 was the hottest year in recorded history and I have no doubt that as climate change intensifies 2017 will break that record yet again. Despite this planetary emergency our world leaders and decision makers are in a state of perpetual stasis and denial. . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #southkorea #korea #asia #eastasia #climatechangeisreal

caption: Fossil fuels burn brighter than the glow of the setting sun as twilight falls over south Mumbai. The city‚Äôs annual carbon footprint is double the national average of 1.4 tonnes. Every year, an average Mumbaiite emits 3.83 tonnes of carbon dioxide, which is equivalent to emissions from a small petrol car making 76 round trips between Mumbai and Pune (a distance of 165km). The city is blessed to be flanked by the Arabian Sea on one side and the Sanjay Gandhi National Park and other forested areas on the other, both of which act as carbon sinks. A general lack of environmental concern among city dwellers and apathy on part of the government has led to the continual abuse of these natural assets.#EverydayMumbai #Mumbai #EverydayIndia #India#ReportageSpotlight #everydayeverywhere#magnumphotos #burndiary #burnmagazine#natgeo #featureshoot #lensculture#photojournalism #documentaryphotography #one__shot__#lensculturestreets #everybodystreet#Streetphotographers #everydayclimatechange #climatechange Photo and text by Rizwan Mithawala / @rizwanmithawala

caption: The Fallen... it seems like I am making images with an apocalyptic overtone in the last few days... perhaps it's the influence that a figure like Trump has...the removal of any mention of Climate Change on the Whitehouse website seems to enhance this image... this small beautiful bird was still warm when I found it... I have no idea why it suddenly died... but such beauty is fragile and we must do as much as we can to nurture and preserve our native environments...in this respect Trump terrifies me... day 29 of a photo a day for a year...#photooftheday #dailyphoto #streetphotography #storytelling #reportage #reportagespotlight #dailyphoto #instadaily #yourshotphotographer #burndiary #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #everydayaustralia #australianlife #birdsofinstagram #instamood #featureshoot #theearthissue

caption: Climate Change is Real¬Æ #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: A sunset accompanied by thick brown smog over part of the megalopolis of Seoul, South Korea. The Air Quality Index (AQI) last week hit over 200 yesterday with PM 2.5 levels reaching 145 and PM 10 levels reaching 131. This level of air pollution would case public health alerts in nations with strict air pollution policies. However, here, in Korea, little to nothing is being done on scale to even attempt to control this. Most air pollutants are sourced from the combustion of fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and also biomass (wood etc.) fires, which are also the drivers of human-induced climate change. . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #climatechangesireal #globalwarming #airpollution #publichealth #korea #southkorea #seoul #iseoulu
tags: globalwarming, everydayclimatechange, airpollution, seoul, iseoulu, publichealth, korea, climatechange, climatechangesireal, southkorea, repost

caption: A Tale of Bleeding Earth üåø part 43üåø #DidYouKnowüëâ The #carbon clock is ticking and the time left for total #ecological imbalance is just 18 years? #DidYouKnowüëâ If we plant a tree on every #sunday i.e. 52 trees per year, we can recover the damage done by #globalwarming in next 30 years? #DidYouKnow üëâ Trees don't provide free WiFi, otherwise we would have definitely planted 60 trees every year , individually? What say? Just asking! @winsletthebest #LeoSavesThePlanet #globalwarming #globalwarmingisreal #gardens #parks #sun #plants #trees #reducecarbon Picture credit @zenyepakkayagiyim #everydayclimatechange üåøüåøüåøüåªüåøüåøüåøüåª #DidYouKnow üëâ The UK‚Äôs first Air Pollution Garden has been established at Sheffield Botanical Gardens through a collaboration between the three White Rose universities of Leeds, York and Sheffield. üëâAn Air #Pollution Garden contains plants that are particularly sensitive to damage by #pollutants in the air. These plants can help us identify regions that experience high concentrations of dangerous pollutants, such as #nitrogendioxide (NO2) and #ozone (O3). üëâDespite efforts to improve air quality over the past few decades, air pollution levels in the #UK remain high enough to have significant impacts on the natural environment and our health. üëâChildren from the Porter Croft Primary School, as well as some home-educated students, helped to create the garden and learned about the importance of good air quality for their health. üëâThe garden will visually demonstrate the effects of pollution on plants with discolouring of the leaves. So far, snap beans and clover have been planted alongside lettuce and wheat, and cutleaf coneflower and common milkweed will be added in a few months. üëâBeing exposed to poor air quality can cause #lung and #heart problems. On days when ground levels of ozone and nitrogen dioxide are high, people can experience lung irritation, while those with existing diseases such as #asthma, may experience more severe symptoms.

caption: Elba mountain #4 Eissa using radio transmitter to contact with his friends since there is no signal there. Gabl Elba National Park in the remote southeast region of Egypt. This region, situated on the Halaib Triangle. The park was named after the highest peak on the mountain Gebel Elba which is 1435m above sea level. caption: Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: A sunset accompanied by thick brown smog over part of the megalopolis of Seoul, South Korea. The Air Quality Index (AQI) last week hit over 200 yesterday with PM 2.5 levels reaching 145 and PM 10 levels reaching 131. This level of air pollution would case public health alerts in nations with strict air pollution policies. However, here, in Korea, little to nothing is being done on scale to even attempt to control this. Most air pollutants are sourced from the combustion of fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and also biomass (wood etc.) fires, which are also the drivers of human-induced climate change. . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #climatechangesireal #globalwarming #airpollution #publichealth #korea #southkorea #seoul #iseoulu
tags: korea, globalwarming, southkorea, airpollution, everydayclimatechange, seoul, iseoulu, climatechange, climatechangesireal, publichealth

caption: PUBLIC LANDS RALLY 2017 will be tomorrow at 12pm in Helena, Montana. If you can make it, please come! If you can't, please write a letter to your representatives asking them to #keepitpublic. Public lands are important, not just for recreation. Public lands are often crucial habitat for wildlife. Keeping corporate hands from developing public lands is one of the easiest ways to preserve wildlife habitat. Migratory ungulates (like the pronghorn antelope in this photo) move through public lands, state lands, wildlife refuges, and national parks during their journey from wintering grounds to summer habitat. Development like roads, mines, and oil drilling can overtake habitat and block migration corridors. ü¶åüêè We need to keep public lands public, not only for ourselves and future generations, but for the many species (who don't have a voice) who rely on it as well. #wildlife #conservation #publicland #keepitwild #environment #nature #pronghorn #montana #activism #science #sciencebasedpolicy #everydayclimatechange #natgeowild
tags: publicland, montana, keepitwild, conservation, activism, everydayclimatechange, natgeowild, keepitpublic, environment, pronghorn, sciencebasedpolicy, nature, wildlife, science

caption: @everydayclimatechange An abandoned cement factory sits decrepit at the center of a ghost town called Siberia outside Bogota, Colombia. caption: @social.affairs Suku anak dalam or Orang Rimba. The origin of jungle people of Jambi. @Regrann from @info_jambi_ - Orang rimba tribes take a rest while they going for hunting in the forest. Orang Rimba (forest people) or known as Suku Anak Dalam is one of the tribe groups living in the depth of forests in Jambi Province (Sumatra, Indonesia). They are nomadic life based and their lives depend on what is provided by forests. Since the 1970s, many of these peoples have been displaced from their traditional lands by logging companies and palm oil plantations, and for some time have been the target of government settlement projects. - lokasi bukit 12 kab.sarolangun.jambi.indonesia foto @uletifan #infojambi#pesonajambi#taujambi#jambi#galeryjambi#jambiku#travel#travelltrip#wonderfulindonesia #forestproject #saveourforest #saverainforest #deforestation #orangrimba #sukuanakdalam #climatechange #everydayclimatechange - #regrann

caption: RepostBy @everydayindia: "Photo by @nishallama Lower Assam | August 2016 Malati Das, a resident of Nalbari district, in the Indian State of Assam, waits for her husband in knee-deep water outside her house who was out to look for a job. A farmer otherwise, he had been forced to look for a job as a wage laborer elsewhere, since most of the agricultural land he owned was inundated in flood water. The 2016 Assam Floods were caused by large rains over the Indian State of Assam in July. The flooding had affected 1.8 million people in the State. When the floods hit the State in August last year, their main concern was about repaying the debt. When I think about it, I feel the annual natural calamity must have made them strong enough to cope with the situation but little has been done to rehabilitate them. All that‚Äôs been done year after year is to provide relief materials during flood for a couple of days. When the water recedes, they are left on their own. And it‚Äôs a vicious cycle. Last year when I visited some of these villages, floods had arrived just before the harvest. Many villagers like them lost almost 90% of their cultivation to flood. And there was no way they could repay the money they had borrowed from money lenders. Lack of proper irrigation facilities force farmers, especially those living in low lying area, to cultivate during monsoon. And floods being a yearly affair in Assam, little can be done to stop these areas from flooding. Experts say, if Government could provide with a better irrigation system, winter rice crop could be raised in many of these low lying area that remain flooded during the rainy season otherwise. Also, as part of the rehabilitation process, if specific skill program could be introduced, they could perhaps work else where during the monsoon. This image is part of a personal documentary project documenting lives of families affected by flood every year in Assam. #drowningstate #everydayindia #everydayeverywhere #floodsinassam #assamflood #dailylifeindia #floodplain #naturaldisaster #naturalcalamity #globalwarming #brahamaputra #lenscultureportraits #everydayclimatechange #disastermanagement #photooftheday #editorial
tags: disastermanagement, brahamaputra, editorial, everydayclimatechange, floodsinassam, photooftheday, everydayindia, assamflood, dailylifeindia, naturaldisaster, lenscultureportraits, floodplain, naturalcalamity, globalwarming, drowningstate, everydayeverywhere

caption: @samreinders: "One of the highlights of my trip to Zimbabwe was meeting Melody Ruya and her extended family. Seven women live at their homestead. The patriarch of the family (Melody‚Äôs uncle) is away trying to make whatever money he can to send back and support the family. The next few photo‚Äôs are of the Ruya family and their homestead, where I was welcomed with food despite the shortage of it, (I replaced it the next day), with kindness (I‚Äôd like to think I gave that back in heaps) and, admittedly, with a little intrigue. When I first met Melody there was something in her eye‚Äôs that made me immediately like her: a mischievousness that I recognized and I could relate to. The Ruya family is just one family among millions of others who are being affected by massive drought across huge swathes of the Africa. Climate change is making the 2015/2016 El Nino one of the worst in history. Millions of the world‚Äôs poorest people are being affected by increasing droughts, floods and other weather-related disasters that are happening more and more often. These disasters are destroying crops and killing the cattle and goats of people who are dependent on them to survive. Women and girls are amongst the worst affected‚Ä¶ #everydayclimatechange #everydayafrica #Zimbabwe #actionaid #ElNino #drought #portrait" (via #InstaRepost @AppsKottage)

caption: Photo by Vlad Sokhin @lens_pacific Station Chief of Barrow Observatory in Alaska Bryan Thomas holding two five-litre flasks to collect samples of air during a weekly experiment, where he measured the background level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. At the observatory he and his colleagues study the effects of global warming on the population of birds, polar bears, and other Arctic animals, as well as measuring levels of sea ice melting in the Arctic Ocean. All the data is sent to the San Diego laboratory for analysis. Bryan showed me a graph with an upward curve of the carbon dioxide levels for the whole observation time since 1975 in the laboratories in Alaska, Hawaii, American Samoa, and the South Pole. All the four stations show almost the same increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which is one of the contributing factors of global warming. #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #globalwarming #climatescience #Alaska #icemelting #arctic ##USA #UnitedStates #America #climatechangeisreal @panospictures @everydayclimatechange

caption: Photo by Vlad Sokhin @lens_pacific for @everydayclimatechange Station Chief of Barrow Observatory in Alaska Bryan Thomas holding two five-litre flasks to collect samples of air during a weekly experiment, where he measured the background level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. At the observatory he and his colleagues study the effects of global warming on the population of birds, polar bears, and other Arctic animals, as well as measuring levels of sea ice melting in the Arctic Ocean. All the data is sent to the San Diego laboratory for analysis. Bryan showed me a graph with an upward curve of the carbon dioxide levels for the whole observation time since 1975 in the laboratories in Alaska, Hawaii, American Samoa, and the South Pole. All the four stations show almost the same increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which is one of the contributing factors of global warming. #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #globalwarming #climatescience #Alaska #icemelting #arctic ##USA #UnitedStates #America #climatechangeisreal @panospictures @everydayclimatechange @agencecosmos @laifphoto
tags: icemelting, unitedstates, america, climatechangeisreal, climatechange, everydayclimatechange, arctic, globalwarming, usa, alaska, climatescience

caption: 2016 is officially the hottest year on Earth since record-keeping began in 1880. Global temperatures have continued to rise, making 2016 the hottest year on the historical record and the third consecutive record-breaking year. Of the 17 hottest years ever recorded, 16 have now occurred since 2000. Studies have shown that human-induced climate change is perhaps the biggest factor that has contributed to global warming. One could argue that about 75 percent of the warmth is due to human impact. In this picture, men seeks respite from the cold by standing in front of a burning haystack in #Ranchi, #Jharkhand, #India. #EverydayEverywhere #EverydayClimateChange #EverydayIndia #DailyLife #ReportageSpotlight #IndiaPhotoProject #OnePlusLife

caption: Climate Change in Bangladesh ~ Villagers are shifting their belongings to secure place. The worst flood affected district in Munshigonj on 09 August 2007. People become homeless and suffering shortage of food, drinking water and medicines especially children and woman suffer much more. Rising sea levels and the growing number of natural disasters forced by climate change are already driving migration and displacement.Climate Change is my long-term project where I began to document of marginal condition in my own country of Bangladesh. My investigation finally brought me to a climate refugee in Bangladesh.¬© Monirul Alam #climatechange#globalwarming#everydayclimatechange#photojournalism#bangladesh#dailylife#erosion#drought#flood#yourshotphotographer#reportagespotlight#opensocietyfoundations#lensculture#longtermproject#documentary#Munshigonj#CycloneSidr#safedrinkingwater#river#women#food#disaster#villager

caption: Photo by @nishallama Lower Assam | August 2016 Malati Das, a resident of Nalbari district, in the Indian State of Assam, waits for her husband in knee-deep water outside her house who was out to look for a job. A farmer otherwise, he had been forced to look for a job as a wage laborer elsewhere, since most of the agricultural land he owned was inundated in flood water. The 2016 Assam Floods were caused by large rains over the Indian State of Assam in July. The flooding had affected 1.8 million people in the State. When the floods hit the State in August last year, their main concern was about repaying the debt. When I think about it, I feel the annual natural calamity must have made them strong enough to cope with the situation but little has been done to rehabilitate them. All that‚Äôs been done year after year is to provide relief materials during flood for a couple of days. When the water recedes, they are left on their own. And it‚Äôs a vicious cycle. Last year when I visited some of these villages, floods had arrived just before the harvest. Many villagers like them lost almost 90% of their cultivation to flood. And there was no way they could repay the money they had borrowed from money lenders. Lack of proper irrigation facilities force farmers, especially those living in low lying area, to cultivate during monsoon. And floods being a yearly affair in Assam, little can be done to stop these areas from flooding. Experts say, if Government could provide with a better irrigation system, winter rice crop could be raised in many of these low lying area that remain flooded during the rainy season otherwise. Also, as part of the rehabilitation process, if specific skill program could be introduced, they could perhaps work else where during the monsoon. This image is part of a personal documentary project documenting lives of families affected by flood every year in Assam. #drowningstate #everydayindia #everydayeverywhere #floodsinassam #assamflood #dailylifeindia #floodplain #naturaldisaster #naturalcalamity #globalwarming #brahamaputra #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #disastermanagement #photooftheday #editorial #reportagespotlight

caption: Monks walk out of a meditation session after the first heavy snow of the South Korean winter. Up until about a week ago temperatures during the ‚Äúwinter‚Äù on the Korean peninsula were extremely mild and there were days when the mercury would reach up to 10 degrees Celsius. For the (almost) two months that it was meant to be winter it felt like autumn never ended. This is no surprise, as recently, climate scientists stated that the Earth, for the third year in a row, reached record high overall temperatures due to the warming effects of climate change from CO2 emissions. . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange#globalwarming #southkorea #korea #asia #climatechangeisreal

caption: 'They give us electricity to power our homes, I learnt that in school.' said Meera in a very jubilant mood. Meera and her friends were really happy to meet people from the 'company.' (@hero_futureenergies ) you like going to school?' I asked Meera, she said that she loved to visit school, learn new things and be with friends. Her mother and father work in the fields and also work as laborers in occasional constructions around the village. She also told me that she loved watching the windmills move. For me it's a very unique scenario to live besides such giant structures which have such noticeable impact on the global climate change. I tried to watch the windmills moving peacefully just like Meera, and for a moment I truly forgot about my assignment and was engulfed in a sense of childish awe and a little bit of hope for a greener future. Climate Change is real hope our world leaders understand that! #everydayclimatechange
tags: everydayclimatechange

Up until about a week ago temperatures during the ‚Äúwinter‚Äù on the Korean peninsula were extremely mild and there were days when the mercury would reach up to 10 degrees Celsius. For the (almost) two months that it was meant to be winter it felt like autumn never ended. This is no surprise, as recently, climate scientists stated that the Earth, for the third year in a row, reached record high overall temperatures due to the warming effects of climate change from CO2 emissions. . #climatechangeimpact #actonclimate #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #southkorea #korea #climatechangeisreal

caption: Along with being the planet's lungs, trees protect watersheds. Use coupon code: DUMPTRUMP for 10% off prints and 10% will be donated to Standing Rock until Jan. 31st. Link in bio. This is an aerial photograph I created with the support of @lighthawk_org of an aspen stand. Aspens are part of the same massive organism, connected underground and living for millennia. Pando, Earth's largest aspen stand found in Utah‚Äôs Fishlake National Forest, is one of the oldest living organisms on the planet estimated to be 80,000 years old. There's been an abrupt and extensive range wide aspen die-off from widespread drought sparked by human generated climate change including 1.3 million acres in the Southern Rockies.
Save the planet so we can continue to enjoy our oceans and the life Earth provides. Via @ramontormes

Fiji was the first country in the world to ratify the Paris Agreement on #climatechange for a reason (actually, a few reasons). We see the effects of climate change with seawater levels rising above the well line, forcing the Mali community to import water to get through the dry season. We see it in the damage of the coral reef with Mali‚Äôs Great Sea Reef Divers. We see it in the extreme weather patterns that have wiped out the homes and resources that so many Fijians rely on. Take action today: www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/takeaction/ #EverydayClimateChange #Vorovoro #Mali #Fiji #ClimateChangeInFiji #SouthPacificClimateChange #climatechange #risingsealevels #cyclonewinston #thisisreal #weseeit #collectiveaction

caption: Photo by @marceloperezdelcarpio .- A huge pipe collects some water from the farest snow mountains of La Cumbre to drain fresh water towards dry lagoons near Incachaca dam in the outskirts of La Paz, Bolivia, Jan, 2017. The Bolivian capital suffered a severe drought and water shortage since last November, where its principal dams and lagoons reached critical levels. After more than three months of delay, the rain season has just started but in minor intensity than usual, as result of climate change that also has melted almost all the snow mountains and glaciers nearby. / Una gran tuber√≠a colecta agua desde los nevados m√°s alejados de la Cumbre para drenar agua hacia las lagunas que est√°n cerca de la represa de Incachaca, en las afueras de La Paz, Bolivia. Las lluvias reci√©n empezaron, pero con menor intensidad de lo usual, luego de casi tres meses de retraso, producto del cambio clim√°tico, que a su vez ha descongelado la mayor√≠a de los glaciares y nevados de la zona. #pipe #lagoon #water #level #shortage #cumbre #dam #laguna #nationalpark #cotapata #futureworld #lapaz #Bolivia #Southamerica #horizon #rainseason #documentary #storytelling #snowmountain #glacier #blackandwhite #rain #minimal #quiet #landscape #climatechange #crisis #everydayclimatechange

caption: A new future is unfolding in the Arctic. Rising temperatures are opening up the region to increased shipping and oil exploration as sea ice thins and disappears altogether. Under Obama, fossil fuel extraction in the Arctic was banned, but under Trump, things could change. Members of the Arctic Council, like Norway, are excited about what this could mean for development in the region. They see investment opportunities. Activists, though, see destruction. The fragile ecosystem of the Arctic is the canary in the coal mine for the growing impacts of global warming. Once the iconic ice and snow is gone, sun radiation which was reflected back into space will be absorbed by the dark soil underneath. Methane and other potent greenhouse gases trapped under the ice will be released into the atmosphere, and scientists say this could warm the planet faster than we had ever imagined. So what is development if it leaves us worse off than before? #obama #trump
tags: climate, troms√∏, trump, norway, arctic, everydayclimatechange, arcticcouncil, obama, globalwarming, sea, actonclimate, greenhouse, climatechange, arcticfrontiers, ice, arcticcircle, traveldiaries

caption: No one likes to go to the doctor, that is for sure. Most waiting rooms are unpleasant too with patients waiting for their turns to get diagnosed. This particular room was in a small village in Madhya Pradesh when I had to get medical approval before climbing the windmills with @hero_futureenergies .The wall in the photograph was heavily decorated with old degrees and certificates, efficiently working as self esteem boosters for the doctor! Three local women entered the room, I instantly wanted to photograph them mainly because of their unique saree prints. I conversed with them and told them that we were here to see the 'pawan chakkis.' Their local dialect was hard to grasp. I asked them if they knew what the windmills did, 'our children learnt in school, they give bijli (electricity) to our homes.' It was good to know that they knew about the windmills. The conversation soon faded into the familiar silence prevalent in all waiting rooms. I chose this particular photograph because of the motion in the women, the killer type on the plastic bag and the doctor's boring waiting room. Everything seemed dark yet comic!
leadinggeneration.com: Giving you the knowledge to power your life toward a sustainable future. #alternativeenergy #cleantechnology #solarpower Launching February 2017.

caption: Photo by @nishallama Just as the water starts receding after the July 2016 flood, Gauran Bhuyan finally manages to get back to his house after living in a boat for almost two weeks in Majuli, Assam. The floodwater had inundated his house along with many others living in Salmora area, one of the worst flood affected areas in the river island. He spent a great deal of time and exhausted most of his savings to rebuild the damaged house. With few thousands as savings, he couldn‚Äôt engage any other workers to rebuild the house and had to do it all by himself. His parents are too old to be of much help to do such physical work. Bhuyan and his family have been displaced many times already. He lost his fertile farming land to erosion and now works as a wage laborer. He is also a boat maker but his financial condition lets him make only a couple of them every year. The 2016 Assam Floods were caused by large rains over the Indian State of Assam in July. The flooding had affected 1.8 million people in the State. When I first met Gauran Bhuyan in February 2016, he was making a few boats. His house, just a few meters from the river, was newly constructed after the previous one got eroded away in September 2015 flood. In this image, Bhuyan shows me vaguely where his house used to be at some point of time. In the last 50 years, Majuli in Assam, one of the largest river islands in the world with human settlement, has lost more than half its land mass. Drastic shrinkage of landmass of the island due to erosion caused by river is posing a serious threat to the very existence of the island. Hundreds of families get displaced every year due to erosion leaving many homeless and affecting their livelihood. This image is part of a personal documentary project documenting lives of families affected by flood every year in Assam. #everydayindia #everydayeverywhere #everydayclimatechange #drowningstate #floodsinassam #assamflood #soilerosion #livelihood #photojournalism #dailylifeindia #majuli #worldslargestriverisland #brahamaputra #assam #drowningstate
tags: photojournalism, assam, brahamaputra, floodsinassam, drowningstate, everydayclimatechange, soilerosion, worldslargestriverisland, dailylifeindia, everydayindia, livelihood, assamflood, everydayeverywhere, majuli

caption: "Every time I pick up the basket, my head aches, but it recovers after some time", recollects Sandeep, a 13-year-old boy who shares his experience of working in the coalfields of Jharia while scavenging coal since last one year. Sandeep , who used to help his father in the fields earlier, has never been to a school. On being asked about his desire/dream, he says that he dreams of riding a tempo rickshaw after growing up in order to earn a living. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia
tags: fire, everydayclimatechange, people, everydayindia, pollution, natgeoearthday, asia, life, dailylifeindia, everydayeverywhere, reportagespotlight, landscape, nature, tybitto, india, climatechange

caption: Climbers near Stella Point on Kilimanjaro's rim at sunrise, a view of the vertical margin wall can be seen of what is left of the Rebmann Glacier, a small remnant of what was the enormous icecap which once crowned Mount Kilimanjaro, 14 October 2016. There are many forces driving the climate of East Africa, one being the increased dryness of East Africa - the cause of droughts and famines in Kenya, Ethiopia and Sudan - which may be the key driver of glacier shrinkage and may in fact be speeding up due to global climate change. About 90% of Kilimanjaro's snowcap has vanished, the rate of glacier shrinkage doubling since the 1970s when human caused climate change kicked in. #climatechange #everydayclimatechange @everydayclimatechange #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #kilimanjaro #tanzania #environment #desert #desertification #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #justbackfrom #glaciers #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #reframeclimate #dust #canon #ic_landscapes #canon5dmarkIII #photooftheday

caption: At the time of this portrait, Gauran Bhuyan stands on the boat and tells me how they had taken shelter in the boat during the flood. ‚ÄúWe lived here for almost two weeks before the water receded. There were a few more families with us,‚Äù he said. The 2016 Assam Floods were caused by large rains over the Indian State of Assam in July. The flooding had affected 1.8 million people in the State. When I first met Gauran Bhuyan in February 2016, he was making a few boats. His house, just a few meters from the river, was newly constructed after the previous one got eroded away in September 2015 flood. Along with him, many other families lost their agricultural land, their only source of livelihood. Now, without his own farming land, he till‚Äôs someone else‚Äôs land and gets half the profit. Most of the time, the profit is the rice he cultivates, which is used by his family for consumption through out the year. Sometimes, all the hard work goes in vain because the floodwater would have damaged the harvest completely. In the last 50 years, Majuli in Assam, one of the largest river islands in the world with human settlement, has lost more than half its land mass. Drastic shrinkage of land mass of the island due to erosion caused by river is posing a serious threat to the very existence of the island. Hundreds of families get displaced every year due to erosion leaving many homeless and affecting their livelihood. The region is possibly India's most flood-prone state and has experienced at least 12 major floods since 1950. #everydayclimatechange #drowningstate #floodsinassam #photojournalism #dailylifeindia #assamflood #everydayindia #everydayeverywhere #floodplain #naturaldisaster #globalwarming #naturalcalamity #displacedfamilies #onassignment #rehabilitation #humanintereststories #storiesfromassam #dailylife #climatechange #climatechangeindia #foodinsecurity #floodrelief #travelstories #Majuli #riverislands #reportagespotlight #instagram #instagramgrant website: www.nishallama.com

Up until about a week ago temperatures during the ‚Äúwinter‚Äù on the Korean peninsula were extremely mild and there were days when the mercury would reach up to 10 degrees Celsius. caption: When I first met Gauran Bhuyan in February 2016, he was making a few boats. His house, just a few meters from the river, was newly constructed after the previous one got eroded away in September 2015 flood. Along with him, many other families lost their agricultural land, their only source of livelihood. Now, without his own farming land, he tills someone else‚Äôs land and gets half the profit. Most of the time, the profit is the rice he cultivates, which is used by his family for consumption throughout the year. Sometimes, all that hard work, too, goes in vain because the floodwater would have damaged the harvest completely. When asked if he was expecting a good return selling the boat, he replied, ‚ÄúI can hardly make a couple of boats since I work alone. And the money I get after selling them is not enough for the family‚Äù. He goes on to add, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have a place to stay when it‚Äôs flooded here. So we take shelter in the boat, which is why we always have one extra for ourselves.‚Äù Displacement due to soil erosion in Majuli is not new. In the last 50 years, Majuli in Assam, one of the largest river islands in the world with human settlement, has lost more than half its land mass. Drastic shrinkage of landmass of the island due to erosion caused by river is posing a serious threat to the very existence of the island. Hundreds of families get displaced every year due to erosion leaving many homeless and affecting their livelihood. 2015 Assam flood affected more than 10 lakh people in the State. The region is possibly India's most flood-prone state and has experienced at least 12 major floods since 1950. #drowningstate #everydayclimatechange #floodsinassam #photojournalism #dailylifeindia #assamflood #everydayeverywhere #everydayindia #floodplain #naturaldisaster #globalwarming #naturalcalamity #floodstory #displacedfamilies #assamflood2016 #onassignment #ngo #rehabilitation #humanintereststories #storiesfromassam #dailylife #climatechangeindia#foodinsecurity #floodrelief #majuli #majuliisland #reportagespotlight #instagram #documentary #capturedmoment website: www.nishallama.com

caption: Photo by @marceloperezdelcarpio .- A rock is glimpsed among the fog at Estrellani lagoon, near Incachaca dam in the area known as "La Cumbre", at 4670 masl (15321 ft) in the outskirts of La Paz, Bolivia. Jan, 2017. The Bolivian capital suffered a severe drought and water shortage since last November, where its principal dams and lagoons reached critical levels. After more than three months of delay, the rain season has just started but in minor intensity than usual, as result of climate change that also has melted almost all the glaciers nearby. / Una roca se vislumbra entre la niebla en la laguna Esteellani, cerca de la represa de Incachaca, en el area conocida como "La Cumbre" (4670 msnm) a las afueras de La Paz, Bolivia, Enero de 2017. La capital sufri√≥ una severa sequ√≠a y racionamiento de agua desde Noviembre, donde sus principales represas y lagunas alcanzaron niveles de agua cr√≠ticos. Las lluvias reci√©n empezaron, pero con menor intensidad de lo usual, luego de casi tres meses de retraso, producto del cambio clim√°tico, que a su vez ha descongelado la mayor√≠a de los glaciares y nevados de la zona. #rock #fog #lagoon #water #level #shortage #cumbre #lacumbre #dam #laguna #nationalpark #cotapata #futureworld #lapaz #Bolivia #Southamerica #horizon #rainseason #documentary #storytelling #blackandwhite #rain #minimal #quiet #landscape #climatechange #bwphotography #everydayclimatechange #iphone6

caption: Photo by Amnon Gutman @gutmanen for #everydayclimatechange. A man fishing in a polluted river at the outskirts of Kurakhovo. E Ukraine. In the Carpathian Region (encompassing Croatia, Hungary, Slovakia, Czech Republic, Poland, Ukraine, Romania and Serbia), heat wave events have become more frequent, longer, more severe and intense over the period 1961 - 2010, in particular in summer in the Hungarian Plain and in Southern Romania. Cold wave frequency, average duration, severity, and intensity over this period, on the other hand, generally decreased in every season except autumn. In this study, a heat wave was defined as at least five consecutive days with daily maximum temperature above the long-term 90th percentile of daily maximum temperatures. Similarly, a cold wave was defined as at least five consecutive days with daily minimum temperatures below the long-term 10th percentile of daily minimum temperatures. The trend analysis shows a general tendency to more frequent, longer, more severe and more intense heat wave events in every season in the entire Carpathian Region. On the other hand, the cold waves show a general tendency to less frequent, shorter, less severe, and less intense events. During 1951-2011, most of the heat wave episodes in Ukraine occurred at stations located in Eastern Ukraine (in this case heat waves being defined as periods of more than 5 consecutive days with daily maximum air temperature ‚â•5 ¬∞C above the mean daily maximum air temperature during June to August for the normal climatic period 1961‚Äì1990). The number of heat wave episodes was highest for almost all stations in the decade 2001‚Äì2010. For many stations, the longest heat wave duration occurred in the first two decades of August 2010, i.e. in the period of the extremely severe heat wave in Western Russia. #climatechange #globalwarming #climatechangeukraine
tags: everydayclimatechange, globalwarming, climatechangeukraine, climatechange

caption: A rock is glimpsed among the fog at Estrellani lagoon, near Incachaca dam in the area known as "La Cumbre", at 4670 masl (15321 ft) in the outskirts of La Paz, Bolivia. Jan, 2017. The Bolivian capital suffered a severe drought and water shortage since last November, where its principal dams and lagoons reached critical levels. After more than three months of delay, the rain season has just started but in minor intensity than usual, as result of climate change that also has melted almost all the glaciers nearby. / Una roca se vislumbra entre la niebla en la laguna Esteellani, cerca de la represa de Incachaca, en el area conocida como "La Cumbre" (4670 msnm) a las afueras de La Paz, Bolivia, Enero de 2017. La capital sufri√≥ una severa sequ√≠a y racionamiento de agua desde Noviembre, donde sus principales represas y lagunas alcanzaron niveles de agua cr√≠ticos. Las lluvias reci√©n empezaron, pero con menor intensidad de lo usual, luego de casi tres meses de retraso, producto del cambio clim√°tico, que a su vez ha descongelado la mayor√≠a de los glaciares y nevados de la zona. #rock #fog #lagoon #water #level #shortage #cumbre #lacumbre #dam #laguna #nationalpark #cotapata #futureworld #lapaz #Bolivia #Southamerica #horizon #rainseason #documentary #storytelling #blackandwhite #rain #minimal #quiet #landscape #climatechange #bwphotography #everydayclimatechange #agenciazur #iphone6
