caption: Kinkakuji, Kyoto. When I was a little boy I saw snow five times per year but now it only snows once a year. There is less chance to see Golden Temple with white roof. This is how I feel about global warming. This scenary may be disappeared in the future. This photo is from my personal project "Going Home". I was born in 1981 in Kyoto, most historic and beautiful city in Japan. But when I was younger I wasn't really interested in Japanese traditional culture and history. I was just dreaming of traveling around the world. In 2005 I left my hometown and started living in different cities, different countries. 10 years later, I decided to photograph about Kyoto to know more about my hometown and to recall my memories of childhood.

Photo by @duniaimaji (Fahreza Ahmad). I wonder what, whom and how? It's hard to expressed. My life's won't be long. Even I see you. My eyes closed veil. Growing in your face. Those eyes could not escape. The effort is still the same. Creep. Sweep. Shone. Black and white are clear. I still remember. Banda #Aceh of #Indonesia. January 2017. #documentary #dailylife #streetphotography #everydayeverywhere #everydayclimatechange #reportagespotlight #1000kata #pewartafotoindonesia

caption: Photo by @estherhorvath published by @nytimes in the article "Earth hits up to record high for 3rd year in a row" On Wednesday, Jan 18th NASA announced that 2016 had broken record for the warmest year on record keeping which began in 1880 by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. This month I am posting images about the Arctic Ocean, raising awareness of this beautiful, fragile and rapidly changes environment. Temperature in the Arctic region increases twice as fast as elsewhere on the planet. Arctic experiences some of the largest changes because of climate change and these changes effect our entire planet. caption: @Regrann from @everydayclimatechange - Guest Post: Photo by Samantha Q. Lawrence @samaqlama for @everydayclimatechange Before 1940, you never would have seen these magical "glacial diamonds" washed up on Iceland's shore. Vatnaj√∂kull glacier was so big that it stretched from the land to meet the edge of the sea. Now, it has receded so dramatically that what we see is a glacier lagoon, a melted pool of the remnants of Vatnaj√∂kull, where huge chunks of ice break off and are swept out to the ocean. It is a sight to behold, but it is not a sight to forget. caption: The Saebin Mandaeans are a minority religious group whose community is concentrated in the Khuzestan province of Iran, as well as in Iraq. Water is a prominent part of their ancient religion. The Mandaeans believe that natural flowing waters are pure, sacred and life-giving. For the Mandaeans of Iran, the Karun River ‚Äì one of Iran‚Äôs biggest ‚Äì is their sacred ritual site. But the Karun is also heavily polluted, and each year the quality of the water worsens. Caption by @sashavonawesome #karun#magnumfoundation #everydayclimatechange #azdarya #Iran #weatherchannel

caption: "I had discontinued school after my father's demise", says Sadaam Khan, 14. He recalls having left school after his third grade. Sadaam has been earning his bread since 5-6 years by scavenging coal in Jharia. When asked if he would like to resume school, he promptly replies with a 'yes'. From "I'll become whatever destiny holds for me" to "I want to become an Engineer" Sadaam's future aspirations reflect his high hopes from life. I asked him if there was anything that he would like to ask from the rest of the world. He replied, "I would ask for the fulfillment of my dream of becoming an Engineer after studying well." This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #tybitto #dailylifeindia #u4humanrights

caption: A man sits by the side of his ailing wife inside a make shift shelter made of bamboo and plastic sheet by a displaced family at Ladanguri village in Dhemaji district of Assam | February 2016. 2015 Assam flood affected more than 10 lakh people in the State ‚Äì Close to 2.5 lakh people in Dhemaji district alone. News reports say that the flood damaged standing crops in over 1.75 lakh hectares, with Dhemaji (66,730 hectares), Dibrugarh (14,000 hectares) and Lakhimpur (13,500 hectares) reporting the maximum damage. The floods that year swallowed up many villages in the district forcing them to stay in these make shift tents for days‚Äô, some, even months. What‚Äôs worse is they lost their fertile agricultural land, their only source of livelihood. Originally agriculturists, many now look for an alternate source of income like fishing, wage labor etc. Floods in Assam is a yearly natural calamity and people seem to have started to live with it. Every year, floodwater causes soil erosion and deposition of silt and sand, thus making the soil infertile. This has also been one of the reasons for many to migrate to other States in the Country looking for jobs. @everydayclimatechange #drowningstate #everydayclimatechange #floodsinassam #photojournalism #dailylifeindia #assamfloods #everydayeverywhere #everydayindia #floodplain #naturaldisaster #globalwarming #naturalcalamity #displacedfamilies #onassignment #floodfury #aftermath #ngo #rehabilitation #humanintereststories #storiesfromassam #dailylife #climatechange #foodinsecurity #disastermanagement #relief #latergram #Photooftheday #reportagespotlight #documentary #instagram Website: buff.ly/2j6mMqA

News reports say that the flood damaged standing crops in over 1.75 lakh hectares, with Dhemaji (66,730 hectares), Dibrugarh (14,000 hectares) and Lakhimpur (13,500 hectares) reporting the maximum damage. The floods that year swallowed up many villages in the district forcing them to stay in these make shift tents for days‚Äô, some, even months. What‚Äôs worse is they lost their fertile agricultural land, their only source of livelihood. Originally agriculturists, many now look for an alternate source of income like fishing, wage labor etc. Floods in Assam is a yearly natural calamity and people seem to have started to live with it. caption: Majuli, Assam | February, 2016 In the last 50 years, Majuli in Assam, one of the largest river islands in the world with human settlement, has lost more than half its land mass. Drastic shrinkage of land mass of the island due to erosion caused by river is posing a serious threat to the very existence of the island. Hundreds of families get displaced every year due to erosion leaving many homeless and affecting their livelihood. 2015 Assam flood affected more than 10 lakh people in the State. The floods that year swallowed up many houses in the river island displacing hundreds of families. Many of them losing their only source of livelihood -- their land. With no alternate source of livelihood, future looked bleak for many of them. This loss made them (who were previously farmers) unemployed, compelling them bound to do informal jobs. The region is possibly India's most flood-prone state and has experienced at least 12 major floods since 1950. It is indeed sad that the rich cultural diversity of the place is yet to be known by others, even worst, is that many may go extinct even before its been explored by the rest of the world. @everydayclimatechange #drowningstate #everydayclimatechange #floodsinassam #photojournalism #dailylifeindia #assamflood #everydayeverywhere #floodplain #naturaldisaster #globalwarming #naturalcalamity #assamflood2015 #displacedfamilies #onassignment #floodfury #aftermath #ngo #rehabilitation #humanintereststories #storiesfromassam #dailylife #climatechange #climatechangeindia #foodinsecurity #floodrelief #travelstories #Majuli #riverislands

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. Sunrise over the Engaruka Basin, Masai and their goats head out looking for pasture in Tanzania's north Rift. This area has always suffered from low rainfall but has now become virtually a man-made desert. A dramatic growth in human and livestock population has lead to Masai communities no longer continuing their traditional nomadic lifestyle which allows pasture to recover from grazing and their areas they inhabit to regenerate. The result is disastrous - overgrazing, further destruction of the environment by cutting trees for firewood and even less rainfall. Now there is no grass root stock left in the soil, even when the rains do come there is nothing in the soil left to grow for any livestock let alone any wildlife that is alive in this beautiful place. The Engaruka Basin is one of the many examples of how human activity becomes a self-perpetuating cause and accelerator of climate change, turning the marginal areas of our planet to uninhabitable. #climatechange #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #aerial #sunrise #Masai #windowtotheworld #ic_landscapes #tanzania #environment #desert #desertification #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #justbackfrom #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #natgeo #reframeclimate #dust #canon #canon5dmarkIII #photooftheday

caption: Scene inside a make shift shelter made of bamboo and plastic sheet by a displaced family at Ladanguri village in Dhemaji district of Assai | Dhemaji, Upper Assam, February 2016. 2015 Assam flood affected more than 10 lakh people in the State ‚Äì Close to 2.5 lakh people in Dhemaji district alone. News reports say that the flood damaged standing crops in over 1.75 lakh hectares, with Dhemaji (66,730 hectares), Dibrugarh (14,000 hectares) and Lakhimpur (13,500 hectares) reporting the maximum damage. The floods that year swallowed up many villages in the district forcing them to stay in these make shift tents for days‚Äô, some, even months. What‚Äôs worse is they lost their fertile agricultural land, their only source of livelihood. This loss made them (who were previously farmers) unemployed, compelling them bound to do informal jobs. Originally agriculturists, many now look for an alternate source of income like fishing, wage labor etc. Floods in Assam is a yearly natural calamity and people seem to have started to live with it. Every year, floodwater causes soil erosion and deposition of silt and sand, thus making the soil infertile. This has also been one of the reasons for many to migrate to other States in the Country looking for jobs. The region is possibly India's most flood-prone state and has experienced at least 12 major floods since 1950. @everydayclimatechange #drowningstate #everydayclimatechange #floodsinassam #photojournalism #dailylifeindia #assamflood #everydayeverywhere #floodplain #naturaldisaster #globalwarming #naturalcalamity #assamflood2015 #displacedfamilies #onassignment #floodfury #aftermath #ngo #rehabilitation #humanintereststories #storiesfromassam #dailylife #climatechange #climatechangeindia #foodinsecurity #disastermanagement #relief #monsoon #actionaid #floodrelief

caption: Climate Change in Bangladesh ~ Local villagers collect safe drinking water at Gabura village in the Satkhera district on 05 February 2010 Bangladesh. Climate Change touches already every corner of the world and every aspect of people‚Äôs lives. As the global temperature increases, its impacts will become even more extreme. The impact of climate change world is already facing food and fuel crises. World Bank and IMF have sounded a larger alarm push 100 million people in low-income countries deeper into poverty. In Bangladesh we are seeing rice-crises firsthand everyday. The long queues on the roadside subsidized rice sale centers are probably an indication of the coming hunger, when 30 million people will face starvation. In Bangladesh natural disasters like SIDR, River Erosion, Drought and Flood mass migration of people from the countryside to the cities. Visions of money, food and a better life, but many of they failed to realize their dreams lured the migrants, and the rural poor became the urban poor. Climate Change is my long-term project where I began to document of marginal condition in my own country of Bangladesh. My investigation finally brought me to a climate refugee in Bangladesh. ¬© Monirul Alam #climatechange#globalwarming#everydayclimatechange#photojournalism#bangladesh#dailylife#erosion#drought#flood#yourshotphotographer#reportagespotlight#opensocietyfoundations#lensculture#longtermproject#documentary#villagerForest#Suburban#Shatkhera#CycloneSidr#safedrinkingwater
tags: safedrinkingwater, longtermproject, bangladesh, cyclonesidr, yourshotphotographer, lensculture, flood, erosion, shatkhera, drought, reportagespotlight, climatechange, dailylife, villagerforest, globalwarming, documentary, everydayclimatechange, suburban, photojournalism, opensocietyfoundations

With Hindi as his favourite subject, Gautam goes to school and studies in fourth grade, presently. Although unable to recall much of his learnings from the subject, he tells that he is strong in the field and can cope with peculiarities like headaches. While appreciating him for his dedication, I asked him about his dream. Aiming high, he said that he would love to join the Police services or become a Doctor or work with BCCL -a subsidiary of Coal India Limited. caption: Here's a photo I made from a @Greenpeace helicopter over Petermann Glacier in remote Northwestern Greenland in 2009. Those are meltpools on the floating tongue of the Glacier, and the black blobs are cryoconite, deposits of rock, soil, soot, and other matter that collects on ice, then melts its way down. I made this image was during Greenpeace campaign to look at how climate change was affecting Greenland's outlet glaciers, before the 2009 Copenhagen climate meeting. Recently this picture ended up being used by @natgeotravel National Geographic Traveller (http://on.natgeo.com/2kautOj) - in an article about travelling to Greenland. However, it's extremely unlikely that even the most-pocketed, resourceful traveller to Greenland would have the chance to stop by Petermann Glacier during their trip. It's 400km north of the most northerly village in Greenland, Qaanaaq - and Qaanaaq itself is extremely remote, even by Greenland's standards, getting a couple of Air Greenland flights stopping by twice a week. There are few roads in Greenland, none to Qaanaaq and certainly none to Petermann Glacier! Still, if you want to go, good luck to you! #Greenland #Arctic #nature #igersarctic #igersgreenland #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #nature #landscape #nationalgeographic #natgeo #natgeotravel
tags: greenland, landscape, everydayclimatechange, natgeo, nature, igersgreenland, natgeotravel, igersarctic, arctic, nationalgeographic, climatechange

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: Solar panels in the Zanskar Valley, India. These panels have brought much needed electricity to some of the most remote communities on the planet. In a government partnership with local communities, the state put forth the initial investment for the panels and then handed over the responsibility of maintenance to the communities in the valley. Influential economist E.F Schumacher coined the idea of ‚Äòappropriate technology‚Äô in 1973. His idea of appropriate technology hinged on the notion where the context of the situation determined what technology was to be used. This would do away with the ‚Äòone size fits all approach‚Äô. In the case of electricity within the Indian Himalayan region it is a prime example of this idea in play. The region receives 300+ days per year of sunshine and typically homes do not require vast amounts of energy. The solar panels allow the lighting of homes at night, charging mobile phones, and increasingly watching TV. Small-scale carbon emissions free solar plants, as pictured, are a perfect source for these activities in remote parts of the world. --- . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #india #himalayas #asia #southasia #climatechangeisreal
tags: climatechange, southasia, globalwarming, everydayclimatechange, climatechangeisreal, himalayas, asia, repost, india

caption: A family stands on flooded Agricultural land in Lower Assam. Since a vast majority of families in Rural Assam depend on agriculture for livelihood, it‚Äôs customary for families to work together during cultivation time. For instance, the young girl in the picture had been assisting her parents in farming after school for months. ‚ÄúAll of us in the family work together. We don‚Äôt have money to engage outside laborers,‚Äù said the father. He adds, ‚ÄúAfter spending on pesticides and other fertilizers, and irrigation charges, there is little money we are left with. We don‚Äôt even have our own tractors, which we get under share contract. Sometimes, we even have to get that on rent.‚Äù When the floods hit the State in August last year, their main concern was about repaying the debt. When I think about it, I feel the annual natural calamity must have made them strong enough to cope with the situation but little has been done to rehabilitate them. Last year when I visited some of these villages, floods had arrived just before the harvest. Many villagers like them lost almost 90% of their cultivation to flood. And there was no way they could repay the money they had borrowed from money lenders. Lack of proper irrigation facilities force farmers, especially those living in low lying area, to cultivate during monsoon. And floods being a yearly affair in Assam, little can be done to stop these areas from flooding. Experts say, if Government could provide with a better irrigation system, winter rice crop could be raised in many of these low lying area that remain flooded during the rainy season otherwise. Also, as part of the rehabilitation process, if specific skill program could be introduced, they could perhaps work else where during the monsoon. #drowningstate #everydayclimatechange #floodsinassam #photojournalism #dailylifeindia #assamflood #everydayeverywhere #floodplain #naturaldisaster #naturalcalamity #assam #onassignment #floodfury #aftermath #ngo #rehabilitation #humanintereststories #storiesfromassam #dailylife #climatechange #climatechangeindia #foodinsecurity #disastermanagement #relief #monsoon #actionaid
tags: actionaid, disastermanagement, floodsinassam, photojournalism, foodinsecurity, floodplain, aftermath, monsoon, climatechangeindia, assam, storiesfromassam, onassignment, humanintereststories, naturaldisaster, dailylifeindia, floodfury, rehabilitation, climatechange, relief, naturalcalamity, everydayclimatechange, assamflood, everydayeverywhere, dailylife, drowningstate, ngo

caption: Repost @leonardodicaprio: "#Regram #RG @everydayclimatechange: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. This image of an Amhara boy and his horse in barren fields that should be full of wheat and teff was taken in Wollo 600kms north of Ethiopia's capital Addis in 2008 when the entire region suffered major drought as both the years' rains failed. Ethiopia continues to face the same issues of failed rains and are currently suffering the worst drought in 30 years exacerbated by the El Ni√±o phenomenon. A recent climate change study in the Horn of Africa finds that the land is drying out at an unusually fast pace as a result of soaring greenhouse gas emissions. Associate professor at the University of Arizona and lead author of the study Jessica Tierney said in a statement in the IBTimes, "Given the scale of threats in Africa and across the world, studying the hyper-local impacts of climate change will be critical to helping communities adapt and prepare". In a country where more than eight in ten people depend on rain-fed agriculture, the drought is having a significant impact and the Ethiopian government estimates that more than 9 million people will need humanitarian assistance in 2016. #climatechange #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #ethiopia #documentary #photojournalism #climate #visualsoflife #ethiopia #GlobalClimateChange2015 #News #environment #famine"

caption: Bees are so important to our environment. Help save them by planting some bee-friendly flowers in your yard! Via @planet_bee

Climate Change is Real¬Æ #Repost @leonardodicaprio with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª #Regram #RG @everydayclimatechange: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. Empusel, the name the Maasai call the salty, dusty plains and from which the word ‚ÄòAmboseli‚Äô is derived, is about to relish in the first of the rains. The Amboseli basin, a semi-arid, open savannah area of southern Kenya, has experienced extensive changes in habitat since the early 1960's with daily temperatures increasing dramatically at a greater rate than that attributed to global warming. Amboseli has experienced an extensive loss of the trees due to a rising water table and the related rise of the salt layer in the soil, to grazing patterns, to a natural ageing of the woodlands, and to damage from an increasingly resident elephant population now unable to move the distances they used to due to growing human population around the reserve. The temperature changes here are now causing the landscape changes, and to confuse matters the temperature pattern may itself have been caused by the landscape changes. The climate change discussion is as dynamic and as important as ever. #climatechange #globalwarming #ic_landscapes #travel #natgeohub @natgeotravel #desertification #dust #everydayclimatechange #drought #deforestation #trees #colorcrush #horizon #canon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkiii #ccr_2017

caption: Before 1940, you never would have seen these magical "glacial diamonds" washed up on Iceland's shore. Vatnaj√∂kull glacier was so big that it stretched from the land to meet the edge of the sea. Now, it has receded so dramatically that what we see is a glacier lagoon, a melted pool of the remnants of Vatnaj√∂kull, where huge chunks of ice break off and are swept out to the ocean. It is a sight to behold, but it is not a sight to forget. If we don't make an effort to stop climate change then Vatnaj√∂kull will be gone forever. #iceland #brei√∞amerkurj√∂kull #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #globalwarming #glacier #risingseas #globalclimatechange #climate #nature #diamondbeach #vatnaj√∂kull #j√∂kuls√°rl√≥n #glacierlagoon #landscape #cleanenergy #environment #conservation #ice #beforetheflood #mystopover #takeaction #sonya6300

caption: Climate Change in Bangladesh ~ A dead cow lie near a Pousher river at Patharghata on 21 November 2007 Borguna, Bangladesh. Cyclone Sidr reached a top speed of almost 240km per hour. The coastal area was most affected. The countrys southern costal areas and southwest was devastated. Thousands were killed. Climate Change touches already every corner of the world and every aspect of people‚Äôs lives. As the global temperature increases, its impacts will become even more extreme. The impact of climate change world is already facing food and fuel crises. World Bank and IMF have sounded a larger alarm push 100 million people in low-income countries deeper into poverty. In Bangladesh we are seeing rice-crises firsthand everyday. The long queues on the roadside subsidized rice sale centers are probably an indication of the coming hunger, when 30 million people will face starvation. In Bangladesh natural disasters like SIDR, River Erosion, Drought and Flood mass migration of people from the countryside to the cities. Visions of money, food and a better life, but many of they failed to realize their dreams lured the migrants, and the rural poor became the urban poor. Climate Change is my long-term project where I began to document of marginal condition in my own country of Bangladesh. My investigation finally brought me to a climate refugee in Bangladesh. ¬© Monirul Alam #climatechange#globalwarming#everydayclimatechange#photojournalism#climate#bangladesh#worker#migrant#dailylife#erosion#drought#flood#yourshotphotographer#reportagespotlight#opensocietyfoundations#lensculture#editorial#longtermproject#documentary#photoessay#animals#Forest#Suburban#Borguna#DeadAnimal#CycloneSidr

caption: Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: Solar panels in the Zanskar Valley, India. These panels have brought much needed electricity to some of the most remote communities on the planet. In a government partnership with local communities, the state put forth the initial investment for the panels and then handed over the responsibility of maintenance to the communities in the valley. Influential economist E.F Schumacher coined the idea of ‚Äòappropriate technology‚Äô in 1973. His idea of appropriate technology hinged on the notion where the context of the situation determined what technology was to be used. This would do away with the ‚Äòone size fits all approach‚Äô. In the case of electricity within the Indian Himalayan region it is a prime example of this idea in play. The region receives 300+ days per year of sunshine and typically homes do not require vast amounts of energy. The solar panels allow the lighting of homes at night, charging mobile phones, and increasingly watching TV. Small-scale carbon emissions free solar plants, as pictured, are a perfect source for these activities in remote parts of the world. --- . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #india #himalayas #asia #southasia #climatechangeisreal
tags: asia, southasia, everydayclimatechange, climatechange, india, globalwarming, himalayas, climatechangeisreal

caption: #Regram #RG @everydayclimatechange: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. This image of an Amhara boy and his horse in barren fields that should be full of wheat and teff was taken in Wollo 600kms north of Ethiopia's capital Addis in 2008 when the entire region suffered major drought as both the years' rains failed. Ethiopia continues to face the same issues of failed rains and are currently suffering the worst drought in 30 years exacerbated by the El Ni√±o phenomenon. A recent climate change study in the Horn of Africa finds that the land is drying out at an unusually fast pace as a result of soaring greenhouse gas emissions. Associate professor at the University of Arizona and lead author of the study Jessica Tierney said in a statement in the IBTimes, "Given the scale of threats in Africa and across the world, studying the hyper-local impacts of climate change will be critical to helping communities adapt and prepare". In a country where more than eight in ten people depend on rain-fed agriculture, the drought is having a significant impact on the people of Ethiopia. #climatechange #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #ethiopia #documentary #photojournalism #climate #visualsoflife #ethiopia #GlobalClimate#News #environment #famine #earth #environmentalist

caption: Suresh Mahto talks about his farm and how his family has been into farming since the last 100 years in #Ranchi, #Jharkhand, #India. Of late, Mahto has been worried owing to the numerous brick kilns that have come up in the vicinity of his farm. Today, he says, the level air of pollution has risen due to these kilns and because of the deterioration in air quality, the yield and the quality of the produce has been affected, but not in a very significant way. At the same time, he is worried about the what the future holds for farmers like him if things continue this way. #EverydayEverywhere #EverydayClimateChange #EverydayIndia #DailyLife #Photojournalism #ReportageSpotlight #IndiaPhotoProject #OnePlusLife

caption: Sagebrush is an icon of life in the west. However, North America's sagebrush ecosystem has declined from a historical 153 million acres to 106 million acres today. Sagebrush habitat in the Great Basin is threatened from many angles... so are bison, sage grouse, pronghorn, and many other animals who depend on it. Sagebrush scrub is threatened by temperature increase, land use change, fragmentation due to urbanization, disease, increased fire frequency, cheatgrass invasion, and woodland expansion. We love living in mountain towns like Jackson, WY at the base of the Grand Tetons. However, our civilization impacting these invaluable ecosystems more rapidly, and in more ways than we realize. #everydayclimatechange #grandtetons #findyourpark #protectourwinters #sagebrush #bison #sagegrouse #outdoors #nature #mountains #conservation #keepitwild #natgeowild #wildlifephotography #canon #natgeoyourshot

caption: @Regrann from @thephotosociety - Photo: @rubensalgadoescudero // Tires from mining vehicles lay on the shore of a beach in Palomina, Colombia. Coal mining picked up steam, transforming the Colombian countryside just as it did England‚Äôs green and pleasant lands all those years ago, as huge mines dig deep into the heart of the Andean foothills and outskirts of the Amazon basin to get at the coal that provides Colombia with significant export earnings from China and the EU, among other destinations. The environmental damage that this industry causes is monstrous, both at the local level through deforestation and pollution, and at the global level by releasing huge amounts of greenhouse gases and particles into the atmosphere, contributing to global warming and climate change. However, given the spread of Colombia‚Äôs many indigenous and Afro-Colombian communities across rural areas, the fallout from mining often has a human face as well, as entire villages are routinely forced from their land, or at the very least have to live with polluted surroundings and loss of natural habitat that is crucial to their land-based way of life. #Colombia #mining #trucks #beach #paradise #shore #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #latinamerica #everydaylatinamerica #tires #coal #fossilfuels #jungle #amazon #Southamerica #sudamerica #latinoamerica #chile #beautiful #insta_chile #ig_chile #chilegram

La reserva colinda en su l√≠mite norte, con el cerco fronterizo en el tramo entre Sonoyta y San Luis R√≠o Colorado, mismo que interrumpe las rutas naturales de #migraci√≥n de las especies. Por la composici√≥n de su terreno, en 1967 el sector fue utilizado en pruebas de la #NASA para las misiones #Apolo. caption: Regram from @everydayclimatechange - Photo by Vlad Sokhin @lens_pacific for @everydayclimatechange Nathan Tom, 32, holds a scull of musk ox near his house in Newtok village, Alaska. Nathan's house will be the first to disappear due coastal erosion. Nathan says that every year the villagers put pegs into the ground several dozen meters from the cliff. Almost every year the pegs collapse into the ground due to erosion. This year the peg was hammered in Nathan's backyard. He says: 'A couple years from now, I will have to leave this house. It's good that our village has already started relocating to a new place where we won't have these problems.' Surrounded by water, Newtok village is under imminent threat from climate change. Permafrost thaw, regular floods and coastal erosion make it dangerous for people of Newtok to remain there. It is estimated that in the next ten years nearly a 1/3 of the village's area will become uninhabitable due to erosion. #Alaska #Newtok #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #unitedstates #usa #America #globalwarming #climatechangeisreal @panospictures -

caption: Babu (Changed name),6, poses for a portrait in Jharia, Jharkhand. I first met Babu in 2014, a 3-year-old toddler then, whose face was covered with black dust blowing out of the coal burning just a few metres away from him. It was very scary to see him sitting and playing so close to the fire all alone, so I moved him away from it. Seeing toddlers and young children around the burning coal is a very common scene, but, mostly there is an adult around, so I was a little surprised to see Babu sitting alone. Hence, I asked the people around about the whereabouts of his parents. I was informed that Babu had lost his parents in an accident, and is being raised by his grand parents. I have been meeting Babu every time I go back to Jharia. My eyes fill with tears of joy every time I see him, but it also breaks my heart to see a toddler turning into a man, seeing him missing out on being a child. It's heartbreaking to watch him carry chunks of scavenged coal, and not being given a chance to study, play and have a childhood. This year I will be sharing stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #January2017 #u4humanrights
tags: people, u4humanrights, landscape, asia, natgeoearthday, pollution, india, everydayeverywhere, everydayclimatechange, everydayindia, fire, life, nature, reportagespotlight, climatechange, january2017

caption: @ravimishraindia #thevisualactivist Salman (10) poses for a portrait in Jharia, Jharkhand. I dream of becoming an engineer and help my family by getting a Job where I can earn more then 100 - 120 RS (approx 2 USD), I get very tired because we start walking (working) at around 4 A.M everyday, and walk (work) till late in the afternoon. The scavengers around this region start their day long before the sun rises in the sky, a big group of scavengers, especially women and young children between the age group of 8 to 15, begin the first of countless treks down a steep and narrow switchback into the open pit mine to scavenge chunks of coal, which they carry back to the surface in baskets balanced atop their heads. This year I will be sharing some of my favourite stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #January2017 #u4humanrights

caption: "Peace is not merely a distant goal that we seek, but a means by which we arrive at that goal." - Martin Luther king, Jr.

It was almost the middle night of march 14, 2011. the day was long and difficult for more than 40 families that walked at a road side. the night would be absolutely black not to be for the red and blue sparkling of a patrol that chosen them. they walked with the cansancio to cuestas for them urged to arrive to a small canyon called the union, where they were to live the next five years. Bbehind their home in the community los guajes de ayala, in the municipality of coyuca de catal√°n. they left everything to save their life, but the fear that forced them to leave. they left their houses, their belongings, their forests. they were obliged by the organized crime, which seemed that these families would storm to traffic with the wood. in particular, the criminals had in the watch to don ruben santana, who was a leader of the communers and who attempted to face the tala montes de los c√°rteles. true that tried it. rub√©n santana, complained complaints and complaints before diverse defense agencies and state authorities, but nothing served. was found in the population when 28 families had abandoned their lands under the threat of organized crime. he resisted until he was killed. on february 15, 2011, 20 armed men came out of their life. A month after the community understand that the threats were seriously, that may have been better. and so, were advanced as the night on the ways of the costa chica de guerrero that march 14, 2011. #everydayclimatechange

caption: A Tale of Bleeding Earth üåø part 19 üåø #DidYouKnow üëâ üå¥Your #Selfies Are Melting The #Polar Ice Caps? Where the battery come from? Does your #mobile uses a #renewable charging system or #fossilfuel based? Just asking! #DidYouKnow üëâ üå¥Over 17 million #selfies are now uploaded to social media each week as of January 2014. Whilst they may not all be selfies, we upload an astonishing 1.8 billion photos a day to various spots on the internet. #DidYouKnow üëâ üå¥ Every Google search generates 0.2g of #carbondioxide, whereas watching #YouTube for 10 minutes generates about 1g. #DidYouKnow üëâüå¥ The average #Facebook user generates the equivalent of a carbon footprint of coffee annually (269g) through Facebook usage, and using Gmail for a year generates about 1kg a user. #DidYouKnow üëâ üå¥#Google has only recently started to publicly announce its carbon footprint data. In 2013, Google‚Äôs #carbon #footprint was 1,766,014 tonnes of carbon dioxide. #DidYouKnow üëâ üå¥ #Turtles are dying of #plastic #straws. The straw goes into the nose leading to death of the turtle. So, #drinkfromglass . @leonardodicaprio #actor #environmentalist #leosavestheplanet #globalwarming #carbonkills #selfieleavescarbonfootprints #carbonkills #ecofriendly #everydayclimatechange #ecofriendly #ecologicalimbalance

caption: Climate Change in Bangladesh ~ Local village people in search to Mahamud body after a man-eating tiger killed him in Sundarban at Shatkhera on 02 June, 2010. Village people are threatened by tigers when they have to collect wood in the forrest. Climate Change touches already every corner of the world and every aspect of people‚Äôs lives. As the global temperature increases, its impacts will become even more extreme. The impact of climate change world is already facing food and fuel crises. World Bank and IMF have sounded a larger alarm push 100 million people in low-income countries deeper into poverty. In Bangladesh we are seeing rice-crises firsthand everyday. The long queues on the roadside subsidized rice sale centers are probably an indication of the coming hunger, when 30 million people will face starvation. In Bangladesh natural disasters like SIDR, River Erosion, Drought and Flood mass migration of people from the countryside to the cities. Visions of money, food and a better life, but many of they failed to realize their dreams lured the migrants, and the rural poor became the urban poor. Climate Change is my long-term project where I began to document of marginal condition in my own country of Bangladesh. My investigation finally brought me to a climate refugee in Bangladesh. ¬© Monirul Alam #climatechange#globalwarming#everydayclimatechange#photojournalism#climate#bangladesh#worker#migrant#dailylife#erosion#drought#flood#yourshotphotographer#reportagespotlight#opensocietyfoundations#lensculture#editorial#dailylife#everydaylife#longtermproject#documentary#newsphotograohy#image#photoessay#animals#dryland#villager#body#Forest#Suburban#Shatkhera

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. View from Gilmans‚Äô Point 5685m (18,650ft) on the rim edge of Kibo, Kilimanjaro‚Äôs highest peak, across The Saddle, a 5km (3.1mi) wide high alpine semi-desert that resembles a lunar landscape, to Mawenzi, Kilimanjaro‚Äôs second peak. Over 150 years ago, when the first European visitors documented Kilimanjaro‚Äôs appearance, the volcano‚Äôs cone was covered with a thick crust of ice. There is not trace of snow, what was once a solid ice climb is now a scree and rock climb with the ice that forms over the very cold nights quickly disappearing as the sun rises. The only reminder that the mountain was once covered with an enormous snowcap are two remaining areas of glaciers, the Southern Icefields facing Tanzania and the Northern Icefields towards Kenya, both just slivers of white. According to scientists working on Kilimanjaro, the glaciers are at least 11,700 years old but 90% of the ice has since vanished. The loss of this ice predates the start of human-caused climate change by several decades but the rate of glacier shrinkage has doubled since the 1970s ‚Äî when human caused climate change kicked in. #climatechange #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #kilimanjaro #tanzania #environment #desert #desertification #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #justbackfrom #glaciers #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #reframeclimate #dust #canon #ic_landscapes #canon5dmarkIII #photooftheday

caption: #Repost @leonardodicaprio with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª #Regram #RG @everydayclimatechange: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. Empusel, the name the Maasai call the salty, dusty plains and from which the word ‚ÄòAmboseli‚Äô is derived, is about to relish in the first of the rains. The Amboseli basin, a semi-arid, open savannah area of southern Kenya, has experienced extensive changes in habitat since the early 1960's with daily temperatures increasing dramatically at a greater rate than that attributed to global warming. Amboseli has experienced an extensive loss of the trees due to a rising water table and the related rise of the salt layer in the soil, to grazing patterns, to a natural ageing of the woodlands, and to damage from an increasingly resident elephant population now unable to move the distances they used to due to growing human population around the reserve. The temperature changes here are now causing the landscape changes, and to confuse matters the temperature pattern may itself have been caused by the landscape changes. The climate change discussion is as dynamic and as important as ever. #climatechange #globalwarming #ic_landscapes #travel #natgeohub @natgeotravel #desertification #dust #everydayclimatechange #drought #deforestation #trees #colorcrush #horizon #canon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkiii

caption: A Tale of Bleeding Earth üåøpart 13üåø üåª #DidYouKnow üëâüåª As per research of Paul Williams, an atmospheric #scientist at #University of #Reading, due to warm air, the planes will take extra fuel to take off. Government will put tighter restrictions on weight and increase the fares to meet the operational cost. Due to climate change,there will be annual delay of 2000 hours in flight which will burn 7.2 million gallons of jet fuel and incur $22 million of operational expenditure. It will emit 70 million kg of #carbondioxide in the air which is equal to the annual emission of 7100 British homes. üåª#DidYouKnowüëâüåª Every individual need to plant 60 trees per year to recover the loss in 30 years. caption: Solar panels in the Zanskar Valley, India. These panels have brought much needed electricity to some of the most remote communities on the planet. In a government partnership with local communities, the state put forth the initial investment for the panels and then handed over the responsibility of maintenance to the communities in the valley. Influential economist E.F Schumacher coined the idea of ‚Äòappropriate technology‚Äô in 1973. His idea of appropriate technology hinged on the notion where the context of the situation determined what technology was to be used. This would do away with the ‚Äòone size fits all approach‚Äô. In the case of electricity within the Indian Himalayan region it is a prime example of this idea in play. The region receives 300+ days per year of sunshine and typically homes do not require vast amounts of energy. The solar panels allow the lighting of homes at night, charging mobile phones, and increasingly watching TV. Small-scale carbon emissions free solar plants, as pictured, are a perfect source for these activities in remote parts of the world. --- . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #india #himalayas #asia #southasia #climatechangeisreal
tags: india, climatechangeisreal, globalwarming, asia, southasia, himalayas, everydayclimatechange, climatechange

caption: A raven takes off from Gilmans‚Äô Point 5685m (18,650ft) on the rim edge of Kibo, Kilimanjaro‚Äôs highest peak, across The Saddle, a 5km (3.1mi) wide high alpine semi-desert that resembles a lunar landscape, to Mawenzi, Kilimanjaro‚Äôs second peak. Over 150 years ago, when the first European visitors documented Kilimanjaro‚Äôs appearance, the volcano‚Äôs cone was covered with a thick crust of ice. There is not trace of snow, what was once a solid ice climb is now a scree and rock climb with the ice that forms over the very cold nights quickly disappearing as the sun rises. The only reminder that the mountain was once covered with an enormous snowcap are two remaining areas of glaciers, the Southern Icefields facing Tanzania and the Northern Icefields towards Kenya, both just slivers of white. According to scientists working on Kilimanjaro, the glaciers are at least 11,700 years old but 90% of the ice has since vanished. The loss of this ice predates the start of human-caused climate change by several decades but the rate of glacier shrinkage has doubled since the 1970s ‚Äî when human caused climate change kicked in. #climatechange #globalwarming @everydayclimatechange #everydayclimatechange #documentary #photojournalism #climate #kilimanjaro #tanzania #environment #desert #desertification #toldwithexposure #visualsoflife #followmetoo #justbackfrom #glaciers #climatechangeisreal @natgeo #reframeclimate #dust #mycanon #ic_landscapes #canon5dmarkIII #picoftheday
tags: reframeclimate, climatechangeisreal, glaciers, canon5dmarkiii, desert, dust, visualsoflife, ic_landscapes, kilimanjaro, toldwithexposure, photojournalism, climate, followmetoo, mycanon, environment, tanzania, desertification, justbackfrom, globalwarming, documentary, picoftheday, everydayclimatechange, climatechange

caption: Climate Change in Bangladesh ~ Maharjan searching a grazing ground to feed goats at the Keranigonj on 22 April 2009 Bangladesh. Climate Change touches already every corner of the world and every aspect of people‚Äôs lives. As the global temperature increases, its impacts will become even more extreme. The impact of climate change world is already facing food and fuel crises. World Bank and IMF have sounded a larger alarm push 100 million people in low-income countries deeper into poverty. In Bangladesh we are seeing rice-crises firsthand everyday. The long queues on the roadside subsidized rice sale centers are probably an indication of the coming hunger, when 30 million people will face starvation. In Bangladesh natural disasters like SIDR, River Erosion, Drought and Flood mass migration of people from the countryside to the cities. Visions of money, food and a better life, but many of they failed to realize their dreams lured the migrants, and the rural poor became the urban poor. Climate Change is my long-term project where I began to document of marginal condition in my own country of Bangladesh. My investigation finally brought me to a climate refugee in Bangladesh. ¬© Monirul Alam Dhaka, Bangladesh ¬© #MonirulAlam / ALL RIGHTS RESERVED #climatechange#globalwarming#everydayclimatechange#photojournalism#climate#bangladesh#worker#migrant#dailylife#erosion#drought#flood#yourshotphotographer#reportagespotlight#opensocietyfoundations#lensculture#editorial#dailylife#everydaylife#longtermproject#documentary#newsphotograohy#image#photoessay#animals#dryland#villager#woman#goats

caption: Salman (10) poses for a portrait in Jharia, Jharkhand. I dream of becoming an engineer and help my family by getting a Job where I can earn more then 100 - 120 RS (approx 2 USD), I get very tired because we start walking (working) at around 4 A.M everyday, and walk (work) till late in the afternoon. The scavengers around this region start their day long before the sun rises in the sky, a big group of scavengers, especially women and young children between the age group of 8 to 15, begin the first of countless treks down a steep and narrow switchback into the open pit mine to scavenge chunks of coal, which they carry back to the surface in baskets balanced atop their heads. This year I will be sharing some of my favourite stories that I have covered in Jharia for the past 8 years. #Everydayindia #everydayclimatechange #everydayeverywhere #people #life #climatechange #pollution #fire #nature #India #Asia #reportagespotlight #landscape #NatgeoEarthDay #January2017

caption: Ok so I had to be a bit inventive today because the weather has been really ordinary... these alien looking things are actually a weed called a Scotch Thistle... like every weed that did not exist here before whitefellas showed up it is positively lethal to handle due to its spikes.. there are a lot of these across cleared agricultural country right across the continent of Australia.... and as more of the fragile soils are eroded due to over grazing and drought these weeds seem to spring up miraculously of their own accord please note the fly on one of the thorns on the right... #photooftheday #natgeoyourshot #instagood #landscape #blackandwhitephoto #reportage #photojournalism #everydayclimatechange

caption: A Tale of Bleeding Earth üåø part 9üåø üåª#DidYouKnowüëâ üåª In less than two centuries of industrial revolution, the man has managed to ruin Earth pretty well,which was a beautiful result of millions of years or evolution. Now, time has come to act, to repair what can be repaired to prepare the future, so that humanity exists. Today, our #planet faces a major ecological imbalance because it doesn't have any longer its own natural means to compensate men's ecological print. The #erosion of #soil, #animals and #nature has reached a level unique in life's history on Earth. Destructions of #forests take such proportion that, every single year, more than twelve million hectares disappear, which is the equivalent of four times the total surface of #Belgium. No one can ignore this implacable fact: the #Earth has reached a point of vulnerability that now the damage is visible to the naked eye. We have a duty of solidarity towards the next generations. We have to accept our heavy responsibility in the current situation. We have no right to leave to our children as unique heritage the administration of our mistakes and give them a life sentence for a crime they have not committed. If we don't take immediate actions, we will face major losses in the coming years. @leonardodicaprio @perfectlywinslet #leosavestheplanet #leonardodicaprio #katewinslet #climatechangeeveryday #globalwarming #savetree #saveearth #carbonkills #pollutionfree #pollution #saveocean #article #blog #nature #carbonno #everydayclimatechange
tags: blog, everydayclimatechange, saveearth, planet, carbonno, carbonkills, animals, savetree, katewinslet, pollutionfree, globalwarming, earth, belgium, saveocean, forests, leonardodicaprio, article, didyouknowüëâ, soil, pollution, climatechangeeveryday, nature, leosavestheplanet, erosion

caption: Photo by @estherhorvath This month I am posting images about the Arctic Ocean, raising awareness of this beautiful, fragile and rapidly changes environment. 2016 was the hottest year ever recorded. caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Recent news of the giant crack in the Larsen C ice shelf is yet more distressing confirmation of what global warming is doing to our planet. https://goo.gl/9b6DL2 Very shortly an iceberg the size of Delaware (for the non-U.S. people, that‚Äôs about 6500 square kilometers) will break away from Antarctica and float into the Southern Oceans. The more devastating long-term effect of this event will be that it will likely hasten the demise of the glacial ice still on land behind the shelves. In 2007, I (@danielbeltraphoto) was fortunate enough to photograph icebergs in the Ross Sea of the Southern Oceans, as seen in this photo in which placid waters reveal the size of an iceberg beneath the surface. We all need to take actions in our lives to limit global warming, as future generations will be better off if scenes like this are not repeated. #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #antarctica #rosssea #iceberg #southernoceans #aerial
tags: everydayclimatechange, southernoceans, rosssea, climatechange, antarctica, aerial, repost, iceberg, globalwarming

caption: This is what downtown Pristina looks like right now. On clear days, one can see the hills in the distance, but now they are blanketed in a thick haze of smog. Pristina's Air Quality Index is currently 402, which is considered hazardous. It's also the most polluted city out of 65 cities around the world that are monitored by Air Visual, which provides major city air pollution rankings based on real-time measured data. Pristina, with a small population of around 200,000, is an exception because it frequently has poor air quality. A few kilometers away from Pristina are Kosovo's two lignite-fired thermal power plants. During the winter, it is an everyday reality to smell and breath the toxic fumes from the burning coal used to heat homes and buildings.‚Äã The Kosovo government is planning to build ‚Äãa third lignite coal power plant ‚Äãto replace and refurbish the aging coal plants but local and international environmental ‚Äãand advocacy ‚Äãgroups want to transform Kosovo into a clean energy leader‚Äã and not rely on coal as its sole energy source. #kosovo #pristina #prishtina #europe #everydayclimatechange @everydayclimatechange ‚Äã #photojournalism #environment #climatechange #balkans #cleanenergy #kosovocoal‚Äã ‚Äã#airpollution #pollution #AJEinpictures

caption: Climate Change in Bangladesh ~ A group of people makeshift their broken house during the river erosion at Munshigonj on 15 July 2005. Climate Change touches already every corner of the world and every aspect of people‚Äôs lives. As the global temperature increases, its impacts will become even more extreme. The impact of climate change world is already facing food and fuel crises. World Bank and IMF have sounded a larger alarm push 100 million people in low-income countries deeper into poverty. In Bangladesh we are seeing rice-crises firsthand everyday. The long queues on the roadside subsidized rice sale centers are probably an indication of the coming hunger, when 30 million people will face starvation. In Bangladesh natural disasters like SIDR, River Erosion, Drought and Flood mass migration of people from the countryside to the cities. Visions of money, food and a better life, but many of they failed to realize their dreams lured the migrants, and the rural poor became the urban poor. Climate Change is my long-term project where I began to document of marginal condition in my own country of Bangladesh. My investigation finally brought me to a climate refugee in Bangladesh. ¬© Monirul Alam Dhaka, Bangladesh ¬© #MonirulAlam / ALL RIGHTS RESERVED #climatechange#globalwarming#everydayclimatechange#photojournalism#climate#bangladesh#worker#migrant#dailylife#erosion#drought#flood#yourshotphotographer#reportagespotlight#opensocietyfoundations#lensculture#editorial#dailylife#everydaylife#longtermproject#documentary#newsphotograohy#image#photoessay

caption: Recent news of the giant crack in the Larsen C ice shelf is yet more distressing confirmation of what global warming is doing to our planet. https://goo.gl/9b6DL2 Very shortly an iceberg the size of Delaware (for the non-U.S. people, that‚Äôs about 6500 square kilometers) will break away from Antarctica and float into the Southern Oceans. The more devastating long-term effect of this event will be that it will likely hasten the demise of the glacial ice still on land behind the shelves. In 2007, I (@danielbeltraphoto) was fortunate enough to photograph icebergs in the Ross Sea of the Southern Oceans, as seen in this photo in which placid waters reveal the size of an iceberg beneath the surface. We all need to take actions in our lives to limit global warming, as future generations will be better off if scenes like this are not repeated. #globalwarming #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #antarctica #rosssea #iceberg #southernoceans #aerial
tags: globalwarming, iceberg, everydayclimatechange, antarctica, aerial, southernoceans, climatechange, rosssea

caption: More than 630 companies and investors have called on Donald Trump and the Republican-dominated Congress to continue the move to a low-carbon economy, warning that failing to do so would ‚Äúput American prosperity at risk‚Äù. The US President-elect has talked about scrapping the United States‚Äô international commitments to tackle global warming, such as the Paris Agreement, dismissed climate change as a hoax, and appointed a string of climate science deniers to senior positions in his administration. His election has been described as a ‚Äúvery big challenge‚Äù to the world‚Äôs efforts to address the problem by UK Climate Change Minister Nick Hurd. In a joint statement, leading companies, such as Johnson & Johnson, General Mills, Kellogg‚Äôs, General Mills, Hewlett Packard Enterprise and Unilever, appealed to Mr Trump to reconsider his apparent views. ‚ÄúWe want the US economy to be energy efficient and powered by low-carbon energy,‚Äù they said. ‚ÄúCost-effective and innovative solutions can help us achieve these objectives. Failure to build a low-carbon economy puts American prosperity at risk. ‚ÄúBut the right action now will create jobs and boost US competitiveness.‚Äù More than 530 companies, which collectively have revenues amounting to nearly $1.15 trillion (about ¬£950bn) a year and employ about 1.8 million people, signed the statement. The 100 investors include the New York State Common Retirement Fund, the California State Teachers Retirement System and other firms that manage assets worth more than $2 trillion.

caption: I came across this biomass power plant, run by a Spanish renewables firm called Iberdrola, in the highest reaches of my road to Barcelona. Reasoning that the biomass they burn is mostly composed of carbon that was recently CO2, the EU has designated wood pellet power plants as zero-carbon energy sources. But the reality is not so simple. Ongoing research is starting to hint that logging may increase carbon emissions from peaty forest soils, and there is growing concern among experts that encouraging wood-fired power plants could lead to deforestation in areas where regulations and enforcement are lax (for more on this topic, see this great Science article) During low points in its domestic energy output, Spain imports energy from nuclear-rich France. With recent instability in the politics of nuclear energy in France, the Spanish government has been searching for ways of increasing its energy independence and diversifying its sources of domestic and imported energy. For countries like Spain, renewables represent a triple opportunity: becoming energy independent, fostering new domestic industries, and mitigating the worst effects of climate change. But it‚Äôs important to remember that with the increasing importance of sustainable and low-emissions technologies to world markets, that not every technology stamped with the word renewable can deliver on its promises, and that even those who hope to help deserve skepticism. #energyindependent #opportunity #renewables #fossilfuels #energy #renewableenergynow Cycling the world, telling the human story of climate change. #climate #climatechange #fossilfuels #renewables #renewableenergy #renewablefuture #cycling #bicycling #biking #worldbybike #cycletouring #bicycletouring #activetransport #hesterthebike #travel #travelphotography #landscape #nikon #everydayclimatechange

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: Women of Kumik village high in India‚Äôs Zanskar Himalayan range take their cattle to the high summer grazing grounds around 4000m above sea level. In front of them now just bare land with the scars of a once mighty glacier than ran down the mountain to the village supplying the people with water. As you can see, it has now completely disappeared due to warming temperatures from climate change. The people of this particular village are now reliant on winter snowmelt, which is also in decline, for their water. However, the snowmelt that feeds the spring is not enough and Kumik is now is a perpetual state of drought, and many villagers have begun to relocate their lives and homes. . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #india #globalwarming #climatechangeisreal #environment #drought #water
tags: globalwarming, everydayclimatechange, environment, climatechangeisreal, water, climatechange, drought, repost, india

caption: #MerDeGlace, #montBlanc. #climatechange is real. #everydayclimatechange Witnessing climate change on the #Alps is as easy as taking a touristic ride on a cableway up to the Mont Blanc. Here, between Pointe Helbronner and Aiguille du Midi, is Mer de Glace glacier. In the distance, it is clearly visible the difference in colour of the rocks revealing where the ice level was some 100 yeas ago. View more at http://cosimosanitate.com/en/acute-mountain-bliss/ or follow link on my profile "Acute mountain bliss"

caption: Climate change affects everyone but the already vulnerable are at a greater risk. Poorer communities and especially women and children, without the means to build resillience face an uncertain future. In Lesotho, close to 50% of the population live below the poverty line, meaning close to zero ability to adapt. This is one of the areas where we, the developed nations, need to step up and provide help. caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Guest posting by Shailendra Yashwant @shaibaba Himalayas, Sikkim, India. The Himalayas, are sometimes called ‚Äòthe roof of the world‚Äô or Earth's ‚Äòthird pole" and Asia‚Äôs ‚Äòwater towers‚Äô because they supply fresh water to communities throughout South Asia. Roughly 210 million people live in the region, and another 1.3 billion people who live downstream depend on rivers fed in part by glaciers and mountain snowpacks. Climate change is having a severe impact on the amount of snow and ice precipitation in the Himalayas, which has serious implications for downstream water availability in both short and long term as up to 50% of the average annual flows in the rivers are contributed by snow and glacial melting. The melting glaciers would mean floods and fast run-offs in the rivers in the short term and droughts and water scarcity in the long term. Irregular availability of water is going to be the biggest hazard in future. This will alter the area‚Äôs erosion, river discharge and sediment patterns. Photo from my ongoing photography project ‚ÄúClimate change - Himalayan Odyssey‚Äù documenting climate change impacts and community adaptation initiatives in the Himalayas. #everydayclimatechange #shaibaba #globalwarming #climatechange #himalayas #sikkim #glaciers @thirdpole #watertowers #roofoftheworld #India
tags: watertowers, shaibaba, climatechange, himalayas, globalwarming, roofoftheworld, sikkim, repost, everydayclimatechange, india, glaciers

caption: Guest posting by Shailendra Yashwant @shaibaba Himalayas, Sikkim, India. The Himalayas, are sometimes called ‚Äòthe roof of the world‚Äô or Earth's ‚Äòthird pole" and Asia‚Äôs ‚Äòwater towers‚Äô because they supply fresh water to communities throughout South Asia. Roughly 210 million people live in the region, and another 1.3 billion people who live downstream depend on rivers fed in part by glaciers and mountain snowpacks. Climate change is having a severe impact on the amount of snow and ice precipitation in the Himalayas, which has serious implications for downstream water availability in both short and long term as up to 50% of the average annual flows in the rivers are contributed by snow and glacial melting. The melting glaciers would mean floods and fast run-offs in the rivers in the short term and droughts and water scarcity in the long term. Irregular availability of water is going to be the biggest hazard in future. This will alter the area‚Äôs erosion, river discharge and sediment patterns. Photo from my ongoing photography project ‚ÄúClimate change - Himalayan Odyssey‚Äù documenting climate change impacts and community adaptation initiatives in the Himalayas. #everydayclimatechange #shaibaba #globalwarming #climatechange #himalayas #sikkim #glaciers @thirdpole #watertowers #roofoftheworld #India

caption: Photo by @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: Women of Kumik village high in India‚Äôs Zanskar Himalayan range take their cattle to the high summer grazing grounds around 4000m above sea level. In front of them now just bare land with the scars of a once mighty glacier than ran down the mountain to the village supplying the people with water. As you can see, it has now completely disappeared due to warming temperatures from climate change. The people of this particular village are now reliant on winter snowmelt, which is also in decline, for their water. However, the snowmelt that feeds the spring is not enough and Kumik is now is a perpetual state of drought, and many villagers have begun to relocate their lives and homes. . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #india #globalwarming #climatechangeisreal #environment #drought #water
tags: globalwarming, india, drought, climatechangeisreal, climatechange, water, environment, everydayclimatechange

Writing is in the works. #climateaction #fracking #frackfreeohio #nofracking #nopipelines #frackoff #everydayclimatechange

caption: The risks of climate change are not easy to communicate clearly. Since the atmosphere affects everything, everything will be affected by its warming ‚Äî there‚Äôs no single risk, but a wide and varied array of risks, of different severity and scales, affecting different systems, unfolding on different timelines. . . One of the better-known and more controversial attempts to address this problem is a graphic from the reports by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. The so-called ‚Äúburning embers‚Äù graph attempts to render the various risks of climate change ‚Äî ‚Äúreasons for concern,‚Äù or RFCs ‚Äî in an easy-to-grasp visual form. . . The graphic is generally accurate (though it has key limitations). They offer suggestions for how the RFC framework could be extended in the future to ‚Äúbetter account for possible changes in social and ecological system vulnerability.‚Äù . . The thermometer on the right shows temperatures relative to preindustrial levels; the thermometer on the left shows them relative to 1986-2005. The distance between the two blue lines is warming that occurred through 2005. (As that note on the right indicates, warming is up a bit 2003-2012.) . . Following the IPCC, risks are divided into five buckets or RFCs: . . ‚ñ´Risks to unique and threatened systems. ‚ñ´Risks associated with extreme weather events. ‚ñ´Risks associated with the distribution of impacts. ‚ñ´Risks associated with global aggregate impacts. ‚ñ´Risks associated with large-scale singular events. . . For more information on climate change and this ‚Äúall-in-one‚Äù graph visit the source via link in IG bio! . . #ClimateChange #Ecology #Endemism #Ecosystem #climateaction #everydayclimatechange
tags: ecology, endemism, climatechange, climateaction, ecosystem, everydayclimatechange

caption: A Tale of Bleeding Earth üå≤ part 3: üå≤ Just be concerned about reducing your own #carbon #footprints and consumption of #plastic.That would be enough to make this #planet really a #heaven to live. @leonardodicaprio @katewinsletdaily @alankapoor #leosavestheplanet #DidYouKnow the #factüëâ Plastic straws thrown in ocean enter into the nose of #sea #turtles and many #marine animals which leads to their death. caption: From the roots to the fruit. This tree gives me life. Nature gives me life. Connecting with Mother Earth gives us life. The Earth gives us everything we need and for FREE. We need her to survive. So why are we still letting industries destroy her? Start sharing ideas, start giving a shit (if for some insane reason you don't already), start putting plans into actions. No idea is too small. In fact, start small. We are smart enough to fix the mess we've made. I believe we can and I believe we will. THIS is where we need to be superheroes.

caption: La naturaleza se abre paso en cada rinc√≥n de Paraguay.

@Regrann from @ashleycrowtherorg - Women of Kumik village high in India‚Äôs Zanskar Himalayan range take their cattle to the high summer grazing grounds around 4000m above sea level. In front of them now just bare land with the scars of a once mighty glacier than ran down the mountain to the village supplying the people with water. As you can see, it has now completely disappeared due to warming temperatures from climate change. The people of this particular village are now reliant on winter snowmelt, which is also in decline, for their water. However, the snowmelt that feeds the spring is not enough and Kumik is now is a perpetual state of drought, and many villagers have begun to relocate their lives and homes. . #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #india #globalwarming #climatechangeisreal #environment #drought #water - #regrann
tags: environment, globalwarming, climatechangeisreal, climatechange, regrann, drought, water, india, everydayclimatechange

caption: Grande Isle, Louisiana is a barrier island on with Barataria Bay on one side and the Gulf on the other. It is sinking. According to NOAA, Grand Isle has lost 1.32 inches of elevation in the last 5 years. That multiplies out to 3 ft in a century. An estimated 1,400 people live here as of 2015. caption: Scarlet Macaw!! The scarlet macaw (Ara macao) is a large colorful South American parrot. It is native to humid evergreen forests of tropical South America. Macaws have suffered from local extinction through habitat destruction and capture for the parrot trade, but locally it remains fairly common. This particular bird was one of a pair of "Chicos", macaws that had once been pets and now have been returned to the wild. Since they had lost their fear of humans, they made a point of raiding the breakfast buffet every morning at the research center. #discoverglobe #canon_photos #canonusa #jj_daily #instagood #jj_nature #gramoftheday #weekly_feature #prestige_pics_ #charlottesville #exploretocreate #justgoshoot #theoutbound #WildlifePlanet #wildlifeonearth #WildlifeFriend #wildlife_perfection #wildlife_supreme #amazonaid #amazon #peru #everydayclimatechange #macawproject

caption: The Lower Ninth Ward has some lovely rows of new homes designed by internationally famous architects, all with solar panels especially near the Industrial Canal. Yet so much remains simply empty. Only about 25% of the pre-Katrina population remains. caption: Just inside the levee between Deslondes St and Reyes Streets, the 3 story building that housed the Holy Cross school for which the neighborhood is named sits abandoned. The building was severely damaged by Katrina and the school itself moved to Gentilly. caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. Empusel, the name the Maasai call the salty, dusty plains and from which the word ‚ÄòAmboseli‚Äô is derived, is about to relish in the first of the rains. The Amboseli basin, a semi-arid, open savannah area of southern Kenya, has experienced extensive changes in habitat since the early 1960's with daily temperatures increasing dramatically at a greater rate than that attributed to global warming. Amboseli has experienced an extensive loss of the trees due to a rising water table and the related rise of the salt layer in the soil, to grazing patterns, to a natural ageing of the woodlands, and to damage from an increasingly resident elephant population now unable to move the distances they used to due to growing human population around the reserve. The temperature changes here are now causing the landscape changes, and to confuse matters the temperature pattern may itself have been caused by the landscape changes. The climate change discussion is as dynamic and as important as ever. #climatechange #globalwarming #ic_landscapes #travel #natgeohub @natgeotravel #desertification #dust #everydayclimatechange #drought #deforestation #trees #colorcrush #horizon #canon #canonphotos #canon5dmarkiii

caption: #Repost @groundtruth with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª A woman fetches water for washing clothes from a shrimp farm in Kochukhali village. While the salt water makes it hard to cultivate rice, the traditional crop in the area, shrimp thrives in the saline water. Selling shrimp earned much more money than any other fish, and wealthy farmers were attracted to the fish they called ‚Äúwhite gold‚Äù. Now, daily wage farm laborers find it hard to find work, as the shrimp farms that have proliferated in the area, need very few laborers. üì∑ @nehanotes ... #climatechange #everydayclimatechange #photojournalism #photography #bangladesh #asia #waterislife

caption: "La revanche" - 2016 Marbre noir Golzinne de Belgique Black marble Golzinne from Belgium "Les catastrophes nucl√©aires ont beau d√©vaster tout un paysage, en quatre ou en 30 ans, m√®re nature sait reprendre ses droits... Surtout l√† o√π l'Homme a d√©sert√©... cela ne signifie pas que la radioactivit√© est bonne pour la faune sauvage, mais seulement que les effets des activit√©s humaines comme l'agriculture, la chasse et l'exploitation foresti√®re sont nettement pires" "No matter how nuclear disasters devastate everything around within four or thirty years, mother nature knows how to take back its course...especially where Man has deserted...which does not mean that radioactivity is good for wildlife but only that the effects of human activities such as agriculture, hunting and logging are much worse..." (les echos, revue Current Biology: "fukushima, tchernobyl, la nature a repris ses droits") #art#marbre#marble#sculpture#sculptures#tailledirecte#directcarving#artist#fineart#ecology#ecologie#artcontemporain#contemporaryart#fineartist#artwork#artlovers#sculptor#savoirfaire#handmade#madeinfrance#climatechange#everydayclimatechange#lanaturereprendsesdroits#naturetakesbackitscourse

caption: Photo by Georgina Goodwin @ggkenya for @everydayclimatechange. Empusel, the name the Maasai call the salty, dusty plains and from which the word ‚ÄòAmboseli‚Äô is derived, is about to relish in the first of the rains. The Amboseli basin, a semi-arid, open savannah area of southern Kenya, has experienced extensive changes in habitat since the early 1960's with daily temperatures increasing dramatically at a greater rate than that attributed to global warming. Amboseli has experienced an extensive loss of the trees due to a rising water table and the related rise of the salt layer in the soil, to grazing patterns, to a natural ageing of the woodlands, and to damage from an increasingly resident elephant population now unable to move the distances they used to due to growing human population around the reserve. The temperature changes here are now causing the landscape changes, and to confuse matters the temperature pattern may itself have been caused by the landscape changes. The climate change discussion is as dynamic and as important as ever. #climatechange #globalwarming #ic_landscapes #travel #natgeohub @natgeotravel #desertification #dust #everydayclimatechange #drought #deforestation #trees #colorcrush #horizon #canon #canon5dmarkiii #vsco #canonphotos

caption: http://bit.ly/2hWrMPS > protectourwinters.org/keepparis PC: the wonderful CED who doesn't gram #wildlife #wildlifephotography #natgeowild #alaska #arctic #spectacledeider #duck #ducksunlimited #conservation #climatechange #keepparis #activism #birds #nationalbirdday #audubonsociety #protectourwinters #nature #seaice #nsf #everydayclimatechange">Spectacled eiders fly over melting ice on the Bering Sea. Join me @protectourwinters @jeremyjones and @brodyleven today in tweeting to @realdonaldtrump about the importance of the Paris Climate Agreement by using #KeepParis. Photo choice is also in honor of National Bird Day! The facts: These large sea ducks are currently listed as an endangered species. They spend most of their lives at sea, only coming ashore to breed and nest. Their distribution limited to a few specific areas in northern Russia and Alaska, and the entire population winters at a single site in the Arctic ocean. At this site, availability of sea ice and forage such as clams and polychete worms are critical to winter survival. The USGS states that "it is difficult to predict how this threatened species will respond to rapid climate and ecosystem change in the future." More information at > http://bit.ly/2hWrMPS > protectourwinters.org/keepparis PC: the wonderful CED who doesn't gram #wildlife #wildlifephotography #natgeowild #alaska #arctic #spectacledeider #duck #ducksunlimited #conservation #climatechange #keepparis #activism #birds #nationalbirdday #audubonsociety #protectourwinters #nature #seaice #nsf #everydayclimatechange

caption: So pod3 is of a fella who looks like he is straight out of central casting walking across the upper Snowy River... which just goes to prove that there is always a photo to be had even in the most remote places! But the image has a serious undertone... mans relationship to fresh water is going to be more and more of a priority in the future... the more we disregard how we use the water we have the more we will regret it in the future... the biodiversity of a heating planet is under threat and if we don't acknowledge the science behind climate change by voting in leaders who understand this then frankly I think we are in for very big problems in the very near future... #yearsjourney #natgeoyourshot #photooftheweek #photooftheday #photojournalism #australianlife #mountainlife #snowymountainsnsw #water #river #snowyriver #reportage #everydayclimatechange

caption: #Repost @everydayclimatechange with @repostapp „Éª„Éª„Éª Photo by Ashley Crowther @ashleycrowtherorg for @everydayclimatechange: Wheat fields blow in the Himalayan wind at Kumik village located in the Zanskar Himalayan range, India. Kumik‚Äôs glacier, which once provided the village with ample water, has now all but disappeared due to warming temperatures from climate change. . The village now struggles to water its subsistence crops adequately through the short summer harvest season and is in a perpetual state of drought. The communities in this region already have extremely hard working lives; the changing climate and lack of access to water are pushing people to the limits. Many in this village pictured have begun to relocate their centuries-old homes closer to a new water source. #everydayclimatechange #climatechange #globalwarming #migration #drought #climatechangeisreal #asia #environment
tags: climatechangeisreal, climatechange, environment, migration, drought, globalwarming, repost, asia, everydayclimatechange
